Title: It Was Like My Trying to Have a Tender-Hearted Nature: A Novella and Stories
Author: Diane Williams

Title: It Was Like My Trying to Have a Tender-Hearted Nature: A Novella and Stories
Author: Diane Williams

Title: Thirteen Days in September: Carter, Begin, and Sadat at Camp David
Author: Lawrence Wright

Title: Swimming Home
Author: Deborah Levy
My Review: A strange, disquieting, hopeless fugue: six people lounge about a villa on the French Riviera, but no-one is happy, and the book follows the strange logic of dreams, moving its feet but not its body. If surrealist beauty was the "sewing machine and umbrella on the operating table", this book might be the dead mouse encountering a melting ice cream on the poolside lounger. One character is a Holocaust survivor poet, but it is the beautiful Kitty Finch and her black, unhappy heart that suffuse this odd, memorable book.

Title: Amusing Ourselves to Death: Public Discourse in the Age of Show Business
Author: Neil Postman
My Review:
The media has changed a huge amount since this book came out, in ways complex and hard to classify. So large parts of Prof Postman's get-off-my-lawn snark about TV is obsolete, but his rules are still helpful. A student of Marshall McLuhan, Postman's central tenet is the former's famous doctrine: the medium is the message. A TV can be used to prop up books, or for ambient reading light, but this doesn't make it a medium of literacy. Thus too all attempts to convert it into a medium of enlightenment will crash against the irresistible straitjacket of form. (Who still watches those dimly-lit, high-minded, long-monologue shows on public TV?)

Postman is most interesting when he tracks the shift in modes of thuoght between eras with different dominant media - from orality to writing, writing to printing, and printing to TV. In his telling, the US had the rare luck to be founded by intellectuals, and maintained astonishing levels of public interest in policy and rational debate until around the turn of the 20th century. Then several things changed: the rise of images and jingles in advertising, the invention of photography and telegraphy, and then the great menace of TV. The very concept of the day's news is a technological invention (he quotes the Luddish Thoreau: “We are in great haste to construct a magnetic telegraph from Maine to Texas; but Maine and Texas, it may be, have nothing important to communicate... We are eager to tunnel under the Atlantic and bring the old world some weeks nearer to the new; but perchance the first news that will leak through into the broad flapping American ear will be that Princess Adelaide has the whooping cough.” )

So what ought we to make of podcasts, blogs, even - dare we ask - Twitter? I think blogger Hossein Derakhshan (or Hoder) is right thatthe internet started off primarily text-based, and as it changes to be more image- and video-based, it has gotten worse, form dictating content. Twitter, and social media more generally, encourage snark, snap judgments, and anger. But there is so much else. Might, say, podcasts be our salvation?

I recently read a blog post arguing that reading the news has no value whatsoever to one's life. Setting aside the author and his tragic early death, I think this claim is embedded in a worldview that already seems quaint. Swartz thinks that if the newspaper criticises the mayor, the mayor will apologise or justify herself or whatever, so why does the reader need to get involved? But nowadays the mayor has her own media. It is harder to split entertainment on an axis of brain-food to brain-mush, and there are broader political quandaries. But still, our media consumption takes on the shape of the conduit through which it reaches us.

Title: Deep Work: Rules for Focused Success in a Distracted World
Author: Cal Newport
My Review:
Like everyone these days, I wish I knew how to spend less time distracted by digital devices and more on things that matter. Unfortunately, this book is a pretty terrible guide. Its first half is spent proving the idea that idly browsing social media is less productive than doing something creative. The author also commits a pet peeve I like to call "scaring with science" - quoting, for example, a line of SQL or a bit of a software manual not to explain it but to impress the reader with how daunting and incomprehensible it is.

But the worst is that this book reads like a parody a French socialist might have written of American 'fordisme'. Its underlying assumption is that the sole priority of gaining better focus is to become a higher-earning "winner", and it’s full of irrelevant and fatuous predictions about the future of the economy, leveraging the implicit threat that AI and genius programmers will make us all redundant unless we learn how to focus.

Later on the book improves slightly, wielding Marshall McLuhan, Neil Postman and Hubert Dreyfus in an attempt to prove that greater focus leads to a more meaningful life. But at the end of the book's second half - a hodgepodge of simplistic anecdotes and cherry-picked research - Newport admits that this technique is worthwhile only to the extent that it increases your productivity. And yet: I can't unrecommend this entirely. If reading it inspires you to reduce the time you spend being distracted by the flashing lights of the internet, or even to stop yourself from prioritising mindless tasks over work you're proud of, it might be worthwhile.

Title: The Origin of Consciousness in the Breakdown of the Bicameral Mind
Author: Julian Jaynes
My Review: There seems to be a popular perception that this book is sort of "crazy, but might just be true" (possibly inspired by a Richard Dawkins quip). I'm here to say: this book is crazy! But it's a fascinating read, as sort of creative nonfiction. Jaynes, a pretty respected psychologist writing in a time that was perhaps more receptive to New Age-y big picture ideas, thinks that a) schizophrenia is the natural, pre-conscious state of humans, which b) explains idolatry, ancestor worship and basically all religion from ancient times, and that c) consciousness is a relatively recent phenomenon which developed when external stresses broke up the "bicameral" societies (people whose minds were split into a speaking part, a sort of auditory (or sometimes visual) hallucination), and a listening part. He evinces examples from Greek literature, the Bible, and ancient history, as well as neuropsychological studies, his own experiences with schizophrenic patients, and his consumption of hallucinogens. I haven't seen Westworld.

Title: Half-Earth: Our Planet's Fight for Life
Author: Edward O. Wilson
My Review: If you're reading this, you're probably concerned about our unfolding ecological catastrophe, which has only gotten worse since this book came out. Wilson's comically unfeasible plan is to give over half the planet to wildlife. Given the inability of the world's governments to agree on even the mildest steps to protect the environment, you can safely ignore this pompous, rambling book, whose Pulitzer seems a perfect example of futile virtue signalling.

Title: The Long Ships
Author: Frans G. Bengtsson
My Review: Astonishingly entertaining yarn written in the sparse manner of ancient epics, with little introspection, spare, clipped prose, and jarring attitudes towards violence, honour and religion. There's plenty of historical data submerged in this tale of Northern men gone "viking" in the southern lands, who encounter Andalusian Muslims and Jews, Irish jesters, Khazars, England being fought over between Danes and Anglo-Saxons, and the creeping Christianisation of Scandinavia. But again: it's nothing deep, but endlessly fun, gripping, and often funny.

Title: The Deluge: The Great War, America and the Remaking of the Global Order, 1916-1931
Author: Adam Tooze
My Review:
Tooze knows an enormous amount of facts. His history is global, and economically informed. But he's not the most fun to read. His sentences are crisp and learned, but this book is lumpy, crooked. It presents fascinating anecdotes which abruptly end. I kept asking myself what the central thesis is, and though I have some ideas, I'm still not sure. In an odd twist, most of the book covers a few years around WWI in great detail, while the last bit rushes through about a decade in almost no time, skipping the rise of Stalin and the Great Depression.

But here is what I think is his point: between WWI and the 1930s, the world shifted from being a multilateral sphere of competing imperial Great Powers, to one of tenuous international organisations with the dominant presence of American might (and Wall Street finance) overshadowing it. Much of the war was paid for by loans from JP Morgan and his friends, and afterwards the victors were in nearly as bad financial shape as the losers. Much of the German repayments from the Versailles Treaty went straight from Britain and France to America, where at some points they were lent back to Germany. And the book ends with Ramsey McDonald's courageous decisions to go off the gold standard and finally, unthinkably, default on war debts, saying:

Payments that would upset the financial order such as it is would be treason to the whole world. We have to take upon ourselves the thankless task of putting an end to the folly of continuing to pay


Mr Tooze is sympathetic to the pacifists and liberal internationalists, the animating spirit behind the League of Nations and the Kellogg-Briand ban on war, and Woodrow Wilson's desire for American influence to obtain "peace without victory" in the Great War, a New World Order rather than an intervention in favour of one side. Such ideas in his view weren't utopian folly but a way of dealing with new conditions: imperial might was untenable when everyone but the US was drowning in debt (and later when even the US looked ropy). Prior to the war, the Prussian or Westminster models of government (or "Liberal Imperialism") were seen as superior to democracy, but the tumultuous forces of nationalism, liberalism among imperial subjects, and the crushing economic depression eviscerated that order and set the stage for the violence of the next war, and the arrangement of the present time.

Title: A Time to Keep Silence
Author: Patrick Leigh Fermor
My Review: PLF's two great gifts - boundless, obscure knowledge, and an infectious enthusiasm - are brought to bear on the sombre beauty of monastic life, in France and (now abandoned) in Cappadocia. Even if you think you're not interested in the topic, Fermor will rope you in.

Author: Patrick Leigh Fermor
My Review: PLF's two great gifts - boundless, obscure knowledge, and an infectious enthusiasm - are brought to bear on the sombre beauty of monastic life, in France and (now abandoned) in Cappadocia. Even if you think you're not interested in the topic, Fermor will rope you in.

Title: Between the Woods and the Water
Author: Patrick Leigh Fermor
My Review:
Claudio Magris’s Danube was a subtle expansion of the possibilities of travel writing. Or one could just delete the ‘travel’ part altogether and say it’s a great piece of writing. That deletion cannot always be safely made since certain titles enjoy a reputation as ‘travel’ classics while falling way below more general standards of literary achievement. Patrick Leigh Fermor’s A Time of Gifts depends on these standards being dispensed with entirely.


What Geoff Dyer really means there is that Patrick Leigh Fermor's writing is travel writing par excellence, a genre I don't think I really recognised until I read this book and its predecessor. One gets books that are basically true stories involving a trip (Bruce Chatwin and Bill Bryson are good at these), or mostly informative but unliterary medieval 'travel journals' (one great exception to this is the majestic, Jacobian [b:Travels in Arabia Deserta|854738|Travels in Arabia Deserta, Volume 1|Charles M. Doughty|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1178925822s/854738.jpg|840230]). Dyer's example, Danube, is basically Magris chatting about highbrow lit, roughly organised by geographic location.

But Fermor is pretty much the perfect traveller, and almost the Platonic ideal travel writer. Young but astonishingly educated, he is quick at picking up languages, able to connect with everyone he meets, and to name everything around him, be it plant, beast, fowl, heraldic symbol, architectural nuance, or landscape. I was overwhelmed by the rococo English words (many of which stymied my e-reader's feeble built-in dictionary), feeling like I inhabit a duller, flatter more impoverished world than Fermor's. (And perhaps to some extent this is true: educational priorities have shifted, and the vagaries of the Information Age find us indoors more. In a soulful epilogue, the author laments that the time capsule of a Muslim, Turkish-speaking island on the Romanian Danube has been literally swamped by a hydroelectric power project, the inhabitants transferred elsewhere, their mosque meticulously taken apart and restored.)

Fermor does have some connections, and through these and their extended network he has fun staying in castles with old nobles and traipsing around the more playful cities in the old Empire, even seemingly falling in love at one point. Yet even without these friends, he strikes up conversations with everyone, sharing a rabbit stew with a shepherd's family, trying to learn Rumanian from gyspsy gold prospectors, talking Scripture with some black-clad Hasidim in a logging camp. (And according to a story, swapping lines from Virgil with a captured German officer during WWII, with Latin their common language.) And he is equally adept on his own, trying to map places to classical names, observing plants and animals.

Why travel? Today might be a Golden Age for it, with cheap airfare and accomodation, and abundant advice online. Yet for so many people the experience feels wasted. PLF is the perfect travel companion: extremely knowledgeable to begin with, always curious, animated every minute by a meeting with a stranger or an unfamiliar bird or tree. It's an approach not just to travel but to life. The world he writes of has been swallowed up by time, but his descriptions, and his echt-humanist mindset, remain timeless.

Addendum: really excited for this.

Title: A Time of Gifts
Author: Patrick Leigh Fermor
Bookshelves: aesthetes-hedonists-bohemians, art-aesthetics-culture, mais-o-sont-les-neiges-d-antan, modern-classics, nyrb, travel, sad-young-literary-men
Bookshelves with positions: aesthetes-hedonists-bohemians (#5), art-aesthetics-culture (#16), mais-o-sont-les-neiges-d-antan (#24), modern-classics (#8), nyrb (#10), travel (#2), sad-young-literary-men (#23)
My Review: So many good reviews here, so I haven't too much to add. Fermor's boyish excitement (even when recalled by the author forty years later), good nature, and extraordinary knowledge about history, art and architecture, make him a thrilling travel companion. Even when I got lost in the thickets of detailed cathedral descriptions, I was carried along by how much fun he was having. Alive to the possibilities of adventure, beauty and a near-religious appreciation of culture.

Title: A Time of Gifts
Author: Patrick Leigh Fermor

My Review: So many good reviews here, so I haven't too much to add. Fermor's boyish excitement (even when recalled by the author forty years later), good nature, and extraordinary knowledge about history, art and architecture, make him a thrilling travel companion. Even when I got lost in the thickets of detailed cathedral descriptions, I was carried along by how much fun he was having. Alive to the possibilities of adventure, beauty and a near-religious appreciation of culture.

Title: A Time of Gifts
Author: Patrick Leigh Fermor
Bookshelves: aesthetes-hedonists-bohemians, art-aesthetics-culture, mais-o-sont-les-neiges-d-antan, modern-classics, nyrb, travel, sad-young-literary-men
Bookshelves with positions: aesthetes-hedonists-bohemians (#5), art-aesthetics-culture (#16), mais-o-sont-les-neiges-d-antan (#24), modern-classics (#8), nyrb (#10), travel (#2), sad-young-literary-men (#23)
My Review: So many good reviews here, so I haven't too much to add. Fermor's boyish excitement (even when recalled by the author forty years later), good nature, and extraordinary knowledge about history, art and architecture, make him a thrilling travel companion. Even when I got lost in the thickets of detailed cathedral descriptions, I was carried along by how much fun he was having. Alive to the possibilities of adventure, beauty and a near-religious appreciation of culture.

Title: Paradise Lost
Author: John Milton
My Review:
You can really trace the shrinkage of people's attention spans even from Milton's time to Samuel Johnson's: the latter's quip about no-one wishing it longer isn't (I realised while reading this) a critique, just an observation: it's really, really, long, and demands a high level of concentration and research. But Milton was writing in the vein of other (even longer) epics from pre-literate times: the Iliad, Aeneid (the beginning lines have an intentionally similar ring), and later the Divine Comedy. It's a cinematic, exciting retelling of the story of Genesis, and although it's pretty sexist and the theology doesn't always make sense (is God omnipotent or not?), you still end up moved, especially at the sad but hopeful tone of the closing lines:
High in Front advanc't,
The brandisht Sword of God before them blaz'd
Fierce as a Comet; which with torrid heat,
And vapour as the Libyan Air adust, [ 635 ]
Began to parch that temperate Clime; whereat
In either hand the hastning Angel caught
Our lingring Parents, and to th' Eastern Gate
Led them direct, and down the Cliff as fast
To the subjected Plaine; then disappeer'd. [ 640 ]
They looking back, all th' Eastern side beheld
Of Paradise, so late thir happie seat,
Wav'd over by that flaming Brand, the Gate
With dreadful Faces throng'd and fierie Armes:
Som natural tears they drop'd, but wip'd them soon; [ 645 ]
The World was all before them, where to choose
Thir place of rest, and Providence thir guide:
They hand in hand with wandring steps and slow,
Through Eden took thir solitarie way.

Title: The Law of Peoples with The Idea of Public Reason Revisited
Author: John Rawls
My Review:
Who today believes in the principle of spreading democracy through armed force? Hearing Rawls, one of liberalism's most eminent voices, talk himself into it by way of consensus through international bodies, IMF sanctions, and coalitions of "decent", "well-ordered" nations against outlaw states, brings to light the rapid changes in public politics that have passed since this book came out. Such ideas, having proved catastrophic in practice, are now seen as abhorrent and illegitimate, curiously branded both "neoliberal" and "neoconservative".

The central idea that this book adds to [b:A Theory of Justice|129237|A Theory of Justice|John Rawls|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1348730096s/129237.jpg|1383130] and [b:Political Liberalism|129238|Political Liberalism|John Rawls|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1347440024s/129238.jpg|2022651] is that a just order between nations needs more latitude than one within a nation. Liberal democracy is an ideal, but we needn't shun "decent" nations - those who don't abuse human rights, but are not liberal. (Rawls gives as an example the imaginary Muslim state of Kazanistan.) A political philosopher must be careful to avoid the statistical crime of "overfitting" - designing a model that too closely resembles her immediate surroundings, and can't be generalised. As Francis Fukuyama would know, the world in the early '90s gave off some promising signals, but reading them too closely would have been a mistake.

Title: The Fall of Constantinople 1453
Author: Steven Runciman
My Review: An enjoyable, short history, not too different from the relevant parts of Gibbon but more fleshed out and with less bias (Runciman doesn't sell short the Turks, who seem more enlightened that the Christians, too zealously schismatic to save their city; nor does he overstate the significance of these events - after all, if it hadn't happened in 1453 it would have happened shortly after), and as haughty and mandarin a writing voice. He thinks that Gibbon saw Byzantium mostly as a barbaric mistake. I hadn't realised that the Crusaders took over Constantinople for Western Christianity after sacking it, for nearly 60 years; until the Palaiologos dynasty brought back the Greeks. After the city fell the Ottomans slowly took over the rest of the Orthodox world, and Russia became the main stronghold of the church. Runciman thinks it a shame that modern Greek nationalism became associated only with the southern tip of the Balkan Peninsula, rather than the broader Greek world. I'm not sure if that's such a bad thing, but it would certainly have obviated the Macedonia naming dispute.

Title: Journey by Moonlight
Author: Antal Szerb
My Review: Intensely Mitteleuropa, and just...intense. A psychological novel full of callbacks to Classical antiquity and a somewhat Jungian dimension, which feels dated, but the self-destructive anxieties of characters desperate to escape conformity, and this novel's surprising humour, made it surprisingly engaging, sometimes even fun!

Title: In Search of Zarathustra: The First Prophet and the Ideas That Changed the World
Author: Paul Kriwaczek
My Review: Somewhat meandering travelogue-cum-history-book. Kriwaczek knows a lot of history but sprays it in all directions, and his attempts to wedge in a lot of only slightly related topics makes for an uneven read. He sees Zoroastrian influence not just in the Cathars (martyred in the Albigensian Crusade), Manicheans and Mithraists (familiar to readers of [b:The Recognitions|395058|The Recognitions|William Gaddis|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1309209622s/395058.jpg|1299804]), and their modern-day descendants the Parsees; but also in Judaism, Islam, Christianity. There's quite a bit on modern(ish) Iran and Afghanistan. Did the ancient Persian faith survive Islamisation into customs like the Nowruz festival, and Shia Islam in general? (An amazing story: as late as 930, a fire-worshiping sect called the Qarmations took over Mecca, stole the Kaaba, and broke it!) Not if you ask Iranians, but who knows.

Title: John Dewey and the High Tide of American Liberalism
Author: Alan  Ryan
My Review:
The only part of Louis Menand's terrific primer on pragmatism [b:The Metaphysical Club|28202|The Metaphysical Club|Louis Menand|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1348603592s/28202.jpg|889248] that left me still feeling a bit in the dark was the one on Dewey, so this was a natural follow-up. What emerged is that lack of clarity is a mark of studying Dewey; a youthful immersion in German Idealism, lack of humour and singularly infelicitous writing style made him flummox even his most sympathetic readers. O.W. Holmes Jr. put it best: "So methought God would have spoken had He been inarticulate but keenly desirous to tell you how it was."

Which is not to say that no-one gets Dewey. Ryan gives a thorough outline of his origins, intellectual inputs, main writing and controversies. Dewey was a towering figure in American intellectual life in his day, engaging in many public political and philosophical debates. One of his key ideas was that philosophy cannot be segregated from the public space, that daily life and political engagement must be natural outflows of one's metaphysical ideas. In the late 1890s Dewey expressed this with his involvement with Jane Addams' Hull House and the Laboratory School he founded in Chicago, and later it was progressive education that came to be the main focus of his thought.

More spiritual than his pragmatist peers (James, Peirce, Holmes), Dewey enveloped his thought in a deep layer of near-religious teleology. His early Congregationalist faith, which he would later rebel strongly against, coupled with his later Hegelianism (also eventually dropped, but less markedly) gave him this orientation. Dewey would become a materialist, but never a "vulgar" one; for him, individual fulfillment is impossible outside of community engagement. For this reason Dewey was seen the philosopher of America, a liberal idealist for whom democracy was not "the worst form of government, except for all the others" but the highest means through which the individual can find happiness. Until the end of his life Dewey would give "lay sermons" and was active in political debate.

However, as Holmes' quote hinted, his noumenal rhetoric never quite manifested itself in concrete terms, making Dewey open to misreadings, and ensuring there are no real "Deweyists" today. Attacked in his time from left and right, (he voted against FDR because he thought the New Deal didn't go far enough; but never stopped attacking the Communist Party for its subservience to Moscow and indifference to human rights, strongly and presciently opposing the evils of Stalinism, and even being involved in a Mexico hearing for Trotsky), Dewey was mostly forgotten after his death, then revived. Attacked by Christopher Lasch as an elitist, by Richard Hofstadter as anti-intellectual, Dewey finally found a champion in Richard Rorty, who saw him a more hopeful harbinger of postmodernism.

So after this big book, what is Dewey about? Firstly we can say what he opposed: big business/plutocracy, the Communist Party, rote learning (and the worship of classics such as the U Chicago Great Books program of Hutchins and Adler). As for the positive, Dewey advanced a communitarian ideal where education would uplift all citizens of a democracy into an engaged, participatory life. He supported learning through doing (some of his educational ideas are taken for granted nowadays), but also vaguer things. He advocated imbuing vocational training with more importance by making it less menial - but how? Dewey saw production under capitalism, just for the sake of a paycheck, as inherently alienating and inconducive with a fulfilled life. But how would his alternative society look? He acknowledged that the average man doesn't want to come back from work, grab some supper, and then head out to a meeting on which electricity supplier the neighbourhood should use.

Liberalism can mean many different things - Dewey's is much more like (in Isaiah Berlin's phrase that Ryan doesn't use) "freedom to" than "freedom from", much unlike JS Mill, Smith, and Hayek. Dewey also differs from the contemporary American left, which is a more practical Social Democracy lite. Dewey cannot be said to have given undue focus to practical issues, and his work can be frustrating, its meaning never quite coming into focus. But that blurry vision is still audacious and inspiring.

Title: HHhH
Author: Laurent Binet
My Review: Not quite what I expected: basically a straightforward telling of a thrilling episode from WWII (for once I must refrain from spoilers, because not knowing the outcome really will increase your enjoyment of this book), but with frequent interjections from Binet: musing about the differences between made-up and historical characters, perusing the many books and films written about this story, recollections of his childhood and his Czechoslovak connections, and occasionally catching himself out for overdramatising. Light on the pomo, and a ripping tale: I just found it hard to stomach more Nazis, having already read Shirer's [b:The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich|767171|The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich  A History of Nazi Germany|William L. Shirer|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1331223772s/767171.jpg|1437584] this year...

Title: The Professor and the Madman: A Tale of Murder, Insanity and the Making of the Oxford English Dictionary
Author: Simon Winchester
My Review: Fun yarn about an schizophrenic American doctor in a British mental asylum and his role in the making of the OED, and through that the more general history of English dictionaries/the OED. If you like Bill Bryson, you'll probably like this chatty mini-history of an astonishing intellectual accomplishment, one you probably never think about in the age of Google.

Title: Down Girl: The Logic of Misogyny
Author: Kate Manne
My Review:
Per its author, this is the first book written on misogyny, a subject Manne has some expertise in: in an interview, she relates being one of three girls going to classes at an all-boys' school, where her locker was covered in misogynistic slurs and fish oil, and being advanced on by a group of boys holding condoms they'd ejaculated into. She is also an MIT- and Harvard-trained philosopher who currently lectures at Cornell.

This book is not fun to read, being an unremitting litany of grievous misogyny: from the violent (Elliot Rodger's deadly rampage at UC Santa Barbara) to the casual, including much about the 2016 elections and America's current president. Manne mostly (though not always) stays cool and detached, using the tools and argot of analytic philosophy. She uses the metaphor of a customer and a server at a restaurant to describe male-female relations, where men feel entitled to service and pleasantness from women, and feel aggrieved if they do not receive them.

While ostensibly a (popular) work of moral philosophy, this often feels exhortative, more like social critique. Rather than referring to things widely considered wrong, Manne often jumps into the heat of currently raging ideological battles, calling out evil and taxonomising it along with stranglers and mass shooters. At least some of the things she classifies as misogynist - like the poetry of Shel Silverstein - might have a more charitable reading. The extent to which misogyny affected Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign (or Julia Gillard's tenure as Australian PM) seems open to discussion; certainly not nothing, but surely not 100% either. For Manne, the idea that Clinton was seen as an "establishment" candidate can be nothing other than bare misogyny. (Relevant disclosure: I'm not American, but I was only ever rooting for a Hillary win.)

In a famous essay called Away From a Definition of Antisemitism, the historian David Engel criticises the idea of using a single term for, say, Christian or Islamic persecution of Jews and the Nazi kind, or overly personal criticisms of Israel. One could similarly question to what extent it is right to cite one explanatory mechanism for all these complex issues.

In general, the use of moral absolutes in discussing fraught political issues seems potentially reckless. In 2015, after the Conservative victory in elections in Britain, the philosopher Rebecca Roache wrote a post on Oxford University's Practical Ethics Blog declaring that "If you’re a Conservative, I’m not your friend". Saying that the other half of the country is not just in disagreement but immoral is not obviously wrong - the classic Ethics 101 example of Germany under the Nazis comes to mind. But it seems like a claim requiring extraordinary evidence. Manne represents liberal beliefs with which I'm almost entirely in accord, but the righteous anger with which she brands her ideological opponents seems unsupported to me. The book ends not with prescriptions but with despair (although Manne is at work on a sequel entitled Himpathy, one of several neologisms in the book), something seemingly inevitable under a worldview in which unveiled hatred is everywhere and incurable.

Also of note is Moira Weigel's mild critique of this book from the Left, found here.

Title: The Popes
Author: John Julius Norwich
My Review:
All the popes - they're all here, from St Peter to Benedict XVI! (Not Francis, though, who took over several years after this book came out.) I thought each section would go through one pope, but there were loads of insignificant or very brief ones, and Norwich wisely structures his story by epochs. The story of the Papacy must to some extent be a history of Europe: after all, the Papal States were a major political player for most of it. Norwich recaps the respective heroism and ignominy of different popes, giving political and theological background and requoting some of Gibbon's most epic burns, e.g.
we read, with some surprise, that the worthy grandson of Marozia lived in public adultery with the matrons of Rome; that the Lateran Palace was turned into a school for prostitution; and that his rapes of virgins and widows had deterred the female pilgrims from visiting the shrine of St. Peter, lest, in the devout act, they should be violated by his successor
as well as the well-known
the most scandalous charges were suppressed; the vicar of Christ was only accused of piracy, murder, rape, sodomy, and incest
Norwich is an "agnostic Protestant" who is fond of the Papacy but doesn't cover anything up, dealing briefly with the worst popes of the "pornocracy", the Borgias, and Pius XII and the Nazis, as well as putting to bed the legend of a female Pope (since which time a junior cleric feels up each new Pope and "shouts out in a loud voice, 'He has testicles!' And all the clerics present reply, 'God be praised!'"). From what I glean from GR reviews, people with a lot of knowledge about the subject won't like this book, but it's a good primer for novitiates like myself.

Title: Birds Through a Ceiling of Alabaster: Three Abbasid Poets
Author: George B.H. Wightman
Additional Authors: Abdullah Y. al-Udhari, Abbas ibn al-Ahnaf, Abdullah Ibn al-Mu'tazz, Abū al-ʿAlāʾ al-Maʿarrī

Title: The Holiday
Author: Stevie Smith
My Review:
Kind of like Philip Larkin, Smith covers her learning with a lumpy grey tarp. Her tools are misleadingly simple, demotic words (in a novel written during WWII, it feels relevant to note that Churchill tried to use "Anglo-Saxon words with the least number of syllables"). "He always liked larking, now he's dead" (from her best known poem). The fact that, while publishing this book several years after the war had ended, she simply replaced occurrences of the term "war" with "post-war", which makes little sense in many places ("Will we ever win the post-war?" "How long will the post-war go on?") gives you a sense of the seeming unseriousness of her technique, and whether you think this lazy or inspired is a pretty good bellwether for your feelings on the novel. There is background chatter of India and Palestine, de Gaulle and Stalin, but none of it matters a whit, because the narrator is listless and unhappy, perhaps bipolar, nursing an unreciprocated crush on her cousin Casmilus. For my money, in its perfectly flat yet elegant evocation of ennui, it's a minor masterpiece.

Asking if things like Celia's bizarre jingoism is sincere seems beside the point. Much of this text is odd and unfamiliar in (for me) just the right way, talk of Gibbon and the countryside veering onto questions about Jupiter's atmosphere. Smith's character Celia (presumably somewhat autobiographical) is learned and terribly unhappy, bleeding her vulnerability onto the page, constantly crying and thinking of suicide. And yet for all that those around her seem to appreciate her company, much as the literary world gave great esteem and success to this anxious poet and her jagged mind.

Title: Death in Venice and Other Tales
Author: Thomas Mann
My Review:
I got this collection primarily for Death in Venice - during a trip to Venice, how cliché ! - but I read the others first, and I think they set it up well. Having previously read Mann's bloated monster [b:The Magic Mountain|88077|The Magic Mountain|Thomas Mann|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1403170928s/88077.jpg|647489], I wasn't quite sure how to place him. Reading this, with some input from the helpful German-lang. Wikipedia, gave me some valuable background.

"It is as well" Mann writes in Death in Venice, "that the world knows only a fine piece of work and not its origins." But that is disingenuous, because many of Mann's stories very obviously reflect his own life. The archetypal Mann hero is the shy, awkward romantic from a respected but dull Hanseatic trading family, who yearns for true love, the warm South, and literary greatness. Writing mainly in the first half of the 20th c., Mann was aware of this trope as somewhat dusty, and usually plays it skew, or sometimes outright for laughs. Also, Mann wrote about perverse sex - lusting after young boys (totally based on his life)! twincest (based on his wife Katia's)! Perhaps not unusually for people who had seen the Weimar bohemia evaporate and fled the Nazis into exile, several members of the Mann family (many of whom were writers) took their own lives.

A quick breakdown of the plots of these stories/novellas:

-The Will for Happiness is a short story about an old, sick man who loves a young woman
-Tristan - mini-Magic Mountain. A Tristan and Isolde story in a sanatorium. But mildy satirical.
-Little Herr Friedmann is a crippled but otherwise successful man who thinks he can live without love, then falls in love (revealing Ibsen's idea of the Lebenslüge) - it doesn't end well
-Gladius Dei - a Savonarola-type zealot rails against art
-Tobias Mindernickel - a satire of the idea of the angry reclusive old guy with a heart of gold. (If animal abuse makes you squeamish, maybe give this one a miss!)
-Little Lizzy - a man prepares an "artsy" version of a pop song. It ends badly.
-The Starvelings - self-pitying artist type feels whiny
-Harsh Hour - the artist sees himself in the (disguised) body of Schiller, struggling to write but still banging it out in the end.
-The Wunderkind - comic story about, well, a wunderkind.
-Tonio Kröger - for me the Platonic Mann story. A writer grows up lonely, becomes famous in the South, heads back to his hometown and doesn't like it much
-The Blood of the Walsungs - two self-hating half-Jewish twins hook up(!)
-Death in Venice - in contrast to Tonio Kröger, a man heads from the dull North to Venice, lusts after a Polish kid, and....well, I don't want to spoil it, but read the title carefully.

I think one generally becomes a better reader as one grows older, because the elements of time and place in each story start to blur, and one remembers the recurrent parts. Mann's characters, wimpy, pale and overmannered, might seem a little ridiculous, but the path they take in trying to achieve friendship, fame and meaning in life, recur in age after age.

Title: The Magic Mountain
Author: Thomas Mann
My Review:
"Sadly, The Magic Mountain, once a fixture of every middlebrow household’s bookshelf, has fallen off sharply in its sales and cultural currency, as has the rest of Mann’s oeuvre. He and it are too forbidding, demanding, and German for contemporary tastes."

Thus spake a recent essayist. The Magic Mountain presents a daunting challenge to the modern reader, not so much because of its length, as because of its mannered, meandering style, which, intentionally or not, drags the reader into the suffocatingly cloistered environment of the sanatorium. In an essay Thomas Mann wrote in The Atlantic Monthly, reprinted in the back of my edition, he admits that the book was meant to be a humorous short story which sprung from his visit to his wife's sanitorium.

So I feel somewhat justified in saying two things: it is too long, and its style will put off many modern readers. It took me an eighteen month hiatus before I could get past the book's "hump" - just before the somewhat climactic events of Walpurgis Night, where the plot starts to gather speed a little. But plot is not what drives The Magic Mountain: rather, it is ideas, as Hans Castorp, a nondescript, though intellectually curious, engineer, engages with the novel's ideologues (Settembrini, Naptha), personalities (Chavcha, Behrens), boredom, and the forces of nature. If journalism is writing about uncommon events and novels are about universal ones, this book is perhaps about the space in between events - a painfully long yet desultory, and seemingly endless stay in a small snowy mountain as the forces of Enlightenment and imperialism roil down in the flatland. Mann weaves a Wagnerian leitmotif of time into the novel. None at all will pass for hundreds of pages, and then years will fly by in a sentence.

What I'm trying to get at is that this book is, by accident and by intention, alienating to the modern reader, and one might be forgiven for passing it up. But if you're willing to brave it. it presents a unique and rare challenge. It is a world of solitude, slowness, and occasional world-historical debates laced with the Classical learning of yesteryear which (if you graduated high school after 1950) will have you Googling a lot. And when, finally, you come down from the mountain and see the world, fast-paced and hurtling toward disaster, you will not understand it any better. But you will at least, for a while, have transcended it.

Title: As I Walked Out One Midsummer Morning
Author: Laurie Lee
My Review:
My fandom of Patrick Leigh Fermor's sort-of unfinished Europe-by-foot trilogy knows no bounds, so I gave this one a shot. Lee is in some ways the dumb version of PLF - both in knowledge (Fermor knows his history backwards and picks up languages quickly, while Lee cheerfully brags of his ignorance about Spain, and knows only a single line of Spanish), and also in common sense - he haphazardly tramps forward, almost dying multiple times of exposure, heat, or a pack of wild dogs. But both share a sense of adventure: they are young men seeking a full-throated experience of a land both unknown but close enough culturally to provide some small continuity.

Lee's story is astonishing, getting increasingly hair-raising as the Spanish Civil War approaches, and at times I was a little skeptical. (I saw later that a 1998 Spectator article alleged that it was entirely made up.) And here is a fascinating look into the women in his life, and the soap opera drama between Lee, Lucian Freud, and the bohemian Garman sisters. This book's sense of place - dusty, hot wheat fields, indigent, boozy villages - and Romantic drama at the onset of war will linger with me for a while.

Title: Gravity's Engines: How Bubble-Blowing Black Holes Rule Galaxies, Stars, and Life in the Cosmos
Author: Caleb Scharf
Publisher: Scientific American / Farrar, Straus and Giroux
My Review: An excellent primer, enthusiastic but not overwhelming, and understandable but never simple. Starting with Einstein's explanations of how gravity is just the curvature of spacetime, affecting even light, to the discovery that objects could collapse to be massive and small enough to trap even light within their event horizons, and to recent developments in cosmology and telescopy that fit black holes into the history and geography of our universe. Not sure I understood it all, but I still gained a lot.

Title: Ferdydurke
Author: Witold Gombrowicz
My Review: This novel is supposed to be untranslatable, but Danuta Brochardt has given it a valiant try. It's full of annoying diminutives and onomatopoeias, and extremely tedious in parts. The semblance of a plot revolves around an adult narrator being pulled into a world of disobedient schoolboys, who spend most of the novel, fighting, pulling faces, being bored in lessons, and making jokes about "pupa" (a Polish word which means "butt", but presumably with extra connotations not available in English). The world it mocks has mostly disappeared, and occasional footnotes fill in some of the blanks. Basically, this is like reading a novel written by a ten-year-old with an erudite ghostwriter: the whole point is to deflate the pretensions of the literary and cultural elite, mostly with scatological humour. Not a bad idea by any means but, like the company of ten-year-olds, it grows stale quickly. If this represents the best of Polish literature, I'll have to assume the wit is lost in translation.

Title: The Signal and the Noise: Why So Many Predictions Fail - But Some Don't
Author: Nate Silver
My Review: Very much of the zeitgeist -  a lot of the ideas contained herein have trickled through into the web and IRL, but this book is still worth reading inside, because you don't know nearly as much about this stuff as you think. Silver is a good writer, covering the statistical ideas behind a huge variety of topics (sport, politics, climate, poker, investing, earthquakes) with wit and brio, and nary an equation in sight. He is also humble about the possibilities of forecasting, notwithstanding the rise of Big Data/ML, suggesting in fact that we may be so early on in our use of these technologies that useful breakthroughs could be decades away. By focusing on domains in which forecasting is usually wrong (economics, political punditry), right (poker, weather), or seemingly not possible (earthquakes, for one), he gives the reader an idea of the need for accurate forecasting, its limitations, and its best practices.

Title: Louis D. Brandeis: American Prophet
Author: Jeffrey Rosen
My Review:
An astute, brief bio which avoids recapitulating the material covered by the judge's other biographers, instead focusing on his legal principles with emphasis on how they would measure up today. Rosen is an excellent (and studiously nonpartisan) legal writer and commentator with an interest in constitutional history.

Brandeis switched opinions often: from anti- to pro-Zionism, anti- to pro-women's suffrage, anti- to pro-unions. He was opposed to "bigness" - big business, big government, and even big unions; a Jeffersonian agrarian libertarian who thought that small, engaged communities were the best political model.

This made him a more liberal figure, opposed as he was to the big trusts of the Gilded Age. Nominated by Wilson, his confirmation was very controversial for the time (ha!), the first to have a public hearing and still the longest - not because of antisemitism, though it existed (his SCOTUS colleague James Clark McReynolds would leave the room when he started talking), but mainly because he was against JP Morgan and his ilk. Brandeis wrote a book called [b:Other People's Money and How the Bankers Use It|1125344|Other People's Money and How the Bankers Use It (The Bedford Series in History and Culture)|Louis D. Brandeis|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1315625387s/1125344.jpg|1112455] critiquing the financial system, which became a lot more popular after 1929. One of the interesting modern-day issues not directly mentioned in the book is the idea of Amazon as a monopoly. Lina Khan has led her "hipster antitrust" crusade against the company, which relies on redefining the law to cover even a company which does not make prices more expensive for consumers, but has other insidious effects. It seems that Brandeis might have been sympathetic to this, just as he might have opposed other behemoth retail chains like Walmart - an opposition to their very bigness as something inconducive to civil engagement and community life.

Brandeis' (perhaps more famous) colleague OW Holmes Jr. was pragmatist almost to the point of nihilism - he propounded a legal realism that saw the law basically as what exists when judges decide. Brandeis himself was more of what we might call a Positivist. His famous 'Brandeis Brief' was 98% sociological/empirical facts, not abstract arguments about legal principles. Only by analysing the real life impact of the issues did he think that the legal solution could be found. (Brandeis was also an elitist who thought that consumers were dumb and the agrarian life the ideal, and that Periclean Athens was the height of civilisation.)

On modern-day issues, Rosen thinks that Clinton-era neoliberalism (such as the repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act, which Brandeis helped put in place) is 'unBrandeisian', as it allows the growth of huge financial monsters - and in fact during the financial crisis the 'too big to fail' banks got bailed out, not the smaller ones who had avoided dodgy proprietary trading. The Dodd-Frank Act, according to Rosen, was an attempt to bring some of this back, although a more Brandeisian solution would have been to tax financial services companies above a certain size, basically keeping them small. (Apparently this was floated in 2008 but died in Congress.)

Other major Brandeis ideas include the right to privacy (a term he invented!), but also the idea that "sunlight is the best disinfectant" in terms of the public's right to know. His far-seeing dissent in 'Olmstead vs US' said that the government wiretapping a citizen's phone was an illegal violation of privacy (he also thought that TV was two-way communication, an idea more premature than wrong!)

In an epilogue, Rosen tosses up a few other interesting issues: he thinks Brandeis would not have included the EU's "right to be forgotten" in the right to privacy (as it goes against freedom of speech), but maybe would have opposed vertical media mergers (such as that of AT&T and Time Warner earlier this year) and the cancellation of "net neutrality". He believed that it was worth sacrificing efficiency for the sake of democratic engagement. But on the other hand, perhaps he would have felt that the internet provides other outlets for engagement, an omnipresent village square reducing the need for the corner shop. A stretch? Either way, his greatest legacy was in always keeping an open mind and continual self education. Those interested in more self-education on this kind of stuff might want to look at this great, very wonky podcast or Rosen's own.

Title: Red Plenty: Inside the Fifties' Soviet Dream
Author: Francis Spufford
My Review: Sort of historical fiction, but with a huge amount of wonky economic info, taking seriously and examining the idea of a centrally planned economy. Takes place during the boom years of the USSR (from Krushchev to Brezhnev), when it looked like it was just a matter of time before Russia really would overtake the West in terms of living standards. GDP growth was terrifying CIA analysts (even after they'd revised down the numbers to somewhere closer to the truth), and people thought that just maybe, after all the austerity, now the good life would be here. Alas, it wasn't to be. It may not sound like it from this review, but this book - with a large, lively cast of characters from all parts of society - is great fun.

Title: Progress of Stories: A New Enlarged Edition
Author: Laura Riding Jackson
My Review:
Laura (Riding) Jackson was a difficult, uncompromising person, better known for her poetry but still relatively unsung. She was close with the Language poets and the so-called Objectivists (though they mocked the term) Zukowsky and George Oppen. This collection of stories spanning her career has surprisingly little attention, either here on the wider WWW : all I could find was an admiring 1982 review in the NYRB by none less than Harry Matthews (paywalled: her response was an angry 1,100-word letter excoriating him for referring to her by her first name [fair enough, I guess!]); David Auerbach's interviews with scholar Lisa Samuels at his website; and this perplexed review. The difficulty is undoubtedly part of it. To use a visual metaphor, some of the early stories seem post-Impressionist: recognisable tales from a queer, unfamiliar perspective. Most are fully abstract, almost impossible to parse, moving beyond the surreal to the realm of Pure Story.

(Riding) Jackson had no tolerance for fools (even calling out [b: The Madwomen in the Attic|149709|The Madwoman in the Attic The Woman Writer and the Nineteenth-Century Literary Imagination|Sandra M. Gilbert|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1348225811s/149709.jpg|2986123] in an afterword for using an epigraph from here, and misconstruing her work as feminist) and I'm far from being on the level to review her, but I think some clue are found in the story A Crown for Hans Andersen. There she divides the world into sentimentalists and raw intelligence, and the struggle between them, classifying writers (Rabelais, Chekhov, Mansfield) and historical figures (Napoleon). To her, the purity of European folklore - the Arthurian myths, or Hans Andersen's revival of them - is the essence of stories, and she seeks to break off the accrual of irrelevance by breaking her fiction down to its components, trying to distill the clarity of those myths into modern terms as Pure Story. It's a difficult work, and it's unfortunate that as yet so few critics have picked up the mantle of interpreting it.

Note: (Riding) Jackson wrote some of these stories when she was Laura Riding, and later ones (after a decades-long hiatus) under the name Laura Jackson after her marriage to Schuyler Jackson. The new editions of Progress of Stories contain stories under both names, hence the unusual nomenclature (and Matthews' ill-advised choice of 'Laura').

Title: Rational Meaning: A New Foundation for the Definition of Words and Supplementary Essays
Author: Laura Riding Jackson
Additional Authors: Schuyler B. Jackson, William Harmon, William Haromon, Charles Bernstein

Title: Rational Meaning: A New Foundation for the Definition of Words and Supplementary Essays
Author: Laura Riding Jackson
Additional Authors: Schuyler B. Jackson, William Harmon, William Haromon, Charles Bernstein

Title: Dealers of Lightning: Xerox PARC and the Dawn of the Computer Age
Author: Michael A. Hiltzik
My Review:
I'm sceptical of the genius narrative. In my mind, there are always a few people with irrational self-confidence - and of course a couple happen to succeed. Cue mythmaking, fawning biographies and countless would-be clones...

Relatedly, I can feel some sympathy for the executives at Xerox. The standard narrative is that their Palo Alto Research Centre (PARC) developed all of the big ideas of modern desktop computing (mouse, ethernet connection, desktop GUI, laser printing) under their noses, but the myopic suits failed to develop and fund it. This unremarkable, reportage-like book acknowledges that there is another side to that story - one in which hindsight is easy but managing a failing company is hard, in which brilliant but cantankerous geniuses aren't always best off given all the control and resources they want - without trying to say which story is true, or divine greater lessons.

Steve Jobs (whose own tech-world canonisation came after this book was written) said that Xerox could have been the IBM or Microsoft of the '90s. Instead, others came in (including, famously and literally, Jobs himself) and took the ideas forward. Hiltzik notes that there is nothing like Xerox PARC at the time of writing - even Microsoft's research is much more product-focused. Would Google/Alphabet change his mind?

Title: Touching a Nerve: Our Brains, Our Selves
Author: Patricia S. Churchland
My Review: Posits that thought is purely a physical phenomenon, and talks about some of the more interesting aspects of neuroscience. Churchland's folksy, cheerful style focuses on down to earth topics, dispensing with the dualists early on and then just accusing them of being anti-science. I found parts of this interesting, but I'm not sure if it was the most efficient way to learn about the topic.

Title: The Landscape of History: How Historians Map the Past
Author: John Lewis Gaddis

Title: The Landscape of History: How Historians Map the Past
Author: John Lewis Gaddis

Title: The Cold War: A New History
Author: John Lewis Gaddis
My Review: This book is not long, and is written by one of the eminent historians of his field. I actually, as someone without much prior interest in the field, didn't learn so much new information? But it's nice to have it all in one place. Gaddis is definitely on the more Orthodox side, having looped back after the Revisionists to present a fairly triumphalist Western view of the war. He sees its origins in Stalin's paranoia, and partly in the fear of appeasement that was a hangover from Neville Chamberlain, and its resolution as a result of the inevitable desire of people for free speech and free markets. In his view hawkish US presidents such as Nixon and Reagan were overwhelmingly successful in their approach to the Russians. I was born in 1989, and names such as Lech Wałęsa, Khrushchev and SALT-II don't resonate with me the ay they would to an older generation. But the Cold War era surely has lessons for our times, though historians will keep debating them for a long time to come. (You can start here.)

Title: Imagined Communities: Reflections on the Origin and Spread of Nationalism (Revised Edition)
Author: Benedict Anderson
My Review:
Happily, a friend passed on their unwanted print sub to the London Review of Books, and last night I finished reading the second part of Perry Anderson's (Benedict's brother) gazillion-word takedown of Proust, or at least attempt to argue the superiority of Anthony Powell. Anderson frère is wonderfully erudite and readable, but it struck me that the argument was totally futile: the two authors are utterly incommensurate, and any attempt to quantify the merit of one over the other is laughable (to say nothing of the bean-counting of sentence length, number of unique characters, proper nouns, etc. that Anderson at times stoops to marshaling).

Reading this book at times made me feel the same. Anderson is amazingly learned, particularly in South-East Asian history, and makes his conclusions feel inescapable, obvious even. Yet as I would turn them over in my mind, the certainty would evaporate, and I wondered if the facts could have been just as easily construed otherwise. (This reminded me a lot of my recent experience reading Foucault's [b: The History of Sexuality|1875|The History of Sexuality, Volume 1 An Introduction|Michel Foucault|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1486236798s/1875.jpg|5991].)

The Wikipedia page I skimmed informs me that there are several major schools of thought on the history of nationalism. There is the naive view, that nations are ancient, coherent groups, that waited until modernity to find expression after the fall of the repressive empires. (For more on this, see the fire-breathing Yoram Hazony's recent [b: The Virtue of Nationalism|37977136|The Virtue of Nationalism|Yoram Hazony|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1531164007s/37977136.jpg|59699961], doing the rounds now.) For Gellner, nationalism is concomitant with European industrialisation; for Kedourie, it was brought to the colonies by Westerners. Anderson's theory is that in fact nationalism began with creoles in the colonies, seeking to define a status for themselves distinct from the colonial class they were barred from, and at the cost of granting solidarity to the natives (who were about to revolt). This then spread to the colonisers, to the point where today there are no empires, and everyone gets an equal seat as a nation.

An important concept for Anderson is 'print capitalism'. This, together with historical linguistics - the first science explicitly founded on the idea of evolution - is part of the replacement of the ancient, 'holy' languages. A bourgeoisie almost by definition has to be connected by print, unlike an aristocracy. The printing press gave expression to suppressed identities, at the same time forcing a Darwinian selection - it wouldn't have had such liberatory potential if each dialect had its own script, and so there was a centralisation, converging on a few winning dialects around which national identity coalesced (e.g. Low/Flat German was oral only, not printed; thus less important). Governments always want to suppress printed dialects, but don't care about spoken ones; Russia and Turkey forced their population to Cyrilicise/Latinise respectively. If the old empires pushed a single language, it was out of convenience, not chauvinism.

As he explains in an afterword, Anderson delights in taking down Western orthodoxies, and in comparing countries to those much poorer than them or geographically remote. His book was seen as too liberal for Marxists and too Marxist for liberals, a satisfying medium of idiosyncrasy, and has experienced a long afterlife, perhaps especially relevant in our times.

Why is William the Conqueror, who spoke no English (a language which did not yet exist), seen as an English cornerstone, rather than as a ravager, a Napoleon or a Hitler? The obvious answer is that tragedy plus time equals nationalism. But this doesn't give us an idea of how to ameliorate the effects of what might be called in modern parlance toxic nationalism. "Who will willingly die for the EEC? Where is the Tomb of the Unknown Liberal?" Anderson jests. The idea of why a nation-community is seen as something one would give one's life for, rather than a convenience, is of pretty critical importance to the European Union.

Title: Seven Brief Lessons on Physics
Author: Carlo Rovelli
My Review: It was just OK. Light on details (it's a short book) and heavy on talk of the "beauty" of physical theories of the universe, comparable to great music or art, an intriguing aesthetic proposition which I would have liked more evidence for. Ultimately, myths and science are both artistic enterprises, except that the ones which help us progress in the world we call "true".

Title: The Lives of the Artists
Author: Giorgio Vasari
My Review: In the beginning there was the void, and then came Cimabue, who taught Giotto, and there, from the endless flatness of High Gothic altarpieces, came the Renaissance. So things appear from this book, which is colourful and opinionated and highly subjective, yet has been utterly formative in our views of Italian Renaissance painting and on the practice of art history. It's also very, very long; I read this as prep for a trip to Florence, and it wasn't a bad idea, but I'm not enough of a hardcore fan to care about all the lesser lights between Giotto and Titian. And my two-volume edition, I believe, was still abridged!

Title: Dataclysm: Who We Are (When We Think No One's Looking)
Author: Christian Rudder
My Review: Rudder says that he decided to omit "statistical esoterica" which this nerdy reader was hoping for. Without them, this is just a stretched out version of the blog posts you've probably already seen, or at least heard the gist of.

Title: Parade's End
Author: Ford Madox Ford
My Review:
I watched the Tom Stoppard-penned BBC-HBO adaptation concomitantly (if nothing else, watch it for the sumptuous Edwardian visuals), although I didn't finish it, and Stoppard didn't finish the book. It's a useful contrast: Rebecca Hall's haughty but fragile Sylvia is a much more complex, sympathetic character than Ford's monomaniac force of impish malevolence, and the show is only marginally easier to follow than the books. FMF's narration technique is echt-modernist (perhaps he would have used the term 'Impressionist'). Each scene jolts far into the narrative future, where a fragmented, constantly shifting stream-of-consciousness narration fills in what has happened in the interim. Presumably the dislocation and confused memories reflect the postwar world, furiously changing, disrespectful of the past, its innocence irrevocably gone.

Which makes me curious about the series' politics. Chrissie Tiejens is a hard-nosed Tory, rigorously bound to his land and his creed, whose politics "died out sometime in the 18th century", and seems saddened by how democracy and greed have ruined everything. But the thrust of the book is his attempts to get away from it all and carve out some happiness with Valentine Wallop. Like its author, this elegiac series is a curious hybrid of the vanguard and the rearguard, offering little resolution.

Title: The Good Soldier
Author: Ford Madox Ford
My Review: Keeps throwing surprises at you, just when you think you've got the narrative straight. As the title hints, the narrator is only secondary, a clueless, helpless device to analyse eponymous Ed Ashburnham. A 'good' soldier he isn't, but the edginess of the fin de siècle/Modernism here is obviously questioning the fast-disappearing Victorian sexual mores. Everything is cloaked, and that just leads to more heartbreak further down the line. It's a shame that we don't get to hear Edward's explanation of himself until his final confession, because that might have made this "tale of passion" less frigid and bewildering. Though that might just be the point.

Title: The Idea Factory: Bell Labs and the Great Age of American Innovation
Author: Jon Gertner
My Review:
For just over 50 years AT&T held a monopoly over phone service in the US. This wasn't (as you might expect) due to corrupt politicians and lobbyists, but a carefully monitored experiment. The government tentatively allowed the company to run as a monopoly in exchange for it constantly needing to prove its worth through research (and defense work, when needed) and to provide infrastructure and service across the country at fixed prices. (And even so, the Justice Department never really gave up on trying to shut it down.) Controlled prices in exchange for no competition: a surprisingly socialist idea for the Cold War era! Nowadays, with a nominally free telecoms market, there are a host of problems, particularly last-mile access in rural areas. So it isn't so clear that the breakup of Ma Bell into Baby Bells was the best decision.

Anyway, this book is not about this at all. It's about how, while that arrangement held, Bell Labs was the one-company Silicon Valley plus of its age, pulling in the best minds and letting them cross-pollinate and range freely. As a result, the world got the transistor (and thus modern computing), information theory, satellite communication (GPS, satellite TV dish), cellular networks for mobile phones, laser, fibre optics, UNIX, C...

Jon Gertner is a model science writer. He has the passion of an enthusiast but the moderation of a seasoned writer; never acting like the material is too arcane for our little minds, while still making it clear that these people were serious boffins. He adds some biographical flavor, but doesn't let it take over the story.

The big question this book poses is how the conditions for world-changing innovation can be created. Bell Labs was superseded by Silicon Valley, a hypercapitalist environment where small companies rise and fall constantly. In fact, some of the early Silicon Valley firms were started by Bell Labs alumni or their students, including IBM, Intel and Hewlett Packard, while others were means to commercialise Bell Labs ideas (Motorola made cellphones, Texas Instruments invented the integrated circuit). Government agencies such as DARPA and university research are other models that have often been crucial to technological progress.

Bell Labs is perhaps unmatched today, even by the likes of Google, but it made lots of mistakes too (such as a picturephone which consumers never liked). It's unclear if it was just right at its time or if its model was something we should recreate. Many of its luminaries thought that it benefited from a longer horizon - unlike at say, IBM, researchers had a longer horizon (around 30 years) for their innovations being profitable, the perks of a regulated monopoly. The critique is often made that Silicon Valley companies focus only on immediately profitable ideas (although Facebook and Google's enormous wealth has allowed them too to take some speculative bets). Whether another Bell Labs could still be doing groundbreaking science in 2018 is not just a thought experiment, but something policy-makers should think hard about.

Title: An Equal Music
Author: Vikram Seth
My Review:
Goodreads is full of complaints about characters being unlikable, which has always seemed shallow to me: I think good writers can and do write blackguards as compellingly as heroes. But it's still important to me that this be part of the conceit. I think I struggled with this novel because it expects the reader's sympathy for someone who is honestly pretty monstrously selfish and self-destructive, ignoring every boundary the (married, female) object of his love attempts to put down. I couldn't muster it, which made parts of reading this book mildly infuriating.

Maybe relatedly, said character is a musician, and his behaviour might be inseparable from his capital-r Romantic persona. He, along with everyone else in the book, inhabits a cozy (and very much pre-internet) world of highbrow art and music. They are cultured and genteel, frequently moved to tears by art; and never remotely tempted to veg out in front of a sitcom. There's something quite noble in it. (Imagine Whit Stillman films without the jokes.) I did often find this book moving, and its (reportedly very accurate) portrayal of the classical music world (as well as other phenomena - which ones would be spoilers) is fascinating. (One wonders if it's changed much in the age of streaming.) But it's also nice to move onto something else; a sitcom, perhaps?

PS Seth's new novel, a long delayed sequel to doorstop [b: A Suitable Boy|50365|A Suitable Boy (A Suitable Boy, #1)|Vikram Seth|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1329421639s/50365.jpg|1651078], is reportedly out this autumn.

Title: The Master Algorithm: How the Quest for the Ultimate Learning Machine Will Remake Our World
Author: Pedro Domingos
My Review:
This past weekend a stunningly ignorant piece ran in the Times Literary Supplement on 'algorithms', wherein a writer spoke of being shown a top-secret algorithm from an unnamed big consumer tech company, describing with awe and horror how the words in the code were different colours and that changing a constant affected the output. Clearly a well-informed book on Machine Learning aimed at the general public is in dire need; sadly this book, which is terrible, does not fill it.

It suffers from two shortcomings: the one is that, being written just three years ago, it still seems worryingly anachronistic, gushing with unclouded optimism about how algorithms will tell us who to date, how to vote, and what to read, and will never possibly get out of control. (Domingos does talk a little about data protection, floating the idea of consumer-led data unions.) But secondly, this book is just awfully written. Trying to aim both at a lay and an expert audience, Domingos hammers in explanations with up to a dozen increasingly vague and incoherent metaphors that obscure more than they uncover, before lurching into a higher-level exegesis. If you, like me, are interested in these latter, do yourself a favour and skip at a minimum the first two and last two chapters. This book elaborates very little to the general reader, and even those with some background will struggle with the poor writing and disorganised, questionable technical detail.

Title: The French Lieutenant's Woman
Author: John Fowles
My Review: Classic metafictional mindgame, impressively full-blooded (the author showing up in the story and flipping a coin to determine the sequence of the plot, cogitations on the difference between fiction and reality), albeit a tad more obvious than a Coover or a Barthelme. But Fowles is master of his Victorian-gent domain, and this book engagingly captures the spirit and wit of the period, and the anxieties of the clash between old and new. And the plot is actually pretty exciting, towards the end. Fowles was a kind of hippy-English professor combination, and shows both sides here. Wish I'd read this before A.S. Byatt excellent sort-of response, [b: Possession|41219|Possession|A.S. Byatt|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1391124124s/41219.jpg|2246190].

Title: Dark Pools: The Rise of Artificially Intelligent Trading Machines and the Looming Threat to Wall Street
Author: Scott Patterson
My Review:
One way of looking at the arguments about modern finance is as a proxy for underlying ambivalence about global and local, modernity and tradition, fast and slow. The industry draws geniuses from Belarus or Singapore or Brazil into a few global meccas, where they proceed to programmatically make eye-watering amounts of money on the never-sleeping global markets of the world. You might feel that this is good - the accelerated vision of hyper-modernity unfolding into an urban and sophisticated sphere of efficiency. You might also feel that this is a disaster.

This book, written by a seasoned Wall Street Journal reporter, tries to take a middle position, tracking one HFT boffin whose firm goes bust when he can't keep up with the shady dealmaking in the exchanges, and a reclusive genius who invented the first electronic network (ECN) which sought to cut out the middleman and let people trade directly. Eventually it became part of NASDAQ, and the practices it pioneered are now standard. But despite the corruption and large spreads having disappeared, markets are still skewed, because of the quants who leverage superfast computers and AI to always be first on line and make money off "market-making".

Not aimed at the most sophisticated reader ("terra nova, a Latin phrase meaning 'new land'"...), the book hedges (pun unintended) its view on its subject, switching from admiring bios of mathematical geniuses to panic about people's 401(k)s. The top-rated review on GR maybe gives a more accurate view on the topic:
The act of buying or selling a whole bunch of anything will change its price. Those big orderers get to prepare ahead of time before they do it, and make a profit on this insider information. To also get to have perfect execution defies the laws of the market...the true problem with the markets these days is, why have we set up a system where the best and brightest are rewarded most for what is essentially high speed poker? It's not a problem that some HFT firm is getting to make some money for providing liquidity to the market, it's a problem that they hired half of MIT & Stanford to do it. A book exploring if and how we change the incentives for those really bright guys would be a welcome addition to the discussion.

Title: Then We Came to the End
Author: Joshua Ferris
My Review: I expected to like this book, which got lot of praise/attention, more than its much weirder sibling [b: To Rise Again at a Decent Hour |18453074|To Rise Again at a Decent Hour|Joshua Ferris|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1391305201s/18453074.jpg|26098475], but didn't. It's a really generic story about some lovable slackers à la The Office, with a feel-good message and a story about the boss with a heart of gold who, get this, has cancer! I breezed through it in an afternoon, so I can't say it was terrible - just mediocre, especially measured against my expectations.

Title: Then We Came to the End
Author: Joshua Ferris
My Review: I expected to like this book, which got lot of praise/attention, more than its much weirder sibling [b: To Rise Again at a Decent Hour |18453074|To Rise Again at a Decent Hour|Joshua Ferris|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1391305201s/18453074.jpg|26098475], but didn't.
