Title: To Rise Again at a Decent Hour
Author: Joshua Ferris
My Review: A very funny, odd little work. Five stars for the smart and inventive dialogue (some amazing strings of one-sided conversation), two for the theological fanfic that forms the book's spine, four for the cold shower of existential loneliness of a wealthy Manhattan dentist, getting drunk alone in front of a baseball game, pondering his lost loves and messed up parents, his insomnia and neuroses, his irrepressible self-destructiveness.

Title: To Rise Again at a Decent Hour
Author: Joshua Ferris
My Review: A very funny, odd little work. Five stars for the smart and inventive dialogue (some amazing strings of one-sided conversation), two for the theological fanfic that forms the book's spine, four for the cold shower of existential loneliness of a wealthy Manhattan dentist, getting drunk alone in front of a baseball game, pondering his lost loves and messed up parents, his insomnia and neuroses, his irrepressible self-destructiveness.

Title: Theory and Reality: An Introduction to the Philosophy of Science
Author: Peter Godfrey-Smith
My Review:
There is a white-coated, Latinate veil of competence draped over the world of science in English - one of the reasons the Anglo-Saxon nomenclature of Uncleftish Beholding is so jarring, as is learning scientific terms in a language besides English. Hearing talk about "water-stuff" or "sour-stuff" rather than Hydrogen or Oxygen sounds rather amateurish; we have convinced ourselves that the recondite Classicism of "deoxyribonucleic acid" represents something essential and unmoving, nature as it is.

Of course, this is a fiction. Science grubs together assumptions and guesses, moving in fits and starts, not always in the right direction, and its practitioners are just as vain and susceptible to groupthink as the rest of the human race. Recent news of the "replicability crisis" has further weakened the consensus around the existing system of experiment, peer review and publication.

And yet. Most systematic critiques of science, the ones proposing a whole new system, are far more terrifying than the system they seek to replace. I'm a pretty open-minded person, but some of the ideas summarised in this book - whole-cloth rejections of science as an imperialist relic of the Enlightenment, thrown around by the kind of people mocked by l'Affaire Sokal, are pretty awful.

The philosophy of science goes back around 100 years. The main schools are the Logical Positivists, pretty much dead now (they believed that nothing that couldn't be demonstrated had any meaning), Popper's verificationism (probably the best known theory, popular with scientists), Kuhn's idea of paradigm shifts, and a spattering of feminist, sociological, economist, and social constructivists critiques that score some valid points but often seem untethered from reality.

Today, the dominant ideas are naturalism, the idea that natural forces are all there is, motivated by what Hilary Putnam called the "miracle" of science; empiricism, a sort of skeptical-Kantian claim that all we can know is the phenomenal world, and there's no point speculating on anything metaphysical; and scientific realism, similar to naturalism but claiming that moral or mathematical facts also exist as part of a scientific reality. Godfrey-Smith is a competent but not overly ambitious or exciting narrator (though his squirming in a section on Bayesian Inference is amusing), and this seems like a good summary of the general ideas. This didn't make me want to read more Phil of Sci: one gets the impression that beyond some basic paradoxes (the nature of reality, Goodman's new riddle of induction, metaphysical realism) a lot of the century seems to have been spent going in circles. Science: it's a bit silly, really, but as long as those rockets launch and bridges stand up, it's the best we've got.

Title: Possession
Author: A.S. Byatt
My Review: Not really sure how I felt about this - I sort of like the form (a sort of phenomenology of being a literature grad student, where the stakes of archival research, doctrinal debates and academic politics seem towering) more than the actual content (two parallel, connected love stories, a literary mystery). What's fantastic about this book is how Byatt recreates the feel of ancient myths slowly burnished into medieval romance, Victorian verse, and '90s grunginess, fluidly, making them all feel apiece. No doubt someone with more knowledge than me would have gotten even more out of all the poetic/historical allusions.

Title: The Iranian Talmud: Reading the Bavli in Its Sasanian Context
Author: Shai Secunda

Title: The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich: A History of Nazi Germany
Author: William L. Shirer
My Review:
The trouble with the lessons of history is that there are too many of them, and their signals are crossed. Take Neville Chamberlain: in seeking to prevent a war in Europe at all costs, he was totally representative of the British people, who had lived through the Great War and wanted to avoid a repeat of it no matter what. (Although he did perhaps go further, refusing to even condemn Hitler's outrages.) Chamberlain was fêted, until he wasn't; contradicted by events and embarrassed by public outrage, he eventually stepped down a broken man and was replaced by Churchill, the war-mongering outcast vindicated at last. But of course, sometimes the Churchills of the world are wrong...

Or take Hitler: in many ways, he was a very consistent person, basically outlining his life philosophy in Mein Kampf and following it all the way (referring here to what he did; if you look at what he was saying, his constant straight-up lies would have made even Machiavelli blush). So the Allies missed a lot of chances by not wanting to escalate things: letting Hitler move first and seize the advantage. But in other circumstances, the prudent, non-escalating move would have been right. So how can we tell?

I don't have an answer, this is just a (pretty trivial) thought I had while reading this book. Shirer was a journalist who lived through and reported on the events at hand, giving this account a freshness and immediacy not found in most academic histories. (Some academics have sniped at the book, as Shirer details in a slightly petty afterword [writers: never read your reviews!]. But it seems that their biggest criticism revolves around the theory that Germans were inherently more susceptible to Nazism, the so-called "Buber-to-Hitler" theory, which seems pretty subjective.) But this book has still become the most popular history of the Third Reich.

Covering so many events, Shirer hurtles through them, skimming over much of WWII and focusing mostly on events within the Reich, such as the bungled plots to kill Hitler. I'll just list some points I found new or interesting:

1. Hitler had diverse strengths, and just one famous shortcoming, namely that he was mad as a March hare. Had he tried only to get Germany to the best position possible, he could have been thought of as one of history's great statesmen - the way he split his allies, making a pact with Russia to avoid a repeat of the Entente Cordiale, pushing the international community's desire to avoid war as far as was possible to swallow up his neighbours bloodlessly. But he was also focused on a) relentlessly growing in the East, even at the cost of starting a huge war and b) committing genocide, enslavement, and all the other bizarre horrors.

2. In some ways the saddest of the Nazi atrocities are those perpetrated during the last years of the war (both on POWs and in the death camps), when it was clear Germany was going to lose. Hitler's fanatical intransigence, determination to fight to the end, and occasional strategic genius kept it going far longer than it might've, against the will of his generals. (His insistence that the troops hold their lines during the first winter in Russia, for example, was justified: had they retreated, most of the generals later conceded that the army would probably have been routed, not really having anywhere to fall back to. But his refusal to allow the 6th army to pull out of Stalingrad directly lead to the death of nearly 200,000 Germans.)

3. Beneš, the Czech leader, fainted as he was browbeaten into signing away his country, and had to be given injections several times by one of the many sinister Nazi doctors that populate this history.

4. Hitler really liked Mussolini for reasons no-one understood (he was a half-hearted ally, and the Italian army was almost comically bad), but they had a fraught relationship. Mussolini hated how Hitler would wake him in the middle of the night for phone calls, and he would only tell him that he was planning to invade a country after his troops had already begun the attack. Mussolini invaded Greece basically just so that he could inform Hitler after the fact, which drove Hitler nuts. In the end, though, the Italians got stuck and the Germans had to come and finish the job.

Title: Swann's Way (In Search of Lost Time, #1)
Author: Marcel Proust
Additional Authors: C.K. Scott Moncrieff, Terence Kilmartin, D.J. Enright
My Review: For a long time I used to consider writing a review in the style of Marcel Proust, the French modernist whose prose - so elaborate, ponderous and, as one who wished to send his reader to a dictionary might say, lapidary, and so inspirational to the more recent crop of so-called 'autofictional' writers such as Karl Ove Knausgård, Jenny Offill and Ben Lerner, whose style, intermediated to me through the venerable translation of CK Scott Moncrieff, receives an improbable -515.1 on the Flesch readability test; but such an opportunity - to talk about a book's reference to the modern imposition of time on our daily lives, on the felt immediacy of childhood emotions, the connection between visual art and music and our perception of events, and the pangs of unrequited love - had never availed itself to me during all my reading until, in the midst of a period of my life in which literary succor seemed not at all close at hand, I decided in a moment of sudden inspiration to undertake the reading of this famed classic, and thereby, pushing through the lassitude imposed by [END OF VOL. I -- TO BE CONTINUED]

Author: Marcel Proust
Additional Authors: C.K. Scott Moncrieff, Terence Kilmartin, D.J. Enright
My Review: I mean, it's possible that at some indefinite point in the future, somebody, somewhere, will create a better portrayal of the bittersweet nostalgia associated with childhood, first love, and a comically snobbish but tight-knit family circle - but it's not exactly likely.

Additional Authors: C.K. Scott Moncrieff, Terence Kilmartin, D.J. Enright

Title: Netherland
Author: Joseph O'Neill
My Review: Anglophile, erudite, melancholy. The style is Mandarin, almost Victorian. "A man cheerfully operating under the subjunctive mood" and the like. A look at New York's multicultural dynamism in the shadow of 9/11. Also about the peculiar dynamics of male friendship, the pleasures of cricket, and NYC's Anglo-Dutch roots. The story sags a bit, and doesn't quite come to life - comparisons to Gatsby are sadly exaggerated.

Title: A Contract With God and Other Tenement Stories
Author: Will Eisner

Title: House of Leaves
Author: Mark Z. Danielewski
My Review:
If you don't know anything about this book, the conceit is this: the inner story is a boilerplate noir horror, a story about a house with dark, seemingly endless hidden passages that defy physics. Around this story is a record written by a blind old man named Zampanò, around which is another story by a troubled man named Johnny Truant, involving some buried childhood trauma, classic Slacker-era '90s nihilism, drugs, and lots of meaningless sex with generically gorgeous women. Around this is an astonishingly convincing array of imagined academic literature - referenced in painstaking detail - referring to a world in which the central story is the subject of countless magazine stories, TV interviews, academic books and monographs, etc.

And that's not even what makes this book so unusual: that, revealed to the reader on a casual flip, is the way it is formatted. The words jump across the page, slanting, shrinking, building shapes, disappearing, switching languages or disappearing, changing colours. There are photos and exhibits.

Danielewski's depth of research and knowledge of world literature is impressive. Every page in this book is full of bizarre details; every page makes you ask questions. But...maybe not in an interesting way? Are there any real answers to them? Is there a complex hidden message to all of this, or is it just a postmodern commentary on textuality, a collage open to arbitrary interpretation?
Which is fine. Art doesn't have to have a single meaning. It's just very tempting to look for a reference in the multitude of signs this book confronts you with.

House of Leaves is a collections of all sorts of texts, from every genre, at once pastiche and palimpsest. In the age of reader-response theory/la mort de l'auteur, we no longer need one text: instead, we have one reader's notes on another's notes on another's ... near the end one of the narrators meets a musician who has read his book and added his own notes. At times, House of Leaves evokes a bygone tradition of index cards and hand-written notes, lovingly photographed at the back (another of the many 'get out!' moments) But this book is of the hypertext era, originally circulated online, accruing further layers of commentary-cum-narrative. Perhaps all that awaits it is a full encoding into hypertext, and with that the form of the novel can be abandoned altogether, left to the crumbling remains of its last adherents.

Title: Book of Numbers
Author: Joshua Cohen
My Review:
Cohen loves language but apparently hates people. His style is perseveration, obsessive playing with sounds and puns, decoupling words from their meanings, abbreviating, listing, switching languages (he loves his French and German). Cohen can't avoid a pun or use a reversable phrase without reversing it. As every reviewer seemingly must, I quote here a sentence drawn more or less at random so you'll believe me:

"We just hung around the condo and avoided the computers, mutant x86ish PCs D-Unit had clunked himself, monitors surrounded by boxes of Kleenex and spritzers of Windex, keyboards surrounded by pressurized air containers, for blowing out the dust from between the keys, and the other periphs he clunked himself too as like joysticks and steeringwheels and the double mice he called rats surmounted with babywipes and kleengel antiseptics."

Note the verbal tics: "D-unit" (one parent, partner of M-unit), "as like", the itemised descriptions.

Which is cool: but here's the thing. Cohen is not interested in plot - which is fine - but this novel has a plot. Plotless would be a vast improvement - but this is a boilerplate tech-corporate story, with a Google-standin and Wikileaks-standin so lazily disguised you wonder why he bothered. And some flimsy, insulting female archetypes - the harping ex-, the fantasy young Francophone married Omani mistress...

Lots of fascinating details about tech/early Google history, which Cohen has inhaled and expelled unchanged (and very lightly explained) onto the page. YMMV on this one; I quite enjoyed it.

It's just a pity Cohen is relentlessly cynical, too cool to care about anything; that's just so fatiguing. He knows everything and thinks it all boring. There is no point to this novel, no lesson. And if these hundreds of pages of linguistic solpsisim have nothing to say about actual humans, one wonders if a novel is really the right form for them.

PS This review sums up my feelings about the novel fairly well.

Title: Four New Messages
Author: Joshua Cohen
Bookshelves: art-aesthetics-culture, contemporary, experimental, sad-young-literary-men, pomo, short-story-collections
Bookshelves with positions: art-aesthetics-culture (#12), contemporary (#46), experimental (#25), sad-young-literary-men (#17), pomo (#46), short-story-collections (#2)
My Review:
Some time has passed since I read this, robbing me of my initial impressions but also causing me to realise what little impression it made on me. Stylistically and thematically, Cohen (a New Books editor at Harper's magazine) attempts to conjure the feel of the Way We Live Now. Each of these four novellas comes with a URL, and the title and content allude to contemporary WWW-related issues (the instantaneity of email, the ubiquity of porn, online shaming). In our high-speed culture, though, technology seems to be adapting, Proteus-like, more quickly than writers can get their heads around it, leaving their fiction and satire as embarrassingly passé as the '90s cyberpunk stuff one still finds at garage sales and used bookstores.

But obsolescence isn't the major problem here, at least for now. After the first (and most engaging) story - about a campus drug dealer exposed online for a sexual contretemps at a frat party - the prose veers into increasingly unclear and uneven territory. A writer cannot bring himself to write the word "McDonalds", a writing teacher tells his students to build a house, and the final story appears to be about a forest made of matryoshka-like porn stars(?) Frequently it is addressed to the author's parents. It rambles, caroming from topic to topic, unbound to structure or narrative arc. My problems with this book, gave me concern that I might just not be cut out for experimental fiction itself anymore. (Prove me wrong, Ali Smith!)

Cohen's most famous novel, [b:Witz|7725947|Witz|Joshua Cohen|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1348420587s/7725947.jpg|10489227], has been sitting on my shelf for a while. It's an epic 900-odd pages, allegedly Finnegans Wake-level difficult in parts. Cohen is said to have cut down the book from 3,000 pages written on a trip through Eastern Europe, part of which he spun off into the book [b:A Heaven of Others|2570619|A Heaven of Others|Joshua Cohen|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1342887958s/2570619.jpg|2581057]. He is clearly a formidable mind - crafting long, intricate sentences with neologisms which frequently flummoxed my e-readers' built-in dictionary. There are plenty of sparks of good ideas here, buried under all the obscurantism. But does anyone care?

Title: The Diaries of Kenneth Tynan
Author: Kenneth Tynan
My Review: Sex, sadism, and a who's who of entertainment personalities from both sides of the Atlantic, too many to count. Some witty one-liners, and some corny ones. A rougher, more personal version of Tynan than his famous essays and criticism reveal. Since most of these notebooks were written during his later years, ill health, financial and professional worries, paranoia and jealousy give it a bitter, almost too-personal feel. Yet its author's love of life and art shine fiercely through.

Title: Letters, Volume One: 1926 to 1951
Author: John Betjeman
My Review: Picked up this slim volume on a whim. Betjeman, the people's poet, is funny and likable, sometimes switching into a Cockney idiom, sometimes serious. Many of the letters are trivial but others touch on faith, literature and how to write.

Title: Angle of Repose
Author: Wallace Stegner
My Review:
A clash of the Ancients and the Moderns: the curmudgeonly writer surveys his Victorian grandmother in contrast to the post hippy apathetic wasteland of the LBJ years. Which is a good indicator of how stacked this particular fight is. Stegner is an immensely talented writer and his characters are moving and true-to-life. But it's not quite clear what the point of this book is. For the most part, his Victorians grandparents are pure nobility: her good-natured, kind, and long-suffering; him talented, hardworking, and honest to a fault, but also tender and loving. Over and over, after grandfather drops a decision on grandmother and she reacts in outrage, she ends up tearfully apologising. (He does have a drinking problem, though.) Apparently these letters were based on the real-life letters of Mary Hallock Foote, though to what extent the picture has been sanitised by her or Stegner we can only guess.

By contrast the younger generation are repped by the heartless son who wants to send his father off to Menlo Park (metonym for a retirement home, not the social media behemoth of today), and a dropout secretary with a deadbeat ex-boyfriend.

There are some tales of the West in the days of Wild Bill Hickok and Calamity Jane, though the emphasis is more on the story of a marriage and its aftermath, and its echos in the narrator's own failed marriage and isolation. Several times he calls upon engineering terms (the Doppler effect, or the titular angle of repose) to illustrate his view of personal and national history. The effect of these metaphors is limited, but overall this story, despite its somewhat shaggy-dog ending, is an effective study of the harsh struggles of the American west, and the frustrations of the older generation with the romanticism of the young.

Title: The Hotel Years: Wanderings in Europe Between the Wars
Author: Joseph Roth
My Review: Caught without a book on a weekend in Vienna, I went down from my AirBnB to the nearest bookstore (Shakespeare & Co, apparently expanding its tourist trap from Paris) and bought this pretty canonical Vienna read. I only knew of Roth as author of [b: The Radetzky March|54258|The Radetzky March|Joseph Roth|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1320967670s/54258.jpg|1624715], but in his time he was in the Tom Wolfe tier of cushy traveling journalist pay, before fleeing the Nazis as far as Paris and drinking himself to death in 1939. This book collects short feuilletons on life entre-deux-guerres in Europe (and a bit of Asia). Roth is always cynical and melancholy, more or less enforcing a Viennese sameness on the variegated places he visits. So this tells us more about the writer than the hotels. But it's pleasant enough to spend a rainy afternoon in his always smart, always slightly bereft company.

Title: Memories: From Moscow to the Black Sea
Author: Teffi
Additional Authors: Robert Chandler, Elizabeth Chandler, Anne Marie Jackson, Irina Steinberg

Title: THAT IS HOW IT IS: (STORIES)
Author: Harvey Fink
My Review: The brilliant and uber-snobbish Joshua Cohen, asked by the Grey Lady to recommend a favourite Jewish novelist, goes for the predictably obscure: not this one but Nadir's [b: From Man to Man|3294743|From Man to Man|Olive Schreiner|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1372701170s/3294743.jpg|3331343], published in 1919. But Audible had this one, so I took the plunge. A reverent introduction by a Columbia Yiddish Lit professor assures us that we are not in the territory of the truly obscure - Nadir even has an English Wikipedia page, though it isn't much - but whether Nadir's style holds up is another question. Unlike the Yehoashes, Peretzes, and Shalom Aleichems of his time, Nadir (the nom de plume of Yitzchak Rayz) was a satirist, gadfly and bon vivant. A good chunk of his professional life was spent defending the Communist Party, a position he eventually retreated from after the Molotov-von Ribbentrop pact. And the bulk of this book is cornball humour about first-gen Jewish immigrants dealing with American life, chasing money and women, and yearning for home. Only in occasional retrospective moods do we see something more valuable: actual reflection on this generational seachange, the break between religious fathers and materialist sons, the ruptures of migration, and the transience and fragility of the creative life. In a few lilting closing paragraphs, Nadir finally grapples with some of these questions. You needn't waste your time on the rest.

Title: The Driver's Seat
Author: Muriel Spark
My Review: A tale of boredom, a death wish, and macrobiotic eating. It's hard to describe this, which one would never have expected from the author of [b:The Prime of Miss jean Brodie|517188|The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie|Muriel Spark|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1379598918s/517188.jpg|6132856]. It's short - just read it.

Title: The Driver's Seat
Author: Muriel Spark
My Review: A tale of boredom, a death wish, and macrobiotic eating. It's hard to describe this, which one would never have expected from the author of [b:The Prime of Miss jean Brodie|517188|The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie|Muriel Spark|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1379598918s/517188.jpg|6132856]. It's short - just read it.

Title: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie
Author: Muriel Spark
My Review: A quick, engaging read, which keeps the reader disoriented with flash-forwards and the varying prespectives of the girl's under Miss Brodie's care. Miss Brodie is an inspiring teacher who is also narcissistic, mainpulative and has Fascist tendencies, so we quickly realise that Dead Poet's Society this is not. Great characters, whose growing awareness of themselves as individuals and as sexual beings elevates this novella. A collective coming-of-age tale, then, told with wit and sensitivity.

Title: Complete Fiction of W. M. Spackman
Author: W.M. Spackman
My Review:
"This country's best-kept literary secret", says no less a luminary than Stanley Elkin. Well. He is singular, erudite and original: but also single-minded in all his writing (this is a 600 pp book, but contains all of his fiction, mostly written in a burst in his final decade). Alternately jubilant and cynical tales of love, often between young women and older men. Not that the women are less fleshed out or passive. But it does get a bit dull.

The term "middle-class morality" implies an aristocracy unconcerned with moral signalling, with nothing to prove. Spackman's character's embody this. They sometimes work vaguely as writers (though one is a banker, to be fair), travel frequently, and enjoy lives of privileges and adulterous affairs. Drawing on themes from Ovid, Restoration comic dramatists like Wyatt, and a handful of French writers (these origins are traced by Steven Moore in an afterword, but frequently invoked in the books themselves), Spackman describes writes defenses of carefree cuckoldry and lovers sunning themselves before the grave beckons. Seeing these books as representative of such an old tradition may excuse how astonishingly retrograde their social politics seem to us.

Spackman would wish to be judged on style, and he certainly delivers. Almost every page will send you to a dictionary, and unless you are fluent in Classics and Romances (WMS was a Rhodes scholar and sometime Classics professor), you will need several types. The prose here is not comparable to anything written today. I'm just not sure I needed so much of it in one go.

A final note: I saw Spackman's Collected Essays on a recent pilgrimage to Three Lives and Company , apparently it too has been recently published by Dalkey Archive.

Title: Melisande! What Are Dreams?
Author: Hillel Halkin
My Review: I inhaled this short book over 24 hours. It hooked me with its opening, the perfectly pitched melacholy of coming-of-age in NYC. The story tracks a love triangle between three gifted students graduating high school in the early '60s, as the counterculture and the pain of adulthood tear them apart.The short, magical sentences are almost Biblical (in fact, a short interlude in the middle reimagines a scene from the New Testament). It's easy to see in this the prose style of the early Hebrew and Yiddish writers Halkin has written about brilliantly in other places. At times, the book can also descend into twee: think the magical shenanigans of lit power couple Nicole Krauss and beau. But this is erudite, high-minded and passionate, a love story for Classicists; a rare and aristocratic breed of novel.

Title: Leo and His Circle: The Life of Leo Castelli
Author: Annie Cohen-Solal
My Review:
The first third is a fascinating story of an Italian-Jewish family, wandering from Tuscany to Trieste over centuries, two world wars, and a dramatic escape from the Nazis. (Like [b: The Hare With the Amber Eyes|7821828|The Hare With Amber Eyes A Family's Century of Art and Loss|Edmund de Waal|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1316730175s/7821828.jpg|10861805], with which it has much in common, it is about wealthy, cultured Jews who have the connections to organise the very difficult escape: unlike almost all of their coreligionists.)

The rest is a story of the American art world, from the end of Abstract Expressionism (Rothko mostly predates this book's timeframe) through the rise of Pop, Minimalism and Conceptual Art. Castelli was a consummate schmoozer, an aesthete who ended every day with Proust, a social striver who cultivated friendships with art figures such as the MoMA's visionary founding curator Albert Barr (whose quick bio in this book made me curious to know more). A notable story is about the Venice Biennale won by Robert Rauschenberg, a 'Castelli artist' whose victory caused outrage among the Europeans. Towards the end of his life, Castelli told Larry Gagosian that he could buy his gallery, but his artists would be unlikely to stay: their connection was with him as an individual. And with his passing, his fame has mostly evaporated outside of the art cognoscenti, but anyone interested in the history of this period cannot avoid his presence.

Title: The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer
Author: Siddhartha Mukherjee
My Review:
Honestly, I've never been much interested in medicine, but I liked this author's follow-up [b:The Gene: An Intimate History|27276428|The Gene An Intimate History|Siddhartha Mukherjee|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1463591739s/27276428.jpg|46190748]. Grandiose titles aside, both books are able to capture what the author finds so fascinating about his profession: the thrill of the chase, the ability to save people's lives. Frankly it makes you think that whatever you're doing with your life can hardly be as significant. Reading this book is like hanging out with an enthusiastic, energetic, high achiever, telling you about the way that other people are trying to solve things you're usually too scared to even think about.

Not every page of this book is uniformly fascinating. There are very granular descriptions of experimental progress and a sea of medical jargon. But this is also helpful, because one feels that the author hasn't oversimplified his material for our sake. Mukherjee traces cancer's earliest history in Ancient Egypt and the Persian Queen Atossa (mentioned in passing by Herodotus), Galen's theory of it being caused by an excess of black bile, and medieval approaches to surgery (the consensus: better not to touch it, probably a blessing for the sufferers given the operating room conditions of the time).

Cancer's history, though, is mainly a modern phenomenon, partly because we live longer lifespans and die less from other diseases, and partly because we have better testing facilities. Early treatment began with surgeries, and one surgeon began to perform ever more radical cuts, maiming patients in order to try save them. Unfortunately, it doesn't work that way: metastatisised cancers can't be stopped even by that, and treatable ones don't need such radical surgery. Later on radiation was found to sometimes reverse tumours, and then with the rise of toxic chemicals (chemotherapy) such as Sidney Farber's anti-folates, the last weapon in the modern arsenal had arrived. Mukherjee talks about the politics of cancer: spurred by a movement led by the socialite and activist Mary Lasker, Farber started the Dana-Farber Cancer Centre and the Jimmy Fund, a perfect piece of "disease marketing" which thrives to this day. Nixon declared a War on Cancer, surgeons skimmed the boundaries of ethics to try radical experiments on dying patients (and sometimes, as in the case of the South African Werner Bezwoda, just made up data), and the fight inched forward. Patient activism such as the AIDS group ACT UP also played a role. (AIDS originally appeared in the guise of a skin cancer, Kaposi's sarcoma, found in gay men.)

The end of the book discusses the search for the genetic and cellular origins of cancer, and the hope that such research might lead to failproof treatments, or at least push the disease back to old age. Mukherjee has some literary flourishes which don't always pan out (frequent references to Susan Sontag's [b:Illness as Metaphor|119688|Illness as Metaphor|Susan Sontag|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1330589896s/119688.jpg|1253513] and Solzhenitsyn's [b: Cancer Ward|254316|Cancer Ward|Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1328028751s/254316.jpg|3202343] get a bit tedious), but his dedication and care for his patients are clear. Ultimately, I did find this foreboding and sometimes depressing book quite inspiring. It made me feel that people are still out there doing great, noble things, and that perhaps I, stirred by an ancient impulse, could find some small way to participate in their struggle.

Title: The Gene: An Intimate History
Author: Siddhartha Mukherjee
My Review: An excellent, captivating work of science for non-science people. The first half in particular delineates the history of thought about genetics from Pythagoras to Paracelsus to Mendel to DNA, clarifying an organising a lot of things you half-knew. The second ~half is a little bit scattered, jumping around in time and topic, a grab-bag of interesting genetics stories: genetic medicine, gene modification, the Asilomar conference (which the author attended as a grad student), and the spectre of CRISPR. Still enjoyable, though, and tied together by Mukherjee's reflections on his own family's dark genes. Recommended.

Title: The Passage of Power (The Years of Lyndon Johnson, #4)
Author: Robert A. Caro
My Review: Probably the book in the series with the widest appeal, and it summarises the salient facts from the others where necessary. LBJ is at his most sympathetic in parts of this book, but also occasionally at his worst: the corruption, the humiliation of subordinates, the ruthlessness. Covers Johnson's decision to become VP, which seemed to be a huge misstep (VPs have basically no power), but ended up working out pretty well for him...as well as Kennedy's rise, the RFK-LBJ mutual hatred, Dallas, the Warren Commission, and LBJ's return to astonishing form pushing bills through Congress, including a Civil Rights bill. (One wonders how Dick Russell and Johnson's other Southern friends must have reacted to this betrayal, but Caro surprisingly doesn't go into it.) "The power had begun to flow back to the Executive Branch..."

Title: Master of the Senate
Author: Robert A. Caro
My Review:
In this volume once again, the focus is much wider than just LBJ's life; and in fact, some of the more obsessive discussions might have been removed for a slightly briefer read. But the meticulous Caro is spectacular when zooming out to cover the American century, and the machinations of democracy. The Senate, with its ability to stymie progress, has seemed at many times to be the enemy of the popular will, and in some ways it is. Its goal is to slow things down, to obstruct and debate to prevent rash action. When the Senate blocked America's role in the League of Nations, or Civil Rights legislation through the dreaded filibuster, it represented the views of an older generation against a popular movement. But sometimes, as in the early years of the New Deal, the Senate just "waved at the bills as they rushed by" in the words of Will Rogers. The Senate is more complicated than a simple democracy - it is a place of unusual bipartisan moves and stubborn independents bucking party lines and endless debates, and thus a source of endlessly fascinating political tension.

When Johnson entered the Senate it was at a low ebb, increasingly blocked by party divisions and unable to get things done. Johnson has been seen in previous books as conscience-less, vain, ambitious and ruthless. Relatedly, he was probably the most gifted politician of modern (all?) times. A section in which he uses proto-McCarthyist tactics (quoting old writings out of context to falsely smear Leland Olds as a Communist and destroy his life) is almost too painful to read. Caro shows Johnson to be naturally friendly towards non-white people - he taught at a Mexican school early in his life - although not without some casual racism shown towards black people around him. But his ambition always came first, and in any case where idealism clashed with expedience, expedience won. Thus, his need for support from the Southern bloc meant that he would block all civil rights legislation, until, after Emmett Till and Rosa Parks and MLK, as the mood in the country changed, he realised that in order to become president he would need to broaden his appeal.

Johnson got to be majority leader in no time, and used the position, which had previously been considered a curse, to basically run the Senate. He felt most comfortable there, even more than in the Oval Office, and was uniquely placed to pass a Civil Rights bill (watered-down, barely worth anything, but still a bill) through it in 1957. That tale is the story of this book.

He felt most comfortable there, even more than in the Oval Office, and was uniquely placed to pass a Civil Rights bill (watered-down, barely worth anything, but still a bill) through it in 1957. That tale is the story of this book.

Title: Means of Ascent (The Years of Lyndon Johnson, #2)
Author: Robert A. Caro
My Review:
If Johnson's career - in which he achieved many great liberal dream, through a life of consistent political foul play - is about the question of whether ends justify means, this second volume of Caro's magisterial bio is only about the means: there are no virtuous ends at play. So claims Caro in the introduction to the shortest volume of his unfinished series. The story here - per the author a lengthy chapter that swelled into a book - is Johnson's 1948 senatorial race against Coke Stevenson. Caro portrays the latter as a model of old-fashioned Texan probity and decency, and Johnson as a ruthless liar who poured in enormous amounts of money from both unions and business interests, assailed his opponent with entirely fabricated allegations, and eventually, when that failed, outright stole the election by just 87 votes. The book, entirely about an interesting, but pretty obscure, state election, is somehow a gripping page-turner, a tragedy in which the modern politics of Big Money, new technology, and shameless lying prevail over a good-hearted, incorruptible John Wayne type. Caro's research is meticulous and intense, and no-one questions it. But in the wake of this book's release, some questioned whether he may have omitted things. To wit: Stephenson appears to have been pretty racist, and a Christian fundamentalist opposed to academic freedom. Caro in turn accepts these points: they are not totally surprising in a Southern conservative from the 1940s. But he claims that they were not election issues, and that it is a mistake to judge a 1940s candidate by today's ideas. At the time, the differences between them weren't about civil rights or academic freedom - this was purely about Johnson's unquenchable thirst for power.

I call the fight for Caro. But I think that this review, by Gary Wills scores a strong point. Johnson is ever the villain for Caro, and you can't write convincingly about someone if you hate him so much. All of the facts in this book are true, but they have been utilised to make Johnson - who was by all accounts not a nice person, but was a complex person - look completely evil. And even after so much research, after driving to interview so many obscure side-characters, and reading tens of thousands of documents - one can still draw a biased portrait. Having no prior knowledge of the subject, I certainly can't arbitrate, but I think Wills' point worth bearing in mind.

Title: The Path to Power
Author: Robert A. Caro
My Review:
People who, like me, are not innately interested in politics might never have stopped to think what kind of person gets into that field. The answer, upon consideration, is that there are two types: people that are deeply idealistic, and people that, for whatever reasons, are interested in naked power. It is more or less the thesis of this book that Lyndon Baines Johnson, 36th President of the United States, was a member of the second category.

Reading the beginning part of this gripping book (seriously - I couldn't put it down), one begins to think that the author hates his subject. It is a litany of near-sociopathic behaviour: Johnson was cold, calculating and cruel beyond belief (especially to his father, who was a true idealist). But as the book continues we cone to understand the appeal of the subject to Caro, who moved to Texas and spent seven years of his life on this volume alone. Caro uses LBJ (and Robert Moses in [b: The Power Broker|1111|The Power Broker Robert Moses and the Fall of New York|Robert A. Caro|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1403194611s/1111.jpg|428384]) the way a chemist uses a florescent chemical to trace a reaction under a microscope. Watching them - painstakingly, step by step - we discover the ways in which power operates in a complex, technocratic, bureaucratic democracy. The way things happen in secret, the so-called "deep state". It is only by wading through enormous amounts of documentation and interviewing hundreds of people that Caro finally traces the pivotal events: millions of dollars unlocked for a dam, or a crucial committee appointment, in a meeting in a secret room; only decades after the subjects have died but one witness lives to tell the tale, how an influential individual changed his mind after a conversation with the subject...

Caro, famously verbose, is astonishingly thorough, although the darkness of this revisionism led to many claims that it was biased or untruthful. Caro's claim is that Johnson was incredibly secretive, even in perfectly harmless matters; that he stole elections, committed fraud and blackmail, and meticulously covered these things up; and that his entire life was a struggle to dominate others and reach the highest rungs of power, within which his values were dictated only by expedience. It is a stark and frightening idea. In fact, it could even make you wonder if such a person wouldn't be capable of pulling off a mysterious assassination of a young and popular president, if that was the only way of achieving his life's dream of becoming president...

Title: The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York
Author: Robert A. Caro
My Review:
An astonishingly in-depth, erudite and comprehensive (fun fact: the author's senior thesis at Princeton was so long that the university decided to institute a length limit in future) portrait of a man who shaped New York City. Brilliant and haughty, Moses used his supple mind to gain power and implement his plans beyond the reach of public or political influence. Caro shows his subject's great strengths - a love of public service, political astuteness, and an incredible work ethic - as well as his faults. He was a product of his time: his views toward non-white people were an embarrassment, and he favoured cars over public transport, with terrible consequences. But none of these would have been fatal, were it not for the book's real theme: power.

The arch of the story shows a young, idealistic student of literature, starting off in city government trying to reform the corrupt politics of Tammany Hall. Failing owing to his lack of power, Moses begins to understand that he must accumulate it if he is to improve his society. But power corrupts, and, over the course of the book's five sections (boroughs?), a Faustian change overcomes him, granting him extraordinary power, and making him a vicious, amoral autocrat not above smearing opponents with lies, misleading elected officials, and ruining the lives of thousands of impoverished city residents. At the end of his life, Moses's reputation is in ruins, his power evaporated, his name associated with bad planning when it is remembered at all: hardly to be expected of one who had done more than any single individual to build the booming city of today.

Caro wrote his book in the 1970s, when the "fall of New York" looked irreversible. Today, post-Giulliani and with the influx of finance money the city booms, and some in turn seek to revive Moses' reputation. But the greater moral lesson of this masterly history book is as relevant as ever.

But power corrupts, and, over the course of the book's five sections (boroughs?), a Faustian change overcomes him, granting him extraordinary power, and making him a vicious, amoral autocrat not above smearing opponents with lies, misleading elected officials, and ruining the lives of thousands of impoverished city residents. At the end of his life, Moses's reputation is in ruins, his power evaporated, his name associated with bad planning when it is remembered at all: hardly to be expected of one who had done more than any single individual to build the booming city of today.

Caro wrote his book in the 1970s, when the "fall of New York" looked irreversible. Today, post-Giulliani and with the influx of finance money the city booms, and some in turn seek to revive Moses' reputation. But the greater moral lesson of this masterly history book is as relevant as ever.

Title: Bleeding Edge
Author: Thomas Pynchon
My Review: I read this during my first visit to Manhattan, and it felt right: few books are more soaked in a certain place (NYC, mainly its most self-adoring borough) and time (before and after 9/11, which acts as something of a pivot for the book). I've read some of Mr Pynchon's bulkier, more overwhelming fiction ([b: Against the Day|409|Against the Day|Thomas Pynchon|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1276429450s/409.jpg|3016553], [b: Gravity's Rainbow|415|Gravity's Rainbow|Thomas Pynchon|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1414969925s/415.jpg|866393]), and I believe the difference between them and this (and its peers like [b: Inherent Vice|5933841|Inherent Vice|Thomas Pynchon|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1347697574s/5933841.jpg|6151926]) is more about volume than anything else. This is a historical fiction set not long ago, a time when the Internet promised magic liberation and dystopian panoptic surveillance, when it would be the voice of courageous protesters and of the medium of control for a nerdy, brilliant young techbro. Sound familiar? Despite being five years out of date, and set almost two decades ago, Pynchon's internet paranoia is more relevant than ever. Of course, there are the necessary elements of the Pynchonesque: bizarre names, ridiculously complex conspiracies and coincidences, an air of magic, science, fate and dread. I think that I resisted admiring  Pynchon for years out of a belief that great writers should be serious and write about Life and Free Will and not just mess around, but in fact, maybe this bizarro world is the most faithful rendition possible of our own...

Title: Gravity's Rainbow
Author: Thomas Pynchon
My Review: Full of brilliance, no book can make you feel stupid as easily - unless it's another Pynchon. But genius alone doesn't make a great writer; in fact, Pynchon's absurdly weak characters are a hallmark. (Of which there are over four hundred in this book alone.) Its fiery, always original prose is matchless, and its representation of the confusing paraphernalia of modern life can make your head spin. But this is a great book, pregnant with symbolic genius, a multitudinous panoply of wit and erudition.

Title: Desperate Characters
Author: Paula Fox
My Review: The best fiction succeeds in conveying the complexity and opaqueness of human relationships. This book contains difficulty in spades, trawling through a zombified marriage, a city in disrepair, all narrated by a troubled and distracted mind. The sympathetic background of crime, vandalism and poverty syncs perfectly with Fox's funereal tone. The story begins with a minor disaster - a stray cat bites the hero on her hand, an old law partnership breaks up - and from there everything gets worse, despite the brittle intellectual veneer of the couple's social life. As I read this I pondered the difficulty of true communication and the isolation of the adult mind from its peers and support network - an unspoken truth as audacious and horror-inducing as this brilliant novel.

Title: The Hare With Amber Eyes: A Family's Century of Art and Loss
Author: Edmund de Waal
My Review:
The Ephrussi banking family was a fabulously wealthy dynasty, now almost-vanished, that emerged as Odessa wheat traders and came to have offices all over Europe. Over time, in the way of the nouveau riche, some of them turned to collecting and patronising art. Edmund de Waal, a scion of the family through his father's mother, tells the story of this family history through a collection of netsuke (Japanese miniature carvings) and a century of stormy personal and political history.

de Waal himself is a pretty successful artist (though he does have an English degree), and writes like one. His eye lingers on facades of buildings, carved staircases, the way a room is decorated. And so this book has two very different parts. The first, which can be slow going, tells the story of Charles Ephrussi, one of the brothers who was freed of the family business and allowed to indulge his cultural passions. He became a noted art historian, writing monographs on Dürer and supporting many of the Impressionists, and was the model for Swann in In Search of Lost Time. He first bought the netsuke at the beginning of the 19th century mania for Japonisme.

But then World War I breaks out, and the narrator, with his elegiac, Sebaldian tone, turns to history, and the predictably unpleasant fate of Jews (and particularly wealthy and prominent ones) under the Nazi jackboot. Thanks partly to their wealth, education and connections, the fate of the characters in the book was much better than that of most of their compatriots: this is a story of exile and loss of a fortune, but not of the death camps. Eventually the netsuke end up with a great-uncle in Japan, completing their circle.

This book is slow and lovingly told, often looking with empathic imagination through the eyes of children or their parents. It's a story of wealth, sophistication and visual culture, of a family buffeted by uncontrollable forces, and of the pull of beautiful objects.

Title: Dune (Dune Chronicles, #1)
Author: Frank Herbert
My Review: "Several of the characters in Dune are psychic, which puts them in the unique position of being able to understand what goes on," wrote Janis Maslin of David Lynch's infamous 1984 film adaptation of this revered classic, and that applies tenfold to the book. We are thrown deep in medias res into an utterly unfamiliar world in which nestled, intricate conspiracies have been set in motion, and mysterious history and mythology abounds. I, hypocrite lecteur, availed myself of these sparknotes and once you get into it, damn. It's a gripping yarn. More fantasy than sci-fi - the Butlerian jihad (one of countless terms you will fruitlessly await an explanation for) wiped out all computers and AI, leaving a hi-tech civilisation that relies on magic, legends, and a hodgepodge of tropes from Eastern and Western history (with strong influence from the Abrahamic religions and a sprinkling of '60s Zen/LSD/mysticism). As I got closer to the end I couldn't put the book down, and its ecological themes and AI warnings make it timely; but still, I think I'll pass on the 7(!) sequels and related extended universe. An important, unforgettable exercise in world-building, once you get over the formidable entry barrier.

Title: The Accidental Universe: The World You Thought You Knew
Author: Alan Lightman
My Review: How could a discussion of such deep issues - the mysteries of physics, God, meaning - result in such a dull book?

Title: In the Country of the Young: Stories
Author: Daniel Stern

Title: The Genius of Birds
Author: Jennifer Ackerman
My Review:
Well actually, birds are...not geniuses? Or maybe the term isn't well-formed. Bird are much smarter than we think: think of the elaborate lairs of bower-birds (one ornithologist quoted here thought birds should be divided into 'bower-birds' and 'all the rest'), the honing instincts of pigeons (which the latest research implies may be based on subtle detection of he earth's magnetic currents), the brilliant mimicry of songbirds and parrots. Birds have shown impressive skill on abstract intelligence tests, even the seemingly dumb ones, and there seems to be little correlation with brain size. But birds are still not capable of thinking in the way humans are: this thoughtful piece, in the digital argot of our time, compares brains to CPUs, which are only capable of manifesting intelligence through their peripherals. A fantastic brain wired to totally different qualia will run in a way so utterly removed from our own that comparisons just don't make sense.



So anyway, if you're just equipped with a sense of wonder, and willing to take the time to observe the birds with Ackerman, you'll find plenty of material in this book. If not, you may find its string of studies somewhat monotonous.

Title: A Private View
Author: Anita Brookner
My Review: A damp, gray afternoon of a book, drenched in ennui. The aptly named George Bland is recently retired and bereft of his best friend, leaving him without plans or direction. Most of this story is of his internal monologue as he encounters a shallow, grasping young woman living without permission in his neighbours' flat. His somewhat masochistic attempts to build a relationship with her, and alienation of potential friends and well-wishers, speak somewhat of the sorrow and loneliness of age, but I found this too bleak and unlikable to connect with.

Title: Rousseau and Revolution (The Story of Civilization, #10)
Author: Will Durant
My Review:
"Always scribble, scribble, scribble, eh Mr Durant?" Another one of these fat books - the last one, ostensibly, before the couple came out of retirement for one final, eleventh gig (wasn't that a movie plot?) Overall I love the Durants: their calm view of history, seeing the extremes of each age in context as just swings of the pendulum really helps me find sang-froid in the current political climate (and in life). Their respect for and interest in almost everything makes them wonderful guides. But there are drawbacks. For one, they tend toward very exact pronouncements on people and artistic works. This one is good, this one is the weakest, this one fails because of x. Astonishing as their scholarship is, I would prefer if they just described rather than rated most of the time. I'm no full-throated relativist but the idea that there is some objective Eye of History giving a verdict on wildly different works of art throughout the world over centuries is patently absurd. And in fact, their idea of synoptic history is predicated on the idea that a civilisation can be summarised by a gentleman (and lady) scholar with sufficient time on his hands, because there is a Artistic Canon comprised of what was good in that time. But a civilisation will always elude synoptic summation, because the social history, the legal history, the folklore history, the ethnological and culinary and climatic history et cetera will always represent too much to summarise in a finite book, an ever-unfurling coastline of knowledge mostly lost to the mists of time, or the veil of Clio. This is not to say that, say, studying the queer history of 18th c. France is a better use of time than studying Voltaire or Watteau, just that both are aspects of an infinitesimally large tapestry.

Also, this book contains an enormous amount, the great age of English rhetoric (Dr johnson, Walpole, Gibbon, Pitt, Burke, Charles Fox), the birth of liberalism (waddup Locke) and Romanticism and basically the seeds of all contemporary Western political discourse so, if you're going to just read one of these, maybe read this one. But honestly, read 'em all - you'll get your edgy modern history takes by reading the right sort of intellectual magazines, but you won't get the crusty old basis contained herein: on which the entire edifice resides.

This one is good, this one is the weakest, this one fails because of x. Astonishing as their scholarship is, I would prefer if they just described rather than rated most of the time. I'm no full-throated relativist but the idea that there is some objective Eye of History giving a verdict on wildly different works of art throughout the world over centuries is patently absurd. And in fact, their idea of synoptic history is predicated on the idea that a civilisation can be summarised by a gentleman (and lady) scholar with sufficient time on his hands, because there is a Artistic Canon comprised of what was good in that time. But a civilisation will always elude synoptic summation, because the social history, the legal history, the folklore history, the ethnological and culinary and climatic history et cetera will always represent too much to summarise in a finite book, an ever-unfurling coastline of knowledge mostly lost to the mists of time, or the veil of Clio. This is not to say that, say, studying the queer history of 18th c. France is a better use of time than studying Voltaire or Watteau, just that both are aspects of an infinitesimally large tapestry.

Also, this book contains an enormous amount, the great age of English rhetoric (Dr johnson, Walpole, Gibbon, Pitt, Burke, Charles Fox), the birth of liberalism (waddup Locke) and Romanticism and basically the seeds of all contemporary Western political discourse so, if you're going to just read one of these, maybe read this one. But honestly, read 'em all - you'll get your edgy modern history takes by reading the right sort of intellectual magazines, but you won't get the crusty old basis contained herein: on which the entire edifice resides.

Title: The Age of Faith (The Story of Civilization, #4)
Author: Will Durant
My Review: One gets the sense that Will and (Ariel Durant) have to work slightly harder to find interest in this volume - it's not the glory of ancient empires, nor the flowering of the Renaissance and Enlightenment in volumes to come. But their work pays off, and this book, running from the last pagan Roman Emperor until Dante, is a hefty cornucopia of philosophy, art, music, wars, and all the other follies of civilisation. It covers Rome's decline and fall and replacement by barbaric European tribes, the cleft of the Empire, the birth of Christianity and its ascent to become the official faith; the origins of Islam and the greatness of the Arab Golden Age, receiving classical learning and preserving and increasing it; Jewish civilisation; the social and economic conditions of the Middle Ages - feudalism, courtly love, troubadours, witch-burning, feasts and fasts; heretics, the Inquisition and the Crusades; the age of Scholastic phiosophy and Duns Scotus' eventual admission of defeat in reconciling faith with reason, and that perhaps, opening the door to the Renaissance. That last run-on sentence is very Durantian, although I haven't the same style. But what I'm trying to say is, there's far too much here to sum up in this brief review, but every page bursts with humility and humanism. Dense but compulsive reading.

Title: Caesar and Christ (Story of Civilization, #3)
Author: Will Durant
My Review: Another big doorstopper from the Durants. Despite the title, it's mainly about the story of Rome, with the rise of Christianity something of a grace note which enters as the empire crumbles, rotted from within and looted from without. Durant notes that the central question historians always ask about Rome is why it fell, but in fact a better question might be how it lasted so long in the first place. He has the long view of history, seeing Spenglerian cycles of rise and fall, from Stoic beginnings to Epicurean decadence. Comforting to read in an era that has a real "twilight of the West" feel: a US president best not spoken about, low birth rates, economic stagnation, cynicism, waves of immigration..Durant is at his best talking about art, poetry, philosophy, and letting the incredible stories of this time tell themselves, only occasionally interrupting with some modern skepticism. As always in Story of Civilisation, this makes for a smashing tale.

He has the long view of history, seeing Spenglerian cycles of rise and fall, from Stoic beginnings to Epicurean decadence. Comforting to read in an era that has a real "twilight of the West" feel: a US president best not spoken about, low birth rates, economic stagnation, cynicism, waves of immigration..Durant is at his best talking about art, poetry, philosophy, and letting the incredible stories of this time tell themselves, only occasionally interrupting with some modern skepticism. As always in Story of Civilisation, this makes for a smashing tale.

Title: Caesar and Christ (Story of Civilization, #3)

Despite the title, it's mainly about the story of Rome, with the rise of Christianity something of a grace note which enters as the empire crumbles, rotted from within and looted from without. Title: The Life of Greece (The Story of Civilization, #2)
Author: Will Durant
My Review: Durant is a great historian for people who aren't usually 'into' history (like myself!) He pulls together an astonishing amount of knowledge into a compelling narrative, stopping to inspect art, architecture, poetry and drama. Though there are doubtless many points for specialist historians to disagree, there are few if any replacements for this masterful work.

Title: Our Oriental Heritage (The Story of Civilization, #1)
Author: Will Durant
My Review: Staggering in its length and breadth, the first volume of an encyclopedic and comprehensive history of civilisation. This, the first volume, gives ample credit to the Near Eastern origins of Western Civ, as well as the other universes of Persia, India, China, Japan, etc. Yet it also shows its age: after all, all non-Western societies are covered in this volume, while the remaining ten(!) focus on the West. And Durant (or rather the Durants, since Ariel seems to have been an equal participant even on the volumes for which she isn't credited) is firm in his judgment of different ethnicities as attractive or not, and a society's general traits as "lazy" or "superstitious" or "original". Sweeping judgments are also passed on entire canons of art or literature. I'm not calling for total relativism, but a bit more humility would be expected from a contemporary scholar. But still: a compendious and eye-opening book for the novitiate, opening up worlds of religion, poetry and anthropology, tinged with a Spenglerian view of the world as a static backdrop on which empires rise, decline into decadence, and fall to younger, more stoic successors. On to Volume II!

Title: The Worldly Philosophers
Author: Robert L. Heilbroner
My Review:
This book should be required reading for everyone, running through the major theories on economics from the beginning of the Capitalist economy until recent times (when the author thinks we have run out of 'Worldly Philosophers', since nowadays economists are too humbled to try and build major systems, rather just suggesting tweaks at the margins), in colourful and gripping terms, free of maths and full of biographical gracenotes. (The life of Thorstein Veblen in particular is a delight.) Here are some unsystematic notes I took, mostly about Marx:

1) Capitalism is based on constant instability, a series of crises (what another might call creative destruction...) in which the system only works provided you have a) constant growth and b) constant technological innovation.

2) This seems to be accepted today: we can date Capitalism from the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, up until our current time of continued industrial and technological growth. But (putting on a Malthusian cap) it doesn't seem like something which can, in theoretical terms, extend forever. The world's resources are finite, technological innovation is ? , and the robots might soon be able to do it all faster and better than us. In a post-growth, post-work, post-scarcity society, what is the optimal allocation of resources?

3) This all sounds very futurist, but my basic point is this: Capitalism is by definition limited to a given historical situation, and finite in duration.

4) Capitalism leads to increasing inequality. This also seems true, and as world growth drags, is increasingly felt in the political sphere. But here, enough concessions to social democracy may be enough to ameliorate these damages.

5) Obviously, Marx was wrong about a lot - both in theory, in predictions, and in actual mathematical errors. Writing an enormous, scientific system around some intuitions doesn't make them any more right. But his innovations were to think about labour as a commodity, about the importance of means of production, and about the ways in which social, cultural and political forces are connected.

~~~~

Continuation, after hearing this 'Elucidations' podcast episode with Brian Leiter

Leiter is fair when discussing the ways in which Marx was wrong and right, and in how the Marxist analysis applies to the contemporary US. But there are two things in which he is tremendously unfair.

1 is a general critique I have of rich-world leftists: anachronism, and local-centrism. It's all too easy to paint a picture of the misery and continuing immiseration of the world. But what are you comparing it to? In almost all times in the past, in almost all classes, life was worse than it is today. (This is maybe the most popular argument for capitalism, but it's true.) Perhaps you can point to a decline in living standards for a certain class over a short time span - say, the middle class has less real income today than 30 years ago - but it's always narrowly focused, and usually the result of an unusual boom or unsustainable welfare policy. To take that example, in the interim, the Chinese middle class has become enormously better off, so there have been huge gains, just redistributed. As a non-American, I'm not inclined to complain about a system that moves wealth from the American middle class to the Chinese poor. (Ah, they argue, but the wealthy have become wealthier! But we cannot focus on the distribution without looking at overall welfare. Capitalism is bumpy, and has vectors of increasing inequality/misery as well as the opposite. But the sum of those vectors is positive, in theory, and it seems to hold so far.) [Sidebar: another important lesson of the book is that all of the attempts to find systematic economic laws in the last few centuries have failed, because society, economies, technology have changed in such unpredictable ways that every scenario seems to require a new toolkit, without much ability to generalise.]

2 is Leiter's attack on moral philosophers. He claims that the ruling class is avaricious and ruthless, and one of the interviewers asks him if there's a moral element involved. Leiter adopts the Marxist argument that all moral intuitions flow from class structures: that our contemporary moral ideas all "happen to" coincide with the interests of the ruling class. I think this massively begs the question of moral philosophy, namely what is the good. He *assumes* that equal distribution of wealth should be our end goal, that everyone is equally deserving of the same amount, and thus that anything that doesn't contribute to this goal is immoral. This is basically to deny the validity of the moral intuitions of almost everyone who lived before Marx, and of most people today: to take everything and make it about one issue, which is very open to debate. It's craziness.

One last point: I mentioned above the Malthusian point about the finitude of resources. Marx takes it up, but offers no solution to it. The real heirs of Malthus are the environmentalists, although even they are split on this issue, as Walter Berglund laments in [b: Freedom|7905092|Freedom|Jonathan Franzen|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1316729686s/7905092.jpg|9585796]. Economists have spoken about it in different ways, but there is no real answer to it, either in capitalist or socialist ideologies.

Title: Elon Musk: Tesla, SpaceX, and the Quest for a Fantastic Future
Author: Ashlee Vance
My Review:
Ashlee Vance, author of this thorough and competently crafted biography currently draping bookstores, does a great job of walking the tightrope between unmitigated adulation of his subject, and no-holds-barred character assassination. Either method would have been easier; there would be no lack of ammunition. Vance relates how getting Musk's consent for the book was tricky, and involved a number of negotiation rounds during which Musk at first insisted on final review privileges, and the right to add footnotes, before eventually yielding to the author's persistence.

To say that Elon Musk is a polarising figure is somewhat understating things. A child prodigy blessed with seemingly endless energy and ambition, he left his (and my) native South Africa for Canada and then the US, did stints at Penn and Stanford universities, before founding Zip2, a sort of proto-Google Maps, selling out, and then founding X.com, which would become (after a bloody corporate takeover) PayPal.

This left Musk as a young dotcom billionaire, and he decided to use the money on fulfilling his biggest dreams. He saw Silicon Valley's agility and geeky smarts as wasted on click-chasing ad companies, and yearned for the optimistic Space Age days of large-scale manufacturing ambition. He wanted to replicate our generation's software breakthroughs in the world of nuts and bolts. This eventually led him - through near bankruptcy and much-maligned failures - to take charge of three visionary startups: SpaceX, the private space company; electric car manufacturer Tesla; and solar energy provider Solar City.

So much for the good. The prosecution also has its say, and there is no shortage of witnesses to call up. Musk is a harsh employer, demanding major sacrifices from employees, haranguing them over minor errors, and firing on a whim even confidantes who have given him years of loyalty. He is consumed by his work to the exclusion of all else, and one gains the sense that the twice-divorced father of five is not much fun to be around. (He is currently remarried to his second wife, English actress Talulah Riley, who took him back after confessing she didn't find too many better options.) The local gossip paper ValleyWag has taken many swipes against Musk in the past, to his great displeasure; there are some question marks over his academic credentials (Vance believes the charges to be false); and a trail of former partners and employees who see him as a crazed, sociopathic egotist. One does not save humanity, apparently, without making some enemies.

How do we judge, then? Is Elon Musk as big as his dreams - a heroic John Galt, besieged by smaller, petty minds, illuminating the way ahead? Or are his ideas about Mars colonies and dangerous AI as tinfoil-hat crazy as they sound to me? My own feeling is that no putative gain is worth sacrificing the values of humility and humanity, and the belief that no individual is that much greater than the society he inhabits. But I am also clearly not as smart as Musk is, and - perhaps more to the point - he has spent much of his career disproving the skeptics in spectacular fashion. (Both Tesla and SpaceX are currently thriving.) Dare we bet against him now?

Title: Night Wraps the Sky: Writings by and about Mayakovsky
Author: Vladimir Mayakovsky

Title: Going Places
Author: Leonard Michaels
My Review: Chaotic, surreal stories of bohemian life in the 50s.

Title: Six Easy Pieces: Essentials of Physics By Its Most Brilliant Teacher
Author: Richard P. Feynman

Title: The American
Author: Henry James
My Review: A defense of the nouveau riche against the stiff, ossified mores of the aristocracy. Having made his fortune, an American millionaire comes to Paris to learn the ways of the world. He attempts to woo a widowed scion of the old nobility, but trouble ensues. Delicately paced, and funny in parts, until the action picks up dramatically in tone and pace in the last third. James' urbane, refined style is always enjoyable, but this novel doesn't achieve the complexity or insight of greatness.
