Title: The Debt to Pleasure
Author: John Lanchester
My Review:
"You can always count on a murderer for a fancy prose style," says Humbert Humbert, and there are a number of similarities between him and the hero of this novel, a snobby aesthete, astoundingly knowledgeable, and completely mad. The conceit could have been anyone's, and the story, told in gaps between discussions on food, history, and aesthetics, pretty unimportant. What's great is the execution. Lanchester's impressive depth of food knowledge and general scholarship (I had to keep interrupting to Google: Cavalcanti, The Praise of Folly, Lichtenberg, etc.). I found it fun and edifying in equal measure. A fairly representative prose sample:

We then sat down to a meal which Dante would have hesitated to invent. I was seated opposite my parents, between a spherical house matron and a silent French assistant. The first course was a soup in which pieces of undisguised and unabashed gristle floated in a mud-coloured sauce whose texture and temperature were powerfully reminiscent of mucus. Then a steaming vat was placed in the middle of the table, where the jowly, watch-chained headmaster presided. He plunged his serving arm into the vessel and emerged with a ladleful of hot food, steaming like fresh horse dung on a cold morning. For a heady moment I thought I was going to be sick. A plate of soi-disant cottage pie – the mince grey, the potato beige – was set in front of me.

‘The boys call this “mystery meat”,’ confided matron happily. I felt the assistant flinch. Other than that I don’t remember (I can’t imagine) what we talked about, and over the rest of the meal – as Swinburne’s biographer remarked, à propos an occasion when his subject had misbehaved during a lecture on the subject of Roman sewage systems – ‘the Muse of history must draw her veil’.

Title: On the Origin of Species [Abridged]
Author: Charles Darwin
My Review: Abridged audio version read by today's Darwinist nonpareil, Richard Dawkins.

Title: The Blue Flower
Author: Penelope Fitzgerald
My Review: A taut novel composed with the obscure formality and gravity found in early family history. I'm not qualified to say how much of Fitzgerald's Saxony is historically accurate, but it certainly feels so - hardscrabble, frugal Lutherans settling down for harsh winters, incommunicate and austere patriarchs and their nervous wives, rigid class and economic barriers...and in the background, the glimmer of Jena, the gay university town where the Enlightenment and Romanticism glimmer. Many historical figures and events appear in this story, based on the poet Novalis and his unconsumated love affair with an inappropriately (especially by today's standards!) underage girl. There are cameos by Schiller, Goethe, Napoleon, and others, as well as the novel Heinrich von Ofterdingen, earlier titled The Blue Flower. The titular flower, non-existent in nature, seems to have had much influence on the later Romantics, who saw in it the fusion of mind and nature, and Man's striving to transcend his limitations. (Thus Benjamin's quip: "No one really dreams any longer of the Blue Flower. Whoever awakes as Heinrich von Ofterdingen today must have overslept.") But what is it, what does it represent, what exactly is our protagonist's inner state? This we are left to guess at, since our author, like her laconic characters, chooses to skip such lofty capital-P Philosophy, except when Novalis releases a stream of Idealist gibberish, something the others basically ignore. So: true Romantics, who we might think this book's natural audience, will found it bloodless and superficial. Instead, it stands either as unusually animated biographical research; or as an Empiricist scoff at all of those long-coated pale young men of Jena, forever seeing their Blue Flowers in silly young girls, just making trouble for the grown-ups around them.

Title: Pilgrimage, Volume 1: Pointed Roofs, Backwater, Honeycomb
Author: Dorothy M. Richardson

Title: Pictures From An Institution
Author: Randall Jarrell
My Review:
Look: Jarrell was renowned as a poet and a critic, not a novelist, and this novel-like object doesn't really cohere. It begins at the end, jumps to the beginning, sketches each of its characters and ends abruptly. What it is, is a means for Jarrell to construct lavish, ornate angel-hair paragraphs: riffing on Shakespeare and the Bible, warping speech cliches, then leaping suddenly into startling lyric beauty. The author's voice is wry, desultory - finding much to make fun of in his progressive college environment, but overall seeming at peace with it. This mocking isn't the excoriation from the outside of, say, William Buckley's [b: God and Man at Yale|844573|God and Man at Yale The Superstitions of 'Academic Freedom'|William F. Buckley Jr.|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1328862725s/844573.jpg|830099]; it's the witty banter heard at the Progressives' cocktail party, from one of the elder backbenchers.

It's fundamentally an unserious book, full of scholarly showmanship, so it's understandable that some might find it tiresome or show-offish. Certainly you can't lose attention, since the descriptions are sometimes almost so opaque as to defy comprehension (even after some sedulous Googling). But I've a taste for archaic literary takedowns (the main antagonist is supposedly a sketch of Mary McCarthy), so for me it was worth the effort. Your mileage may vary.

Title: The Varieties of Religious Experience
Author: William  James
My Review:
For obvious reasons, I've been trying to avoid news and politics for the last while, but I am fascinated by the anthropology of it - how people are capable of disagreeing so virulently on such fundamental issues. Take Mencius Moldbug, a brilliant scientist who happens to think that everything went downhill from the Glorious Revolution; or the fact that all the best historians of the 20th century were doctrinaire Marxists. When I was younger I naïvely thought that rational, intelligent actors would converge on a broad consensus, but it doesn't seem that way. I'm continually struck by the variety, even among similarly intelligent and educated people, of political beliefs.
A parallel discussion is the topic of William James' book [b: The Varieties of Religious Experience|28820|The Varieties of Religious Experience|William James|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1167956957s/28820.jpg|1751058], a transcript of his Gifford Lectures from the beginning of the last century. (He expresses a touching degree of pride at being an American lecturing to an audience of Europeans, a sentiment readers of his brother will understand...) James comes from the liberal, unitarian Boston that spawned Deists like Emerson and Thoreau - but also with Puritan roots, sporadically burned over by religious revival movements during the 1800s, and in which religion still plays an outsized role in public life when compared to Europe.
Dr James intends to analyze the different existing forms of belief in a detached, scientific way, and much of the book (maybe too much) is given over to testimonies of extreme religious experiences, from which he thinks we can deduce the more moderate types. Unfortunately, here the book suffers from a heavy bias toward Western Christianity. Occasional mention is made of non-Christian worship, but little is made of it.
James is wary of drawing fixed conclusions, committed to a certain relativism that takes into account the variety of human nature, culture and personality. But he is adamant that the religious instinct plays an important role in the human psyche, one that Enlightenment rationalism has not made redundant. In the most powerful moments of hope, fear, ecstasy, altruism or temptation, people are drawn to express some belief in a higher power.
Although secularism is more prevalent today than when these lectures were given, various forms of religious belief show no sign of waning, and some are stronger than ever. If these are positive and valuable, then, is there some specific belief or experience that we should aim towards? Here, James the psychologist is wary of prescribing any doctrinal positions that ought to apply to every person in every situation. He has little interest in the "science" of religion, the learned scholasticism of the Middle Ages. But he does very briefly formulate some of his own ideas, a sort of natural religion that requires belief in, and communion with, some power greater than oneself. The infinite varieties of which such being and such communion might be composed, is left to the individual to conceive, in accordance with her own nature.

Title: Enthusiasm: A Chapter in the History of Religion : With Special Reference to the XVII and XVIII Centuries
Author: Ronald Knox

Title: An Anthropologist on Mars: Seven Paradoxical Tales
Author: Oliver Sacks
My Review: Sacks is a humanist, holding a quill along with his scalpel, and honestly befriending his patients. It's amazing how little we know about the mind. Rather than looking for a solution to their ailments, the author seems to just get to know them, see the world as they do, and set it out journalistically. The result is captivating and moving.

Title: Bring Up the Bodies (Thomas Cromwell, #2)
Author: Hilary Mantel
My Review: Anne Boleyn is kind of a cartoonish villain, Machiavellian and amoral, but - no spoilers after 481 years! - she gets hers.

Title: Bring Up the Bodies (Thomas Cromwell, #2)

Title: Wolf Hall (Thomas Cromwell #1)
Author: Hilary Mantel
My Review: Out of my wheelhouse. Plodding at times, but picks up once Cromwell becomes the sort of Tudor Godfather. (Well, except for his terrifyingly capricious boss, but the real power is in the hands of the servants). If you're interested in history, politics and power, this is your thing; I can't speak for the historical accuracy.

Title: Architecture Without Architects: A Short Introduction to Non-Pedigreed Architecture
Author: Bernard Rudofsky

Title: The Girl Who Saved the King of Sweden
Author: Jonas Jonasson

Title: The Elegance of the Hedgehog
Author: Muriel Barbery
My Review: Some beautiful passages, and heady references to Tolstoy, Japanese film and phenomenology, but the core is surprisingly - disappointingly - insubstantial. I liked this book, I just wasn't sure if I respected it; it's like a beach read injected with an issue of the London Review of Books. Still worth reading in any case.

Title: The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire (All 6 Volumes)
Author: Edward Gibbon
My Review:
Nestorians, Arians and Ebionites; Avars, Lombards and Dacians; Visigoths and Ostrogoths, Belasarius, Barbarossa and Saladin, Bonniface and Baldwin, Trebizon and Nicaea; there are enormous heaps of history here, each story full of drama and lessons for today. But when you go through all six of these volumes, covering a millenium and a half of the Western world and some of the East, there isn't much time to dwell on specifics.

Thus an audiobook. The benefit ofthe format - that you can power through the boring parts by spacing out - is also its shortcoming: you can space out and miss a lot. These books cover an enormous amount of detail, and there will be parts to bore anyone, be they theological councils or play-by-plays of battles (I prefer the theology any day). But in between this is the foundation of modern Europe. Gibbon may have been famous for his (then) controversial attacks on Christianity (scepticism about the scale of early Christian martyrdom in particular, and a general dissatisfaction with the Church's lack of interest in secular learning), but this is not a one-dimensional tale of glorious Classicism descending into the boorishness of bishops, barbarians and Saracens. We see classical Rome disappear in fits and starts, replaced by 'Barbarians' - some good, some bad, some brave and wise, some not. Gibbon isn't afraid to dive deeply into Islamic history and show non-Christian points of view. The capital is overrun, moves to Ravenna and Constantinople, the Church splits, and eventually, somehow, we are in the 16th c. There's far too much material for me to remember here, far too many beautifully crafted sentences (check out Justin Evans' superb reviews of these books for more on that) to quote. But at least I got a flyover tour of fifteen centuries of history I'd known little about. Plus, hey: now I can say, I did it.

Title: One Summer: America 1927
Author: Bill Bryson
My Review:
Bryson is a born raconteur who turns uninspiring historical charcters into fascinating, often hilarious ones. (Here’s the secret: judicious use of adverbs!) Topics covered here include the birth of commercial flight (with the standard-bearer being Charles Lindbergh, a surly and taciturn man who was nonetheless universally revered before he became a Nazi sympathizer); Babe Ruth (plying his trade next to Lou Gehrig) going on his final record-busting streak; the Sacco-Vinzetti trial; the invention of commercially viable television, and much more. There’s lots of fun historical trivia, but the real draw is Bryson’s deadpan character sketches, like the lazy President Coolidge and his grasping sidekick (and future replacement) Herbert Hoover.

I’m not sure if the summer of 1927 was a particularly memorable one, or if Bryson could wield these talents on any given timeframe to similar results. At 600 pages, there might even be too much going on in this book - especially towards the end, where the cycle of “introduce topic with dramatic hyperbole -> find some wacky facts about the principals -> summarise denouement” becomes faster and a little tiresome. Still, this is exciting, a little edifying, and laugh-out-loud funny; perfect for a long plane ride or afternoon on the beach.

Title: The White Tiger
Author: Aravind Adiga
My Review:
I've never been to India, and what I know about it from the news is often very impressive: world-class technical schools! Entrepeneurial brio! Cosmpolitan, Western-educated citizens taking on the country's development problems and transforming it into the next great power!

It's easy to forget the staggering levels of poverty in the country, the starvation, the homelessness, the near-serfdom of poorer provinces, the lack of sewage facilities. In essence that contradiction is what this book seeks to take on.

This is a quick and readable book, often funny, often exciting, written in the voice of its scantily educated hero. I got through it over two long train rides.

The author was born in India but left at a young age, returning as an adult to write for Time magazine. In an interview he relates that he simply tried to capture "the voice of the men you meet as you travel through India — the voice of the colossal underclass." Where other countries have a "service culture", India has something of a "servility culture": desparately poor servants are acculturated to expect awful treatment from their masters and accept it as their lot in life. It is, for the unacquainted (like me), quite horrific.

The hero of this book is someone who has pulled himself out otf his bondage by committing a heinous crime (alluded to early on). He discusses his society, in a book-length letter to the Chinese Premier, with cynicism and anger. He has no Raskolnikov-like pangs of guilt. Having gotten a miserable lot in life, penned into a prison from which there are no legal means of escape, surrounded by corruption and thuggery, he "breaks bad". The author claims that there are many such men and women in India. It is a country of such extreme wealth and poverty, and the road to prosperity and equality is far longer than it may seem.

Title: New York Noise: Radical Jewish Music and the Downtown Scene
Author: Tamar Barzel

Title: The Corrections
Author: Jonathan Franzen
My Review: What is left to say about this book in 2017?

Title: The Corrections
Author: Jonathan Franzen
My Review: What is left to say about this book in 2017?

Title: The Corrections
Author: Jonathan Franzen
My Review: What is left to say about this book in 2017?

Title: Purity
Author: Jonathan Franzen
My Review:
There's little I can say about the plot without spoiling anything, except that it is tight, engrossing and maybe a little overwrought (the "magical realism" tag puzzled me, but might be related to the unlikelihood of many of the narrative twists). Franzen's prose is, as usual, crisp and intelligent; his love of nature is in abundance. His characters fit into a mold: they are usually antisocial and a little dysthimic, pessimistic about the world, cerebral and insecure. In short, this environmentalist, tech-skeptic West Coast leftie creates characters not unlike himself. (Which isn't to say that said characters are boring or overly similar, nor are they largely male - most of this book is narrated by women.)

Franzen made a faux pas in a pre-book interview when he mentioned that he'd contemplated adopting an Iraqi war orphan in order to understand the younger generation. Of course this is a pretty astronomically insensitive thing to say, but the flip side of that is the speaker's real commitment to attempting to understand a different generation. In parts of this book, that generation comes under fire for its over-reliance on technology, which in Franzen's eyes represents an all-encompassing prison, not unlike the old GDR in which much of the book occurs. Whether or not we use Twitter, iPads and smartphones, we are defining ourselves in relation to them. This criticism seems a little unfair: Franzen has swallowed the Silicon Valley rhetoric, before expressing his disgust at it. I think technology, and social media in particular, plays a much smaller role in our daily lives, augmenting rather than replacing former modes of social engagement. I remain skeptical of both Kurzweilian utopianism and ecological millenarianism (and see both in the light of Frank Kermode's idea that people need to structure their lives within an expected End of Days, to create the narratively satisfying "sense of an ending"). So some of the monologues on this topic felt unnecessary to me.

Still, those who have come to expect from post-experimental Franzen clear, fancy-free realist fiction, will not be disappointed. Eschewing postmodern posturing, he serves up a gimlet-eyed and up-to-the-minute description of our times and our foibles, of the ravages of recent German history, the beauty of the West Coast, the feeling of young love. There are also some funny references to real people (Snowden and Assange, as well as fellow authors like "Jonathan Savoir-Faire"). In sum: if you liked [b:Freedom|7905092|Freedom|Jonathan Franzen|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1316729686s/7905092.jpg|9585796] and [b:The Corrections|3805|The Corrections|Jonathan Franzen|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1355011305s/3805.jpg|941200], you will equally delight to enter this book's richly imagined world.

I remain skeptical of both Kurzweilian utopianism and ecological millenarianism (and see both in the light of Frank Kermode's idea that people need to structure their lives within an expected End of Days, to create the narratively satisfying "sense of an ending"). So some of the monologues on this topic felt unnecessary to me.

Still, those who have come to expect from post-experimental Franzen clear, fancy-free realist fiction, will not be disappointed. Eschewing postmodern posturing, he serves up a gimlet-eyed and up-to-the-minute description of our times and our foibles, of the ravages of recent German history, the beauty of the West Coast, the feeling of young love. There are also some funny references to real people (Snowden and Assange, as well as fellow authors like "Jonathan Savoir-Faire"). In sum: if you liked [b:Freedom|7905092|Freedom|Jonathan Franzen|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1316729686s/7905092.jpg|9585796] and [b:The Corrections|3805|The Corrections|Jonathan Franzen|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1355011305s/3805.jpg|941200], you will equally delight to enter this book's richly imagined world.

Title: The Rest Is Noise: Listening to the Twentieth Century
Author: Alex  Ross
My Review: It’s worth knowing from the top that if you don’t read music or have a basic grasp of music theory, parts of this book will whizz over your head. The author doesn’t shy away from describing music in terms of specific intervals or Italian adjectives. But that’s also not an obstacle to enjoying it. Ross weaves biographical details, politics and philosophy into his stories, showing the development of the avant-garde from Wagnerian pomp to twisted Romanticism (Salome, Wozzeck), to ethnic/folk revival (Bartók, Janáček), to dodecaphony (Schoenberg’s peak-Modernism insistence on using every note in the octave in equal measure) and atonality, to Minimalism in forms more (Philip Glass) or less (La Monte Young) palatable (someone at a Steve Reich premiere got up and shouted “Stop, stop, I confess!”), to the kitchen-sink broad-mindedness of Harry Partch, and to today’s globally-inspired, post-everything smorgasbord (albeit playing to a shrinking and graying audience). This book in some ways was like a musical equivalent of [b: The Shock of the New|542639|The Shock of the New|Robert Hughes|https://images.gr-assets.com/books/1175649708s/542639.jpg|1666984] - plenty engaging as a linear read, but even more valuable as a reference book. My only gripe might be the implicit snobbiness of the title (never addressed in the book’s pages...) But I think that the author would argue that most of what is interesting in pop and rock has been built in some way on the iconoclasm and ambition of 20th century revolutionaries.

Title: Cabinet of Natural Curiosities: The Complete Plates in Colour, 1734-1763
Author: Albertus Seba

Title: In Persuasion Nation
Author: George Saunders
My Review:
After a long recess, I’m currently getting back into some fiction... George Saunders is all over lately with his first novel having just come out. Although I happily concede that there is no coherent argument for genre fiction having any lesser stature vs. the 'literary' kind, I just don't like the bulk of it, and seeing the term 'science fiction' bandied about in reviews of Mr Saunders' work had at first kept me away. But his style is more like science-augmented reality, or plain old surrealism. These stories are about the real world, until a point - where a comically exaggerated extrapolation of our world bulges out. They are odd, leading us into a familiar room, then pointing out that the mat beneath our feet is a talking robot.

Saunders' characters are unmistakably American, and his love for his countrymen with all their foibles is as evident here as it was in his reporting for the New Yorker from “Trump country”. The stories generally follow simple-minded, struggling characters, whose bumbling leads to circumstances first comic, then tragic. (This formula obtains for basically the whole book, which very slightly diminishes the power of the collection.) His eye is gentle and forgiving, his protagonists loving fools who seek only to pursue their unique versions of happiness, but in that pursuit encounter credit card debt, confusing bureaucracy, and mandatory consumption of advertisements.

Advertising comes under Saunders’ klieg light the most. Behind the gimlet-eyed surreality, and a critique of passive reality TV culture that echoes David Foster Wallace, one finds here a somewhat Tolstoyan call for kindness as the supreme virtue - a sense that, though culture and country may have gone astray and bowed to the narcissistic irrationality, still, as long as we persist, there will be a way back.

Title: Tenth of December
Author: George Saunders
My Review: Most of the characters in these stories are simple-minded and kind-hearted, although their pasts are sometimes a little patchy. They live in a slightly tweaked version of our world, in which our cosmetic symbiosis with technology is satirically magnified. Unethical scientists pump mind-altering chemicals into prisoners to conduct psychology experiments, and foreign workers are strung up as garden decorations via electric cables through their temples. Saunders is a skilled writer, but none of the stories quite hit the sweet spot. (The longest, The Semplica-Girl Diaries, probably comes closest, although I enjoyed the Renaissance Faire melodrama of My Chivalric Fiasco.) Is it unfair to say I expected more from a MacArthur grantee? (Yes, of course it is.)

Title: Last of the Old Guard
Author: Louis Auchincloss
My Review: This came out in 2008, which is amazing, because that makes it like, a late, late, late Edith Wharton novel. Obviously, I love it.

Title: The Cabaret of Plants: Forty Thousand Years of Plant Life and the Human Imagination
Author: Richard Mabey
My Review: A whole string of essays about cool plants: giant Amazonian water-lilies, ancient pagan yews, ferns, daffodils...I learned a lot, and Mabey's writing has flashes of inspiration. But it doesn't quite hold together. I wish there was a clearer theme, a direction for all of these sketches. But rather the overweening idea is, "PLANTS - they're quite something, huh?" Which is hard to disagree with.

Title: Spain
Author: Jan Morris
My Review:
Full of the wonder and wildness of ancient, chivalrous, Spain, and the disorienting possibility of the post-Franco* years. Short on details, long on experiences - like the best travel (writing).

P.S. I'm going on Friday!

*Though only barely, when this book came out.

Title: Spain
Author: Jan Morris
My Review:
Full of the wonder and wildness of ancient, chivalrous, Spain, and the disorienting possibility of the post-Franco* years. Short on details, long on experiences - like the best travel (writing).

P.S. I'm going on Friday!

*Though only barely, when this book came out.

Title: Walden: Or, Life in the Woods
Author: Henry David Thoreau
My Review:
Things I like featured here: being in nature, self-reliance, vegetarianism, reading classics.

Things I don't like featured here: being cut off from city life, philosphical dogmatism, reading classics in the original Greek.

Thoreau left the woods at the end of two years because he "had other lives to live", so, like, I wouldn't see this as a guidebook for life like some do, more just a cool phase to go through.

If you live in a nice city with bookshops and weird people and life and culture and alternative bookshops and a bit of nature left, that's probably the best of all possible worlds (sorry, Candide).

Title: The Invention of Nature: Alexander von Humboldt's New World
Author: Andrea Wulf
My Review:
'Two souls, alas, are housed within my breast./And each will wrestle for the mastery there.' - Goethe, Faust

Humboldt was a Romanticist who felt torn between C.P. Snow's 'two cultures' - science and art. A Romanticist, he struggled to fit within his nature the dry and mechanical nature of the science of his time, which saw nature as a Cartesian machine run by a remote watchmaker Deity. His response to this was to reinvent what science meant. A spirit of adventure led him to South America and Siberia from where he wrote stirring poetic descriptions of the natural world.

Humboldt wasn't the first person to find enchantment in nature. In fact, the anti-enlightenment Romanticism which inspired him had made natural beauty a key part of its anti-industrial spirit. But Humboldt was the first scientist to see his calling as something compatible with natural wonder, and one of his books, Cosmos, inspired the same wonder in his generation as its namesake TV shows did in our times. His new approach also opened his eyes to some of the hypocrisies of his time: slavery, colonialism, the degradation of the environment. (A lifelong liberal, his admiration for the US was matched by his abhorrence for its toleration of slavery.)

This book is about not just Humboldt's life, but also those that he inspired, including Darwin, Thoreau, George Marsh, Ernst Haeckel (whose Kunstformen der Natur was a major influence on the floral curves of the Art Nouveau), and John Muir, the "patron saint" of environmentalism. Our vision of nature has changed from that of an attractive backdrop to that of a dynamic, vulnerable system which may not be around forever. This book artfully and engagingly tracks this awakening, a story as much about imagination as science and society.

Title: SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome
Author: Mary Beard
My Review: A more modern approach than that of Will Durant in a number of ways: 1)focusing on representative key events and people rather than trying to tell everything, 2)showing more of the nuts and bolts of actual historical work, talking about excavations and comparing evidence to sources, rather than just reading Tacitus and Livy and guessing, and 3)a more modern focus on the poor, non-citizens, women, etc, although this is still a pretty traditional history, not a radical corrective. If you take away just one thing from this review it should be this: this book is cracking fun to read, and gives an up-to-date and authoritative view of what the Roman Empire was, how it was different and how it was familiar. Beard doesn't agree with the lazy editorial-ish line that the Roman Empire has a lot to teach us, but she does think that by investigating it, and thinking about our own society, we can gain better tools to grapple with our own problems.

Title: How to Win Friends and Influence People
Author: Dale Carnegie
My Review:
A number of people have told me this book isn't as trite and cliched as one might think, so I thought I'd give it a fair chance. Sadly it seems they were wrong.

(There are way too many stories that end in "...that man's name? Enrico Caruso/Charles Dickens/Abraham Lincoln/Napoleon Bonaparte" etc etc etc)

Title: Prep : A Novel
Author: Curtis Sittenfeld
My Review: This book is classified on Goodreads as "Chick Lit" and "Young Adult", and I, a curmudgeonly hater of all genre fiction (and neither a chick nor a YA), was really happy to be blown away by it. A tightly structured tale of high school life (what a perfect scaffolding the academic year makes for a novel), narrated with honesty and maturity by a character that must surely be autobiographical to some extent, Prep is the story of how life feels among people who are incrementally more sophisticated and astronomically more wealthy than oneself. It's also about the awkwardness of high school, and that of being plain-looking and without any special talent. (Like most people.) Coming of age as a neurotic, shy, slightly literary girl whose greatest fear is that her urbane classmates get to know her earthy Midwestern family comes to feel like a totally universal experience. If the point of literature is to instill empathy, here is great literature - compelling without cliché, confessional but not mawkish, aware that the greater part of growing up is accepting both our ordinariness and our strangeness.

Title: Motorman
Author: David Ohle
My Review: Went into this short read with little foreknowledge, and it hit me hard. This is language as matter without form, and could easily be alienating, but, like the Dali painting with the melting clocks, it's close enough to the familiar to keep you gazing at it. Its aesthetic is harsh and noirish: picture the film Eraserhead, but without the hopeful parts. The plot concerns a man being persecuted by a mysterious antagonist who controls the electricity grid and the weather. I read this on poorly-formatted online samizdat without the Ben Marcus intro people are talking about, but it's easy to see the anxiety of influence on the latter. Strange and haunting, and fully deserving of its cult status.

Title: The Scientists: A Family Romance
Author: Marco Roth
My Review: A strange, deeply personal book - not at all what I expected. Marco Roth grew up in an almost comically cultured and high-minded Manhattan home, the precocious son of a doctor father and artist mother. Chamber music performances and bedtime Russian novels were fixtures of his upbringing. But his father's death of AIDS - ostensibly contracted from a stray needle while treating a heroin addict, although the book centres around the son's growing scepticism of this narrative - causes him to peel back the layers of family history. The book begins as a funny, wry, memoir, and gradually gets darker. At a certain point, it becomes something of a Comparative Lit dissertation, pulling together several semi-famous 19th C. European novels as representative of the absent father. Inconsistency here is testament to authenticity: Roth is hyperintellectual and congenitally sad, listlessly pulling at the thread of his family's secrets in the search for closure. Like hanging out with a brilliant, depressed friend. This may or may not sound appealing to you: your opinion of the book will follow suit.

Title: The Buddha in the Attic
Author: Julie Otsuka
My Review: Formally experimental in its first-person narration, but otherwise not a challenging book, which should by no means be seen as criticism. The taut, chant-like chapters of this slim book flew by: I read it over a weekend. Telling the story of Japanese women brought to California as brides for migrant farm workers, and later interned during WWII - a theme covered more closely in the author's previous novel - this well-researched story converts multiple, different narratives into a choir, a plurality of voices. Some of the stories are hopeful. Most are not. The lives of the heroes are full of both the everyday sufferings of rural life before modern medicine and human rights, and the particular ones of being minorities in an openly racist land. We are not given individual characters to bond with. Instead we have an amorphous mass of people, shuffling through a confusing and hostile world. That is an imaginative and effective way of portraying history, a mass of little stories adding up to a complete narrative (paging Count Tolstoy!) I learned a bit about a historical topic I'd been totally ignorant of, and was moved by the fate of the faceless people it carried along. Particularly relevant in 2016, yet another time of migration and its concomitant mistrust, fear and cruelty.

Title: Love and Obstacles
Author: Aleksandar Hemon
My Review: Heard a lot about the author, but this was my first time reading his work. I liked the deceptively simple and muscular prose, which keeps things moving along without much emotional hand-wringing. Yet the stories are full of brutality. The author is a Bosnian transplant who escaped the wars of the 90s to Chicago, and these stories are a loose retelling of his upbringing - the son of diplomats, a teenage poet, difficult early years as an immigrant, and later on, minor literary stardom (though how much is true and how much made up is part of the writer's game.) Its world is bleak, mocking the innocence of the young, all of a sudden spinning into violence or seedy sex. (Some reviews here draw comparisons to Nabokov, which mystifies me: at least based on this sample, they are chalk and cheese.)

Title: Out of Sheer Rage: Wrestling With D.H. Lawrence
Author: Geoff Dyer
My Review: Whip-smart, endlessly neurotic, a recursive monologue of loathing (self- and general) firmly in the tradition of Thomas Bernhard. The author simply cannot write his study of Lawrence, either because of where he is currently living, which books he does/doesn't have, the climate, etc. He vacillates endlessly, his very contentment making him immediately discontent. This might quickly become tedious (I was starting to get tired of it by page 20) until one realises that, sneakily, the study of Lawrence is starting to take shape behind the scenes. As Dyer stalks the exotic locales where his study lived, he uses quotes from Lawrence's letters and diaries, along with references to his contemporaries and influences (Rilke, Camus), to portray an image of Lawrence the relentless cynic, a perpetual émigré who could never quite be happy anywhere. (I am currently reading the diaries of Kenneth Tynan and starting to worry that this might be an English thing.) And there is something deeper. By the end of the book, Dyer gropes with his battle with depression, his need for a cause to battle against, a resentment against the world that enables him to escape a pit of nihilistic despair. And then follows up with a comprehensive bibliography: apparently the job was done, taking shape not despite his frustration, but in fact, its very incarnation.

Title: The Magic Kingdom
Author: Stanley Elkin
My Review: A thrillingly unique book. Weird topic, baroque sentence structures (everything is repeated in increasingly rare synonyms, like a hyper-verbose echo), a plot that wends through Buckingham Palace and Disney World in a morbid, yet matter-of-fact, monotone. Elkin lived much of his later life with Multiple Sclerosis, and this chronicle of pain and palliative care in the land of magic consumerism suggests that all of us - with moles, flab, nostril hair and varicose veins - are suffering, or temporarily in abeyance. Beginning with a death, and then spinning out into the worlds of its (mostly) terminally ill heroes, this story lands one mordant punchline after another. Poised at the edge of the abyss, it seems not to want to take sides, merely to point out how strange it all is.

Title: Wolfson Of Harvard: Portrait Of A Scholar
Author: Leo W. Schwarz

Title: The Art of Fielding
Author: Chad Harbach
My Review:
There are two ways to write a book review: an actual Amazon-style assessment (whimsical/sad/exciting/I didn't like the hero's cat, etc.); and the style common to more literary Reviews of Books, which more or less use the book as a springboard for some thoughts on the general topic. My style on here is usually to give my gut response to the book, trying to surface the two or three most pressing responses I experienced while reading it, and eschewing plot summaries or informed background, and thus somewhat lacking in the strengths of either of the methods mentioned above, though hopefully still with some appeal to aesthetic types who privilege experience over information.

Anyhow, this book came with some high expectations for me, coming from the pen of n+1 founding editor Chad Harbach. (I've previously reviewed here novels by Keith Gessen and Ben Kunkel.) Those were confounded, in a good way, by what is basically a riproaring yarn, a classic, near-mythical sports novel which pits a hard-working underdog team against big-money opponents - and I'd never dream of spoiling what happens next. Let me reiterate that: this is a gripping sports story, and I know absolutely nothing about baseball (coming from a cricket-playing country).

There are some elements of the author's American Studies background: a Melville motif wraps itself around the college, and there is a Whitman-infused love affair between two men. Some of the vocabulary is beautifully precise, frequently flummoxing my e-reader. But this is essentially not a challenging novel; not social satire, not puncturing intellectual pretensions, nary a word of Theory crossing onto its pages. Its a page-turner suited for all readers. Its heart is in the 1950s (where it could be transferred, with the scrubbing of strangely few modern references), where its all-American heroes could be found more often, taking to the flawless green diamond, for all the world like Greek warriors headed for Troy.

Title: Zoology
Author: Ben Dolnick
My Review: There's something I find deeply appealing in tales of naive, Walter Mitty-ish losers, who find a kind of arcadian joy in the world even as it continues to reject them. This is an apparently somewhat autobiographical tale of a college dropout who moves to the big city, falls in unrequited love, and bonds with farmyard animals. He is not very bright, a little overweight, and largely oblivious to the emotions of those around him. But despite not being destined for greatness, he manages to finds satisfaction in his own little piece of the world; which, the book seems to say, is what growing up is all about.

Title: Log of the S.S. The Mrs. Unguentine
Author: Stanley Crawford
My Review:
A tantalising, absurd, metafictional story of the type that flourished during its era (1970s): a nearly wordless couple live on a giant barge, on which they've planted trees, flowers, vegetables – an entire ecosystem, in fact – all under a giant glass dome, built out of scrap materials trawled from the ocean floor in a diving bell. Strange, inexplicable things occur; the marriage itself, between the narrator and the near-wordless, abusive, Unguentine, never quite comes into focus.

This interview sheds some more light on the ideas of the author, a prodigy turned garlic farmer in the Southwest: puzzlement at the unravelling of America's social fabric, environmentalism, survivalism, and an interest in his wife's mother, the widow of a surly German chemist not unlike the title character? The lack of emotional resonance bothered me, but this is an alienated book about a near post-human life. The writer, like Beckett, is a fluent French speaker, and ice-cold, crisp prose abounds. I'll close with a fairly representative quote (about the narrator's son):

But no name. Unguentine refused. To name, he said, would be to grasp the near and present end of the chain called history, and thus to forge another link, and how sad! I agreed. He remained namless. Child, baby, son. Quite enough terms to cover his condition.

Title: Cheerful Money: Me, My Family, and the Last Days of Wasp Splendor
Author: Tad Friend
My Review: A warm, fuzzy and familiar sweater of a book. Friend's spiel is essentially that he comes from American nobility, a venerable WASP clan that primed him for greatness exactly at the moment that its empire was crumbling under the blows of meritocracy and transparency. (Crumbling, though even today one supposes, not completely crumbled.) But in practice this book is a regular family memoir, told with sensitivity, nostalgia and affection, though not bereft of criticism. Friend exemplifies the positive traits of his, uh, ethnicity? clan? cohort? - but is keenly aware of the negatives - scandals kept secret, bad marriages, repression, racism, alcoholism. Meandering through the story of his privileged upbringing, stopping to examine childhood homes, back-stories of minor relatives, fizzled relationships and lost years: in the hands of a lesser writer, this could become quite a drag. But Friend is a gifted writer, wielding his intelligence carefully, and writing with kindness, wit and an understated grace. So the story starts to feel almost like a lost memory, on a lawn by the beach, where the reader came of age, feeling the ocean swell and the sting of homesickness with each turn of the page.

Title: The Pale King
Author: David Foster Wallace
My Review:
So many good reviews here, and so much has already been said in general about this author and this book. It feels very far from finished, but this might just be the end of Part I. The author's notes at the end are very helpful at putting some structure onto this: the battle between senior administrative figures around digitisation of the tax-collecting work, the value of humans to a repetitive job, the value to humans of a repetitive job, the transcendental power of boredom, civic duty and the ways in which American society has changed since the 60s.

Without those notes, this is a series of longish setpieces, all of which contain DFW's trademark dazzling monologues, endless sentences (full of dangling clauses and footnotes), deadpan, laugh-out-loud humour, and of course brilliance. So many of his ideas seem to predict where we were headed: constantly connected, constantly distracted. Even unfinished, it deserves to be read, and has much to teach us.

Title: Infinite Jest
Author: David Foster Wallace
My Review:
Were not the apt sobriquet "hysterical realism" already invented, I'd have preferred something along the lines of "Adderall neuroticism" to describe the febrile, run-on monologues that take up so much of Infinite Jest. The pharmacological motif also synecdochatically echoes a major theme in the novel; no accident, one assumes. Addiction to technology, entertainment, or psychic support is mirrored by that of the residents of Emmett House, but they also serve as wellspring for the omniscient narrator's powers of description.

And what makes David Foster Wallace so compelling a stylist is in no small part his ability to conjure bizarre, often surrealist images (a child without a skull, his eyes sliding down his plastic bag-like face; a women only capable of moving sideways) combined with hyperreal, textbook-level detail, drawn from his seemingly endless compendium of knowledge.

What may be a flaw (although it's clearly intentional) in Infinite Jest, is its complete shapelessness - a deficiency which David Foster Wallace's description of the shape as a 'Sierpinski Gasket' does more to aggravate then to ameliorate. The [MINOR SPOILER ALERT] suddenness of the ending is part of the aimless, or rather cyclical, flow of the various plots of addiction and mindlessness.

But ultimately: Wallace harnesses the power of language in ways almost no writer living or dead can match. IJ is a tsunami of ferocious mimesis, washing away our ignorance and apathy, seeping into the tiny crannies of our daily lives, literary virtuosity distilled into rivulets of experience. This is why we write, and this is why we read.

IJ is a tsunami of ferocious mimesis, washing away our ignorance and apathy, seeping into the tiny crannies of our daily lives, literary virtuosity distilled into rivulets of experience. This is why we write, and this is why we read.

Title: Infinite Jest
Author: David Foster Wallace
My Review:
Were not the apt sobriquet "hysterical realism" already invented, I'd have preferred something along the lines of "Adderall neuroticism" to describe the febrile, run-on monologues that take up so much of Infinite Jest. The pharmacological motif also synecdochatically echoes a major theme in the novel; no accident, one assumes. Addiction to technology, entertainment, or psychic support is mirrored by that of the residents of Emmett House, but they also serve as wellspring for the omniscient narrator's powers of description.

And what makes David Foster Wallace so compelling a stylist is in no small part his ability to conjure bizarre, often surrealist images (a child without a skull, his eyes sliding down his plastic bag-like face; a women only capable of moving sideways) combined with hyperreal, textbook-level detail, drawn from his seemingly endless compendium of knowledge.

What may be a flaw (although it's clearly intentional) in Infinite Jest, is its complete shapelessness - a deficiency which David Foster Wallace's description of the shape as a 'Sierpinski Gasket' does more to aggravate then to ameliorate. The [MINOR SPOILER ALERT] suddenness of the ending is part of the aimless, or rather cyclical, flow of the various plots of addiction and mindlessness.

But ultimately: Wallace harnesses the power of language in ways almost no writer living or dead can match. IJ is a tsunami of ferocious mimesis, washing away our ignorance and apathy, seeping into the tiny crannies of our daily lives, literary virtuosity distilled into rivulets of experience. This is why we write, and this is why we read.

Title: Consider the Lobster and Other Essays
Author: David Foster Wallace

Title: Consider the Lobster and Other Essays
Author: David Foster Wallace

Title: Consider the Lobster and Other Essays
Author: David Foster Wallace

Title: Consider the Lobster and Other Essays
Author: David Foster Wallace

Title: The Depressed Person
Author: David Foster Wallace
My Review:
For friends of a depressed person, it's really hard to know how best to relate to them: whether to indulge their need to talk (often difficult when one's time and energy are limited) or, on the other extreme, tell them to 'snap out of it' - cruel, yes, but how else will you go on? Whose responsibility is this thing, anyway?

That question seems to be the basic premise in this funny, whip-smart short story, originally published in Harper's magazine. But it's difficult to relate to it without mentioning the pachyderm in the quarters: Wallace's own depression and eventual suicide. The story's ending (spoiler alert, but c'mon, it's like eight pages) shows the neediness of the depressed person to be even more thoughtless and craven than we first realised - but what else would we expect when the author identifies so strongly with the self-loathing of his character?

Perhaps the picture isn't quite so bleak as it's made out to be here. Perhaps the woman's friend (revealed to be suffering silently from a terminal illness) isn't quite as put upon as she seems to be. Seen through the lens of the depression which robbed America of one of its brightest, most promising writers, it seems impossible for it to have ended any other way.
