Title: Palestine
Author: Joe Sacco
My Review: Important reading, beautifully crafted and unflinchingly honest, attuned to the human dimension of a tragedy rarely absent from the headlines.

Title: The Invisible Front: Love and Loss in an Era of Endless War
Author: Yochi Dreazen
My Review:
America's fully volunteer army is cut off in many ways from the general population, and most people have only a vague idea of the isolation and trauma suffered by many combat veterans. This book tells the heart-breaking story of a family that lost two sons - one to depression and one to an IED in Iraq. The vastly different responses shown to the two deaths by the military establishment led them to wage a battle against the culture of machismo that considers depression and PTSD a weakness rather than an illness.

From the earliest iterations of "shell shock" or "battle fatigue", the book covers the military's reluctance to acknowledge the traumatic effects of battle on otherwise healthy, courageous soldiers. Over months of research, and hundreds of hours of personal interviews, Dreazen has assembled a complete picture of a family's history and intimate life, their foibles, jokes and bonds of love. And through interviews with officers from the top ranks of the Army, he shows the challenge of changing a culture, and the army's struggle to deal with what is no less than an epidemic: the eponymous "invisible front", which, in 2012, took more lives than the war in Iraq.

Title: Indecision
Author: Benjamin Kunkel
My Review:
Even more than with fellow n + 1 co-founding editor Keith Gessen's [b:All the Sad Literary Young Men|1355547|All the Sad Young Literary Men|Keith Gessen|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1266781135s/1355547.jpg|2113522], it's almost impossible to talk about this book without talking about the author's background and subsequent life choices. Like Whit Stillman in his movies, Kunkel is a WASPy prep school grad whose characters are likewise, except they're also dumb, lovable putzes. Kunkel's hero is a slacker with a Philosophy degree (his last name of Wilmerding becomes the email handle 'Wilmerdingansich', get it?) lacking the volition to get past his dead-end corporate job or commit to his girlfriend. Given an illicit sample of a new drug promising to cure indecision, he heads off to Ecuador to visit an old girlfriend and turn a page in his life.

The funny thing is that, despite the protagonist's cluelessness and obvious disinterest in politics, this is a very political book, full of angry lefties fuming about Neoliberalism and Western imperialism in the Global South. It reads very much like satire: the book's narrator feels vaguely bad and flirts with "democratic socialism", but never really seems to buy into the deeper economic worldview. Given the angle of the magazine Kunkel set up, though, and his subsequent move to South America and authorship of the millenial Neo-Marxist manual [b:Utopia or Bust|12949288|UTOPIA OR BUST|Yanyara|https://s.gr-assets.com/assets/nophoto/book/50x75-4845f44723bc5d3a9ac322f99b110b1d.png|18106064], you have to assume he's at least semi-serious. Maybe this is how things work nowadays. Unable to express anything sincerely, we have to give over political speeches with a self-aware smirk as if to say, I know, I'm a privileged rich kid, and this has all been done before - but so what.

Anyway, I gave it four stars because it had enough funny parts and plot twists. Never has a book been so keen to disavow politics it secretly believes. [Full disclosure: after years of online browsing - and guilted by the paywall - I recently took out a subscription to n + 1.]

Title: Buffett: The Making of an American Capitalist
Author: Roger Lowenstein
My Review:
My dad bought me this book and I finally read it.

In some ways this guy is the ultimate Mr Burns-like single-minded capitalist. But to be fair to him: he's consistently fought for his income bracket to have to pay much higher taxes, repeatedly attacked Bush's tax cuts for the rich, and finally commited to giving away almost all of his money to the Gates foundation. In some ways I think he is quintessentially American, in the same sense that Citizen Kane is the quintessential American movie.

Title: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man
Author: James Joyce

Author: James Joyce

Title: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man
Author: James Joyce

Title: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man
Author: James Joyce

Title: A Naked Singularity
Author: Sergio de la Pava
My Review:
A tough book to review. I picked this up maybe six months ago, got first excited by and then bogged down in the endless pseudophilosophical dialogue, which is much less interesting or persuasive than the author thinks. When I returned to it, I found it gradually improving. De la Pava is manic and goes through modes: dorm-room bull session, Spanglish family scenes, an epistolary novel about a mentally ill condemned man, the never-ending saga of 1980s boxing and then, closer to the end, a high-suspense crime-fiction fantasy followed by a breathtakingly Kafkaesque downfall. And an ending which is, well, singular.

In parts fascinating, this book is also startlingly amateurish in composition and in desparate need of an editor. What is its central theme? How do the various plots tie together? How much dumbed-down philosophy about The Honeymooners do we really need? There's raw talent here, and I'd like to read more, but this book isn't a finished product.

Title: No Regrets: Three Discussions
Author: Dayna Tortorici
Additional Authors: Elif Batuman, Namara Smith, Astra Taylor, Emily Witt, Carla Blumenkranz, Kristin Dombek, Emily Gould, Elizabeth Gumport, Amanda Katz, Sara Marcus, Dawn Lundy Martin, Sarah Resnick, n+1

Title: A Field Guide to Getting Lost
Author: Rebecca Solnit

Title: Orlando
Author: Virginia Woolf
My Review: One giant, raised middle finger to literary pretension, the tyranny of objective truth, and gender. A trans adventurer-poet's trip through four centuries of English lit and history, and her/his struggle for artistic authenticity. Ignore the winking Bloomsbury cynicism - this book is deeply felt, transgressing boundaries between self and other, between suppressed and accepted voices, between male and female love. Woolf's tone is arch, but her sweeping vision of society in decay is unmistakably tragic.

Title: Dissident Gardens
Author: Jonathan Lethem
My Review: The non-chronological chronicle of three generations of American leftists, their politics and private drama, and the way their foibles impact each other. Lethem's strength as an author is his seemingly endless trove of knowledge about history, pop-culture, music, religion, etc. and he leverages it to write funny and compulsively readable prose. He isn't as good at writing strong characters. Most of them feel like flat collections of tropes, albeit flawelessly researched (Communist Party renegade, '60s folk singer, rebellious hippie daughter). Still worthwhile entertainment for your buck. I spent the last few weeks of my morning commute listening to the audiobook, read by theatre actor Mark Bramhall, whose perfect navigation of the various accents and foreign languages elevated the reading from mere function into performance. My LibriVox days are gone for good.

Title: The Wallcreeper
Author: Nell Zink
My Review:
This whip-smart, dry, art-and-literary-infused novella (my search history while reading it: Empress Theodora, Fragonard, Duino Elegies, Beau Geste, Caduveo, Francis Girod, Philosophy in the Boudoir...) came pretty much out of nowhere for me, put out by an indie press, together with a gushing blurb from J. Franzen, apparently a personal friend of the author. In this Paris Review "microinterview" she comes across as oddly self-contained, unambitious, almost Zen, working as a translator, enjoying life in Germany, writing this book on a whim.

But enough about the author: this book is challenging and lightning-paced, reminiscent in its small talk of Renata Adler's hyperintelligent aperçus and Joy Williams' anarchic enviro-misanthropy. Because its hero, spurred by her (unloved) husband's birdwatching, begins an environmentalist crusade, swooping in and out of the labyrinth that is European environmentalism: government bureaucracy, shoestring NGOs, petty infighting. There are numerous love affairs and an ex-Stasi priest and a bikini barista. The bleak vision of Europe being choked by well-intentioned developers ("HYDROPOWER, NO THANKS!" as a ubiquitous slogan puts it) gives one cause for despair. The quality of the writing, though, is a crisp and new as one of the dawn-lit, foggy marshes in which the heroine might camp out.

Title: Take Five
Author: D. Keith Mano
My Review:
I've agonised over how exactly to review this behemoth, this tsunami of cultural references (both high and low), scatology and eschatology, racism, shlock and Joycean stream-of-perception. For the sake of honesty, I'll state that a big chunk of it just went beyond me: I couldn't Google all of the myriad references (where I was even able to detect them; the many shrewd injokes I laughed atgacve me a gleaming of how much I must have missed), nor, in the absence of an e-copy (having had to order this from Amazon, and hopefully putting some bread in the jar of the good people at Dalkey Archive), unable to look up the words I didn't understand, I must plead the incapacity to give over a comprehensive, thought out review. All I can offer is some fragments of my gut reaction (and in parts, this is a novel which affects the reader exactly there). And recommend the very helpful notes by the author quoted by Nathan "N.R." Gaddis in his review.

Certainly this book is sui generis. The language is dense and daunting. Consider this opening:

Simon.
Simon.
Simon - you'll forgive him, the deaf seem rude among us - Simon is on a dig again. Claw up dirt, catch it, raise - aaaar-um, sprocket wheel around and dump: the fifth hole he has exhumed tonight, todawn. His sandhog immigrant hand dredge and pry.


I mean - I think I know what's going on there, but I can't account for every word. That was my experience with the rest of the book, too. Which is paginated (and enchaptered) backwards, from around 600 to (what else?) ∞. But, weaving around that, there is a brisk, surprisingly slapstick, funny plotline, involving the abrasive and obscenely prejudiced last scion of an old WASP family trying to finance and make a modernised film version of the life of Jesus. In so doing, he dresses up as a Spanish revolutionary to reënact the nostalgic memories of a bed-ridden old woman, attends a party thrown by a creepy artist who makes sculptures based on microscopic images of bodily fluids, lies, offends, wheedles and suffers the progressive loss of his five senses.

And here's another thing: there's a deep religious sensitivity underpinning this book, mostly in the guise of the hero's uncle, a disgraced Episcopalian priest, but also another whose identity comes as something of a surprise (I won't spoil it). I've read that Mano's work grapples with the future direction of Christianity; making him, a playwright, novelist and TV scriptwriter, quite an ecumenical character. His formidable learning shows up in discussions about Heidegger and theology, but just when you're hooked on that, there's a dick joke and an escaped monkey or two. Mano's immersion in New York's various subcultures in second to none - his use of yiddishisms and Jewish mystical terminology is terrific. (The book's characterisation of black people, though, is shameful and shows its age.)

In sum: a book I was frustrated and enthralled by in equal measures. One that I would probably not recommend to anyone, but also one of undeniable depth, possessed of poetic scansion and raucous sensibility peculiar to its time and place. Few people would dedicate the time to writing a book like this, and not many more would read it; but certainly we are all richer for it.

Author: Ben Lerner
My Review:
Terrific, like a scalding espresso on an icy morning. This is the book I need to be reading now. I read and loved its Iberian predecessor [b:Leaving the Atocha Station|11100788|Leaving the Atocha Station|Ben Lerner|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1358349946s/11100788.jpg|16022898] earlier this year. From the opening scene, in which the author watches a man break down in front of a painting, and feels pangs of doubt about his own connection with his art, Lerner wrote with honesty and an indefatigable commitment to the search for artistic vision. It was a bildungsroman for this hyper-knowing, ironic and distracted generation.

Here, Lerner has broadened the scope, both geographically and thematically. The book covers the author's life after having published a critically praised small-press debut and receiving a big advance from a mainstream publisher (which he spends mostly on miscellaneous good deeds). It contains various metafictional tricks, two "superstorms", a residency in Marfa, Texas, and various drugs and literary soirees. The stories within stories don't quite cohere - indeed, this book would probably work much better if it were the same length as Atocha - but Lerner has remembered the cardinal rule of experimental fiction: be interesting, so that if the concept doesn't come off, the reader still enjoys herself.

A big publisher like FSG signing on an overtly experimental author inevitably means that the book will be read by people whose goals as readers are entirely at odds with the author's intentions. Thus, Goodreads has a lot of reviews complaining about the language, and deriding the novel's dialogue as pretentious. This misses the point by a mile. Lerner is first and foremost a poet, specifically, a poet who valorises the near-impenetrable thickets of John Ashberry. He has toned his language down for the sake of this novel, to make it more novel-like, but not much: there is little plot or characterisation. 10:04 is essentially a high concept examination of time and of modalities (alternative worlds - what philosophers would call "modal realism") in art and fiction, of the potential innate in our past and future selves, and the possibility of finding real collectivity - of transgressing the boundaries within our isolated, class-stratified communities.

I look back on the totaled city, and see it in the second-person plural. I know it is hard to understand. / I am with you, and I know how it is.


There is something Hegelian in Lerner's approach: abstracting the world to a high level, and then applying the results in alarmingly specific political ways. Late on in the book, a discussion with a grad student undergoing a serious nervous breakdown is reproduced in full, and the protagonist mulls on and agrees with most of the student's conspiracy theories. That the moon landings were faked, at least in theory, is an ongoing motif in another section. Lerner's book-self is open to many sinister views of the world, and one senses that the author himself is prepared to buy into all of them.

In a sense, then, 10:04 is about all of these conspiracy theories, as well as animal rights, environmentalist doomsday scenarios, and class warfare. It is about creativity and assisted reproduction and faked cancer. It is about hysterical authors and wasted advances and technological disconnections. Lerner is too canny, and too distracted, to be tied down to one thing, so he makes his novel about all of them, and how all may be true and false in their own way. Such wandering can be ephemeral and short on satisfying conclusions, but that is the nature of Mr. Lerner's restless, brilliant mind. It is a great pleasure to follow along with him.

Title: Leaving the Atocha Station
Author: Ben Lerner
My Review:
Most important thing about this book isn't its description of writing, but the description of writing it doesn't give, the one that emerges from its pages of frustration and creative block, into an engaging novel. Either way I promised myself I'd never write a novel, says Adam early on, and we must assume that this statement is basically autobiographical, is mocking us with Beckettian glee because the novel in front of us, despite its self-abnegation, is a very fine one. Adam has 'impostor syndrome', he believes he is an incompetent fraud, constantly downplaying his own poetry, all while throwing out off-the-cuff pearls about the purpose of literature and its relation to reality. What better metaphor for modern writing?

In a sense this book is an extended apology for not having the strength of its convictions. It says the book should have been here, were the author able to write. But in shitting out of the challenge to be sincere, Lerner is no worse off than any of our contemporary serious fiction writers, and in the jumbled notebooks of his non-novel lies an abundance of rich, thoughtful notes on the craft. In sum: this book is reflective of its time. If he wasn't so crippled by self-doubt about his writing, how could Ben Lerner hope to write about it?

Title: The Emerald Light in the Air
Author: Donald Antrim
My Review:
Antrim is a master of psychoanalysis, observing the secrets that we bury and pretend we are free of. In his world, no-one can escape the gravitational field of their past. Characters struggle against inertia, and those around them may briefly hold out hope for them, but ultimately they slide back into their old sorrows.

These are Raymond Carver stories, but told with complex, hyperenergetic language, like Seinfeld on the therapist's couch. Unhappy people stay unhappy. Beyond a haze of antidepressant meds and cocktail-party ennui, nothing really happens.

Title: The Verificationist
Author: Donald Antrim
My Review:
Antrim is the master of the casually bizarre. In crisp, fact-laden descriptions, he gives the reader a perfectly ordinary world scarred by just one or two total strokes of insanity, making his short books both archly comic and deeply unsettling. A genealogy of his influencers could include Charlie Kaufmann, Woodie Allen's neurotic monologues, and Kafka's Metamorphosis, but you don't really need to go past Donald Barthelme (Antrim discusses this in a wonderful retrospective by John Jeremiah Sullivan in last week's NYT). Antrim takes the mischevious surrealism of Barthelme's [b:Sixty Stories|118345|Sixty Stories|Donald Barthelme|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1327948558s/118345.jpg|1574240] and extends it with meticulous, lapidary prose and (in this case) a heavy dose of psychoanalytic tradition.

The plot of this short novel concerns an insecure psychiatrist convening a meeting of his colleagues at a local breakfast restaurant. Intimidated by their seemingly greater confidence, anxious over his unravelling marriage (and raising questions about his sexuality), he narrates the novel in tones of increasing hysteria (always, though, with witty and original language). The overbearing criticism of a father figure colleague, and the possibility of redemption glimpsed via a beautiful teenage waitress, bring him to some sort of critical decision point regarding his life. Saying any more about the plot would spoil it.

Going back to Kafka, what defines 'Kafkaesque' seems to be different to everyone, but to me it must include an oppressive yet genteel atmosphere: the suggestion of paranoia on the part of the protagonist. The uniquely Modern sensation of being out of the loop, unable to grow up and adjust to the exigencies of adult life, because the tools we were given no longer work. Confronted even by ordinary situations - choosing between eggs or pancake at a diner, say - the character feels alienated and inadequate. By this measure, The Verificationist positively oozes Kafka's vapors.

Most of my reading this year has been characterised by wild slashes at the overgrowth of world and experimental literature I have yet to cover, so it speaks to the weird, energetic appeal that Antrim casts that I was drawn to read another of his books just a month after reading his first, Elect Mr Robinson For A Better World. (He has a new book out, but I'm not made of money.) I wasn't disappointed.

Title: Elect Mr. Robinson for a Better World
Author: Donald Antrim
My Review: A portrait of a normal, middle American town blighted with lunatic episodes of violence, which everyone accepts as ordinary. The narrative voice is restrained, erudite, exact, but also echoes with a taut anxiety reminiscent of Charlie Kaufmann's best films (say Being John Malkovich and the first half of Adaptation). Barthelme's influence is clear; Antrim may be a little funnier, a little more caustic, a little more unhinged. Like his protagonist, he's willing to take the joke all the way to its (horrifically violent) conclusion.

Title: The Things They Carried
Author: Tim O'Brien
My Review: Quietly devastating, elegant, controlled. If I was a person who cried I would have cried - I had the tightness in my chest associated with receiving terrible news. I usually avoid war literature and films because though you know in advance what they have to tell you, the telling, when executed without excess smarm or sentimentality, will reliably destroy you, puncturing the bubble of boring calm which we inhabit. The total inhumanity and inexplicability of war doesn't make any more sense at a (temporal/spatial) remove.

Title: Gilead
Author: Marilynne Robinson
My Review: My first impressions reminded me of Terrence Malick's films, or of Cormac McCarthy, with the rich prosody of wide open, lonely prairie spaces that almost compel one to introspection and wonder. But, unhitched from commitments to narrative, Gilead gradually becomes a meditation on belief, forgivenesss, and the nature of grace, as its gentle narrator ruminates on the setbacks life has dealt him and his community, and what he may impart to the next generation. Plenty of Biblical quotes and references to theologians, if that's your jam; for most, the spine-tingling moments of grace Robinson finds in children playing or in the taste of stale, ashy biscuit, will linger the most. There were stretches where I struggled to concentrate, but I felt as that were a shortcoming in me and not the book. A favourite of both my grandmother and Barack Obama.

Title: Tender Is the Night
Author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
My Review:
"Most of us have a favourite, a heroic period in our lives..."

I've been going through Whit Stillman's (very small) cinematic ouevre over the last few weeks, which mostly overlapped my reading of this novel. Fitzgerald's novels appeal to me for some of the reasons for which I love Stillman's films (witty dialogue, worldliness, a soupçon of expensive liberal arts education) but not others (the characters are morally repugnant, self-destructive, and locked on a trajectory of abject failure). Not having read any of the flood of F.-Scott-and-Zelda bios that have come out lately, I couldn't say how closely this hews to the author's life, but he clearly took a dim view of how he'd made out.

The psychiatric motif is fascinating: many of the women take on infantilised roles, be it Rosemary's hypersexuality (her first film billing is in Daddy's Girl), the manipulative "Baby" Warren, and Nicole's incestuous relationship with her father.

An unrelentingly bleak tale of awful people whose lives, at first glamorous and cosmopolitan, spin out into disgrace, makes for grim reading, as you'd expect, though it's punctuated here and there with the kind of devastating sentences that cause you to put down the book and stare at the wall, which I suppose on some level is why many of us read.

Title: Doing Our Own Thing: The Degradation of Language and Music and Why We Should, Like, Care
Author: John McWhorter

Title: Lucky Jim
Author: Kingsley Amis
My Review: Satire of crusty upper class British people, who are ultimately outfoxed by the hero, an affable drunk. More amusing than hilarious. I'm sure I get less of a kick out of this than its original readers, for whom the establishment figures herein lampooned were still the gatekeepers of the British intellegentsia. I listened to the Book Fight! podcast after reading - I was happy that they touched on the book's problematic portrayal of women (all of whom are bitchy and/or hysterical, except for the hot one). Not unenjoyable, but not essential either.

Title: Rabbit, Run (Rabbit Angstrom #1)
Author: John Updike
My Review:
On the one hand, this is longer and looser than it needs to be and overly in love with awkward, overwritten "literary" style, and the protagonist's solpsistic self-obsession is infuriating. It's also incredibly moving in parts: the clumsy, unhappy sex scenes are superbly evoked, and in general the realist commitments of the novelist to open a window into actual person's head come off really well. Rabbit is a perfect name for someone consumed by guilt, listlessness, angst; constantly overshadowed by the feeling that "the good life is out there somewhere", but stymied at every turn by the needs of other people to be treated as people. (Updike intended it as an adult antidote to the whimsy of [b:On the Road|70401|On the Road|Jack Kerouac|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1413588576s/70401.jpg|1701188]). "Harry" means "to disturb or annoy". Harry ANGSTrom, or Rabbit - did Eminem grasp all of the Kierkegaardian nuances? The last couple of hours of the audiobook after [I won't spoil it] left me with a knot in my stomach; a good thing, I think, but not something that would make we want to revisit this.

Co-incidentally, I stumbled upon this this morning.

Title: The Quick and the Dead
Author: Joy Williams
My Review:
The fifth-highest community review of this book on Goodreads is by a gentleman who awarded it one star, alluding to its "lack of plot" and comparing it unfavourably to "Dan Brown's Robert Langdon series". I don't generally like to belittle other people's opinions, or to play the intellectual snobbery game, so I'll just note that the reader in question wasn't the target audience for this book, and might more profitably be directed toward a different section of the library altogether. But a wider statement about society on the whole being not quite clever enough, or reflective enough, to appreciate Joy Williams's caustic genius, wouldn't be out of place when reviewing a book sizzling with barely tamped down misanthropic rage.

At heart, this is something like an environmentalist novel, although its bleak vision doesn't really allow for messages of any type. It simply mirrors an America full of fast-food chains and tchotchkas, addicted to television and oblivious to death. It sprawls over natural habitats with tarmac and air-conditioning, placing its non-human victims in abattoirs, shelters or museums, while congratulating itself for its sophistication, drunk with venal stupidity. Ms. Williams's cool, precise prose combines Don DeLillo's alien-like coldness with Hunter S. Thompson's righteous anger.

The book's major characters are all teenage girls who have suffered tragedy. Alice, orphaned, lives with her slightly batty grandparents. Corvus's parents have drowned. Annabel has recently lost her mother in a car crash, and her father (the focus of the book's wittiest and most merciless scenes) is haunted by his late wife's ghost, who takes pleasure in running him down and ridiculing his budding romance with his gardener, Donald. In another side plot, an eight-year-old girl named Emily Bliss Pickless (sic) accidentally blows off her mother's boyfriend's genitals (and buries them) and befriends a billionaire.

Plot exposition seems like a waste of time here, though: what makes this book so great is how funny it is, and its trenchant, subtle intelligence. Classical references abound. Two cryptic passages begin parts one and three, providing plenty of symbolism for those keen to look deeper. Every page flows with a patter of sparkling one-liners which probe through modern day humanity's delusions of success, and skewer the bromides which make us feel we are special, kind gifts to this planet.

An aide at a retirement home for the especially decrepit, Nurse Daisy, encapsulates the book's theme in her stilted, oracular way:

“It’s better to be dumb,” the nurse said, “than to speak from a heart that’s all darkness and distraction. I’m agreeing with you. I suppose we should go in. Are you ready to enter our little charnel community, not as docent or guide but as a living member? Do you vow to keep your wits among the witless? Do you commit yourself to pondering ceaselessly the uselessness of caring, the uselessness of love, that great reality for which all else must be abandoned?”

Title: The Adventures of Augie March
Author: Saul Bellow
My Review:
What is at the center now? At the moment, neither art nor science but mankind determining, in confusion and obscurity, whether it will endure or go under. The whole species - everybody - has gotten into the act. At such a time it is essential to lighten ourselves, to dump encumbrances, including the encumbrances of education and all organized platitudes, to make judgments of our own, to perform acts of our own...

With increasing frequency I dismiss as merely respectable opinions I have long held - or thought I held - and try to discern what I have really lived by, and what others live by...Our very vices, our mutilations, show how rich we are in thought and culture. How much we know. How much we even feel.


That's from Bellow's Nobel speech. A writer's writer who thinks deeply about his craft and is steeped in the Classical tradition, he represents the archetypal Dead White Guy from whose shadow everybody wants to escape - although we end up grappling with the same problems in different ways, which is the essence of this speech (aimed in its time at Robbe-Grillet's "Nouveau Roman").

I listened to an audiobook of this over a few weeks. A lot of the time I felt as if the plot had hit a dead end - it's episodic, rather than a Freytagian pyramid. I guess there's something Homeric in that, and in Bellow's attempt to distill the American experience into one man's story, as stressed in his opening and closing lines ("I'm an American, Chicago born...Columbus too thought he was a flop, probably, when they sent him back in chains. Which didn’t prove there was no America”.) Bellow wasn't born an American, and I've never even visited there. Is that relevant?

Ultimately this is an attempt to prove the lasting relevance of the old-fashioned novel, going back to the pre-Realist tradition of the picaresque novel and even the Odyssey. In the ideosyncratic U Chicago tradition, Bellow is convinced that the classic books contain as good an answer that we'll get to the great questions of life, and literary innovation be damned. This is his attempt to recreate one of those Great Books: it's uneven, but monumental, visionary, filled with monologues of chest-thumping patrician loftiness. It didn't quite work for me, but I certainly wouldn't write it off just because of that.

Title: A Girl Is a Half-formed Thing
Author: Eimear McBride

Title: The Attic (Serbian Literature)
Author: Danilo Kiš
My Review: A 20-something would-be intellectual hangs out with his philosophically-minded bro and falls in love with a disappearing girl ("Eurydice" to his code name "Orpheus", in one of many heavy-handed bits of signalling). Sort of a scattered, hipster Bildungsroman, though one replete with pomo flourishes that throw the narrative out of kilter (a dream-like trip to a "Bay of Dolphins", a four-freakin'-page quote from [b:The Magic Mountain|88077|The Magic Mountain|Thomas Mann|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1403170928s/88077.jpg|647489] in French). It's an engaging, and occasionally beautiful, read, but by trying too hard to be cool, Kiš gives up the possibility of making a real creative breakthrough. He comes glowingly blurbed by William Gass and Susan Sontag, though, so I should probably get around at some point to his more mature work.

Title: Artful
Author: Ali Smith
Bookshelves: experimental, essays, art-aesthetics-culture, classics, contemporary, poetry
Bookshelves with positions: experimental (#13), essays (#8), art-aesthetics-culture (#8), classics (#2), contemporary (#25), poetry (#17)
My Review: Bold, fascinating blend of short story, poem and literary essay, adapting a Comp Lit lecture into a meditation on loss and the power of art. The ubiquity of references - down to genealogies of quotes and names of translators - detracts a little from the power of the book, which anyway feels a little slight, and a little too dependent on the ideas of others. But this is still an unusual and powerful work.

Author: Coggan Philip

Author: Michael Walzer

Title: New Year's: Nathaniel P. as Seen Through the Eyes of His Friend Aurit
Author: Adelle Waldman

Title: New Year's: Nathaniel P. as Seen Through the Eyes of His Friend Aurit
Author: Adelle Waldman

Title: The Love Affairs of Nathaniel P.
Author: Adelle Waldman
My Review:
Thoughtful, funny and laced with pith, this book at once captures the zeitgeist - for a certain hypereducated, Bohemian, Brooklynite set - and lays out the current state of the War of the Sexes. Waldman does uncannily well to put herself in the mind of a man, committed to egalitarian liberalism, but secretly doubtful about the intellectual capacities of the women he dates.

Nate Piven is a narcissist, increasingly self-justifying and unlikable as the book progresses. But most of his foibles and insecurities will be recognisable to any reader below a certain age. A few narrative weaknesses - which guy spends so much time with his gal pal discussing his dating life? - do not mar the book's main charms: literary wit, a thoroughly contemporary sensibility, and a poignant awareness of the fear of loneliness hidden deep within us.

Title: The Poetics of Space
Author: Gaston Bachelard
Additional Authors: Maria Jolas, Étienne Gilson, John R. Stilgoe
My Review:
Bachelard was something of a polymath who began his career as a postman, taught himself physics and chemistry, and then became a philosophy professor at the Sorbonne. His thinking is suitably eclectic. Quite simply, this book purports to be a work of philosophy (apparently one of phenomenology, though its metaphysics owe a far greater debt to Bergson than to Husserl or Brentano), but is best described as a meditation on poetry, and the connection between language and private spaces.

The influence of Jung's psychoanalysis looms over this book, but Bachelard believes that psychoanalytical thought, with its rigid symbolism, owns title to the world of dreams - while rationalism can explain the world of waking thought. It is in reverie or daydream, then, that he finds space for his phenomenology, describing the dimly felt sensations of intimacy we connect with the structures surrounding us. There are many passages of lyrical beauty - describing the formation of a snail shell, or meditating on a blade of grass. Bachelard attempts to transcend the inside/outside spatial distinction, cryptically paraphrasing Jaspers in the brief final chapter: "Dasein ist rund" (Being is round).

Bachelard's intention, then, is to create a poetics of metaphysics, abandoning logical preconceptions and prioritising experience: the attic, the nest, a blade of grass, a forest. He sees in the poetic imagination the best expression of this feeling, and hence a worthy fulcrum for a new description of environment. Sadly, the inherent subjectivity of such an endeavour makes for difficult, often unrewarding, reading.

Title: The Recognitions
Author: William Gaddis
My Review:
[What follows is a very roughly edited presentation of the notes I took as I drew towards the end of this book.]

What is this book about?

Let's start with Faust - since it's essentially an extended retelling of it, down to the Mephistophelean Recktall Brown's black poodle. The title is a nod to Goethe's third century source material - though you can read a lot more into it, related to the novel's themes of forgery and truth in art.

The chaotic party scenes - disorientating jumbles of unattributed, often hilarious, dialogue - take the place of the difficult escapades of Part II of Faust. (I often needed the online plot summaries to get a handle on what was going on.)

Prominent in the pantheon of post-WWII American experimentalists (Barth, Barthelme, Coover) Gaddis most brings to mind Thomas Pynchon - his interests (art history, religious history, literary arcana) narrower, but his mind no less compendious. At the heart of the book lie multiple themes: forgery, the nature of reality, idealism, the value and purpose of art, humanism, authenticity vs the search for (often elusive or fake) religious experience. This sounds heavy, but it's also full of humour; a satire of values always current in art/lit circles and broader society: pseudoliterary pretentiousness, religious hypocrisy, the commodification of culture.

This helped me understand the term Künstlerroman, and why the average reader would care about an artist's struggles. Because what defines an artist's maturation isn't just the dole, weed-smoking, and rejection letters: it's the struggle to produce art that is sincere and valuable, the battle against cynicism, pretension, nihilism, anxiety, materialism - to find a voice that is your own, and that expresses something true. That's a part of anyone's growing up. And of course there is a world behind this in decay, caught between the mixed-up and often hypocritical Western religious tradition - and on the other side the glitzy, homogenising effects of American pop culture.

P.S. I don't feel as if I've done a very good job describing this mammoth, very difficult novel. But I read Jonathan's Franzen compendious New Yorker essay yesterday, which does that job pretty damn well.

P.P.S. Gaddis' Paris Review interview helped understand what exactly he was trying to accomplish. After some thought, I still don't really get his statement about "thank God there was the gold to fake" being the most important line in the book. Always more to learn, I guess.

Title: JR
Author: William Gaddis
My Review:
Otto in The Recognitions is ostensibly Gaddis's cameo in the story, but it's obvious that Wyatt Gwynn is who the author really pictures himself as. Besides for the shared initials (and just being the main character in the book), Wyatt's metaphysical journey is the central struggle present in Gaddis's work - between faith, aesthetic beauty and the pursuit of truth on the one hand, and the materialism and cynicism of society on the other, which permeates the intellectual and artistic scene as much as it does society at large. It is the individual's painful struggle to be authentic and resolve his expansive vision onto a canvas of physical finitude.

Likewise in JR, the "Gaddis" character is probably Gibbs, and there are plenty of cheeky references to the blank reception that Recognitions received (its title endlessly anagrammed into throwaway books printed to sell ad space and immediately pulped). But in fact it is the frustrated creative Bast with whom the writer's (and reader's) sympathies lie, as he struggles to work in between the ceaseless pressures of the capitalist Antichrist JR - uncouth, impatient, resentful, with a totally deaf ear to artistic value . In the first novel is the erudite, eccentric Harvard dropout, searching for truth while surrounded by artsy phonies; the second one is a retelling of the same story by a frustrated man who has spent two decades as a wage slave. (Gaddis said in his Paris Review interview that he'd half-expected to get the Nobel Prize after The Recognitions came out.) And the relentless, headache-inducing babble of hypercapitalism is his new perception of the world as petty, ignorant and unmoored from all sense of humanism.

I'm a card-carrying humanist and egalitarian, but Gaddis's angry brilliance militates towards a certain measure of elitism. Is his portrayal of Rhoda, the sulky teenage hippy, really so far off the mark in spoofing the counterculture generation? (The scene where she cannot believe that Bast, who avers to being a musician, doesn't have weed on him, is a priceless microcosm of Gaddis's high culture/low culture dichotomy.) In turning to the cult of the individual, allowing self-help and positive psychology to legitimise our weaknesses, JR suggests that we lost sight of the rigor and seriousness required for real intellectual ambition. Far from achieving freedom, we have replaced the medieval Gods and masters with new capitalist overlords, who manipulate our lack of direction and desire to distinguish ourselves, to achieve money and power. (JR, who had my sympathy in the beginning of the novel but gradually evolves into a monster, is unapologetic about his disdain for "dumb teachers" and other people with goals that don't include the accumulation of capital.)

It's reductive to call JR a "satire of capitalism". With its unending talk-stream and chaotic, overlapping storyline, it's an encapsulation of modern urbanism, a phenomenology of the vulgar, and a striking attempt to visualise on the page the transformation that soulless greed is affecting in American society. At the same time, through the character of Bast, Gaddis is obliquely returning to his theme of the kunstlerroman, portraying the frustrated aesthete in an ever grimmer milieu of spiritual dullness. Almost forty years on, the prognosis hardly seems brighter.

Title: The Mezzanine
Author: Nicholson Baker
My Review: An absorbing description of a lunch break, packed with dazzling, brilliant divergences - often via footnotes - analysing the technological wizardry that makes up modern life, with a mathematician's brain and a child's wonder.

Title: The Mezzanine
Author: Nicholson Baker
My Review: An absorbing description of a lunch break, packed with dazzling, brilliant divergences - often via footnotes - analysing the technological wizardry that makes up modern life, with a mathematician's brain and a child's wonder.

Title: Vox
Author: Nicholson Baker
My Review: Hilarious, eloquent, perfectly observed. Nicholson Baker is the quotidian DFW, focusing nthe same manic energy on the tiniest minutiae of modern life.

Title: Vox
Author: Nicholson Baker
My Review: Hilarious, eloquent, perfectly observed. Nicholson Baker is the quotidian DFW, focusing nthe same manic energy on the tiniest minutiae of modern life.

Title: The Marbled Swarm
Author: Dennis Cooper
My Review:
It wouldn't be correct to say I detested this book: that's the reaction that the author is going for, whereas in fact I was too bored to muster any type of strong feeling at all. Mistaking the use of cannibalism, kiddy rape and incest for some type of cooler-than-thou nihilist credo, and sophomoric pretension for eloquence (the titular "marbled swarm"), this book is something like a French rewrite of Less Than Zero - except stripped of the wit, intelligence, self-awareness and satirical vigor that made that book so worth reading.

I feel uncool posting this, because all of my hip writerly friends think this book is the shit...but, well, yeah.

Title: Snow White
Author: Donald Barthelme
My Review:
Flummery, numen, blague. Cess, braw, azote. Even the vocabulary in Barthelme's challenging post-modern fairy tale seems alien, and that's just the beginning of it. The reader is confronted with narrative discontinuity, private soliloquies, and even a quiz on the story. The fourth wall barely exists.

This book may make you dizzy. It may utterly confuse you. It is full of energy and creativity, and if pomo puzzling (and occasional posturing) doesn't drive you mad, you should go read it.

Title: Spanking the Maid
Author: Robert Coover
My Review: Linguistic splendour spread over a dark, sadomasochistic tableau. Every time this simple dreamlike story recurs, like Charlie Brown kicking the bull pizzle, some details are distilled into painful clarity, while others fade away. Puns and verbal flourishes are privileged; form over function. This is fiction for the world of dreams.

Title: Spanking the Maid
Author: Robert Coover

Title: Briar Rose
Author: Robert Coover
My Review: Just like Barthelme's [b:Snow White|118349|Snow White|Donald Barthelme|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1348249337s/118349.jpg|1393624], Coover takes a wry angle on fairy tale conventions. Filled with infanticide, forced cannibalism, and jealous anger, this isn't the Disney Sleeping Beauty. The story never really occurs: each page, just about, is a fresh tale, a thread spun by the wicked (good?) fairy keeping the princess (Rose) asleep. Metafiction in its purest manifestation, this book reflexively looks back at itself, and at all fiction, with the liberated archness of merry PoMo pranksters.

Title: Briar Rose
Author: Robert Coover

Title: Speedboat (NYRB Classics)
Author: Renata Adler
My Review: It's all witty and mordant and formidably well-read, all while nothing happens. There are apparently post-structuralist conceits at play here (Adler studied Philosophy at the Sorbonne, and has degrees from Harvard and Yale) - an attempt to eliminate plot from the novel, a sort of stream-of-the-author's-consciousness. Adler has never really elaborated on her method, though, and I'm not smart enough to get it on my own.

Title: Nothing: A Portrait of Insomnia
Author: Blake Butler
My Review: Part memoir and part history of insomnia, this surprising and exciting book reads emphatically like neither. Blake Butler's trademark prose coheres the parts into a different being altogether, pulling from the Critical Theorists he obviously reveres (Deleuze especially, but also Sartre, Levinas, Nancy and too many others to list) to make his own memories synecdochal of America's. Sentences stretch out, often over pages, filled with original constructions and myriad pop culture references. Sometimes a book as jumbled as this can make one wish the editor had been less indulgent. But in this case it mostly comes off; the originality is always clear - though the intent, at times, less so.

Title: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
Author: Dave Eggers

Title: Eating Animals
Author: Jonathan Safran Foer
My Review:
1. "You wouldn't eat a dog, so why can you eat a pig?" is one of the central moral arguments directed in this book against eating animals. In ethics, as in life, appeals to rationality can open a slippery pathway: why, indeed, should we not eat dogs? Many cultures do? Why should we not, after careful preparation, eat dead people, a la Jonathan Swift? What we are led to is that there are simply cultural taboos which prevent us from eating certain animals but allow us to eat others. Not particularly rational, but a social construct which facilitates life on this planet.

2. Another argument forwarded by Safran-Foer is the comparison to slavery, once accepted but now reviled. But slavery was never as integral a part of our humanity as eating meat, nor as widely practiced. There may really be a time, several generations from now, when the whole world arises and switches to veganism, but it will not be because it is as clearly evil as forced slave labour.

3. Meat-eating is common in nature, but humans are uniquely capable of moral agency, in addition to being omnivores capable of subsisting on vegetation alone. But surely this begs the moral question. And the tendency of vegetarians and vegans to supplement their diet with vitamins (leaving out the tendency to recreate animal products with soya and tofu) shows the importance of meat in our diets and culture.

4. The bulk of this book, however, is directed at factory farming, and in this it is hard for any ethical human being to disagree with the author. The modern animal slaughter industry is a perversion and perhaps the greatest mass crime being committed in the West today. A response to that, legislatively and economically, seems imperative.

5. But how the individual does that is a slightly greyer issue. One way is to reduce or eliminate factory meat consumption, while supporting ethical farms - an option I have opted for. Another is to lobby, start protests, write letters, join PETA. And so on.

6. There is so much suffering in the world that one is sometimes overwhelmed by it. One gets a kind of moral fatigue - am I culpable for baby piglets clubbed or electrocuted to death, dolphins caught in hooks, child soldiers, mass murders in Darfur? Where does it end? It seems impossible to react to it all.

7. Jonathan Safran-Foer is a writer I like, who moved far out of his comfort zone to write a moving book about an issue he is passionate about. Occasionally one feels under siege by the sheer number of different arguments he rustles up to support vegetarianism - moral, religious, social, environmental, health-related. One is tempted to defend oneself, to try and justify meat-eating so that one feels like less bad a person. But that is to mistake collective guilt for individual.

8. I'm not attempting to defend the culture of eating animals, exactly. I fully agree (even from before I came into this book) that we as a species cannot sustain our current level of meat consumption. Hopefully, legislative and cultural changes will occur, and the current insanity of the industry will be relegated to being yet another great historical shame. But I still believe in the basic morality of eating meat, just in a vastly different way to how it is done now. There are traces of that attitude in this book, and I hope that my conclusion is one that Safran-Foer would be okay with.

In ethics, as in life, appeals to rationality can open a slippery pathway: why, indeed, should we not eat dogs? Many cultures do? Why should we not, after careful preparation, eat dead people, a la Jonathan Swift? What we are led to is that there are simply cultural taboos which prevent us from eating certain animals but allow us to eat others. Not particularly rational, but a social construct which facilitates life on this planet.

2. Another argument forwarded by Safran-Foer is the comparison to slavery, once accepted but now reviled. But slavery was never as integral a part of our humanity as eating meat, nor as widely practiced. There may really be a time, several generations from now, when the whole world arises and switches to veganism, but it will not be because it is as clearly evil as forced slave labour.

3. Meat-eating is common in nature, but humans are uniquely capable of moral agency, in addition to being omnivores capable of subsisting on vegetation alone. But surely this begs the moral question. And the tendency of vegetarians and vegans to supplement their diet with vitamins (leaving out the tendency to recreate animal products with soya and tofu) shows the importance of meat in our diets and culture.

4. The bulk of this book, however, is directed at factory farming, and in this it is hard for any ethical human being to disagree with the author. The modern animal slaughter industry is a perversion and perhaps the greatest mass crime being committed in the West today. A response to that, legislatively and economically, seems imperative.

5. But how the individual does that is a slightly greyer issue. One way is to reduce or eliminate factory meat consumption, while supporting ethical farms - an option I have opted for. Another is to lobby, start protests, write letters, join PETA. And so on.

6. There is so much suffering in the world that one is sometimes overwhelmed by it. One gets a kind of moral fatigue - am I culpable for baby piglets clubbed or electrocuted to death, dolphins caught in hooks, child soldiers, mass murders in Darfur? Where does it end? It seems impossible to react to it all.

7. Jonathan Safran-Foer is a writer I like, who moved far out of his comfort zone to write a moving book about an issue he is passionate about. Occasionally one feels under siege by the sheer number of different arguments he rustles up to support vegetarianism - moral, religious, social, environmental, health-related. One is tempted to defend oneself, to try and justify meat-eating so that one feels like less bad a person. But that is to mistake collective guilt for individual.

8. I'm not attempting to defend the culture of eating animals, exactly. I fully agree (even from before I came into this book) that we as a species cannot sustain our current level of meat consumption. Hopefully, legislative and cultural changes will occur, and the current insanity of the industry will be relegated to being yet another great historical shame. But I still believe in the basic morality of eating meat, just in a vastly different way to how it is done now. There are traces of that attitude in this book, and I hope that my conclusion is one that Safran-Foer would be okay with.

Title: Birds of America
Author: Lorrie Moore
My Review:
Unlike good LPs, good short story collections usually save the best for last, unless that's something I just made up. Lorrie Moore starts off Birds of America really strongly and just gets better, culminating in the penultimate story, which has kind of a long title which eludes me at the present mo, but it involves the words 'Peed Onk'. This turns out to be short for Paediatric Oncology, so obviously this is not a cheerful or uplifting story.

Nor are any of the stories, which is fine, because Lorrie Moore is the great chronicler of 'quiet desperation', of lives lived poorly by unremarkable (but well-educated) people, seeking assiduously for greater order and purpose in their lives. In the aforementioned story, one line stuck out for me, though it isn't one of the many richly quotable one-liners that pepper this book:

[E]ndings as stiff and loopy as carpenter's lace, crisp and empty as lettuce, reticulate as a net - ah, words.


Ah, words! Though her fine-grained, lapidary prose is so good, and her sense of humor so dry and likable, what defines this book for me is its characters, true to life, hopeful, anxious, sad, sometimes, but always completely real.

The best fiction helps us understand ourselves and how we live today, and by that standard this book is a valuable component in - to use one more music metaphor - the Adult Contemporary canon.

Title: Although of Course You End Up Becoming Yourself: A Road Trip with David Foster Wallace
Author: David Lipsky
My Review: I've hit a rough patch in Infinite Jest, so I picked this up in the meantime. The book, transcribed from a five day trip with Wallace during his IJ publicity tour, contains the conversational, witty David Foster Wallace of his essays (and the first part of Infinite Jest), and gives a lot of insight into what's going on the knottier parts of David Foster Wallace (Broom of the System, the rest of Infinite Jest). It feels like an accurate portrayal of how he was: brilliant, self-conscious, excited by life, worried about our society, set on an unstoppable trajectory towards great fame and suicidal despair.

Title: The Goldfinch
Author: Donna Tartt
My Review:
1. Too long
2. There's a decent monologue at the end about the value and immortality of beauty.
3. Donna Tartt's prose is workmanlike but not terribly interesting, so when the plot slows down, you have to wonder, what exactly is the point?
4. It is a really nice painting.
5. Protagonist Theo's high-pitched anxiety can really start to grate after the first six hundred pages. Couldn't we mix things up a bit? Some humor? Whimsy? Weltschmerz?
6. I thought the Secret History was pretty entertaining, and just smart enough to elevate it above pure escapism. So is this, come to think of it - but I just stopped caring at a certain point and prayed it would end.
7. Did I mention it's too long?

Title: The Secret History
Author: Donna Tartt
My Review: Erudite, exciting and superbly crafted novel about six Classics majors whose love of Greek leads them to murder and mayhem. The first half is unputdownable; the second half slows down a little, but deepens the character sketches of the uniquely memorable collegiate protagonists.

Title: The Secret History
Author: Donna Tartt
My Review: Erudite, exciting and superbly crafted novel about six Classics majors whose love of Greek leads them to murder and mayhem. The first half is unputdownable; the second half slows down a little, but deepens the character sketches of the uniquely memorable collegiate protagonists.

Title: All the Sad Young Literary Men
Author: Keith Gessen
My Review:
A novel pretty much designed for me: all of the characters (who are in fact one; thinly disguised autobiographical iterations whom I still had difficulty telling apart by the book's end) are solipsistic, awkward, obsessively bookish young white males who intersperse dating failures and study of obscure history/economics/politics with angst about their direction in life. And in that respect it works. I get a kick out of vicariously living my ideated Brooklyn lifestyle of lit parties, cheap theatre and foreign film, unironic discussion of Marxism, and the Indian summer of grad school in the humanities.

Still, Gessen - a founding editor of the soi-disant reincarnation of the Partisan Review, n + 1 - writes like the person he is: an enormously overeducated social critic and Russian history expert, and not a fiction writer. A natural pairing to this is last year's [b:The Love Affairs of Nathaniel P.|16045140|The Love Affairs of Nathaniel P.|Adelle Waldman|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1361026301s/16045140.jpg|21823357], which wears its literary and intellectual references much more lightly, and passes on the momentum conserved into character building and plot. There are only a number of times that a protagonist can compare his relationship to the Menshevik revolutionaries before the reader's patience wanes.

In brief: three young men endure conflict about their love lives, a dissertation and the defence thereof, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, being a young writer, and the Bush administration. Paper-thin references to real life people (Noam Chomsky, Al Gore and his daughter, Saul Bellow oops, apparently someone called Lee Siegel) and newspapers (Dissent, The "so-called liberal" New Republic) abound. There isn't much else to it. If you're interested in this scene and these types of people, then you'll probably be pleased with this book. Which I was.

Title: Dept. of Speculation
Author: Jenny Offill
My Review: Flaky, neurasthenic, slightly rambling, confession novel. Not for everyone.

Title: Tampa
Author: Alissa Nutting
My Review: Fun, filthy, fascinating portrayal of a sociopathic nymphomaniac who becomes a middle-school teacher solely to prey on fourteen-year-old boys - who are no match for her, an insatiable blonde knockout. It's a fun read but not a deep one, and the comparisons to Nabokov - one of the greatest English-language prose stylists of all time - are superfluous and mean. Loosely based on a true story.

Title: Illuminations: Essays and Reflections
Author: Walter Benjamin
Additional Authors: Hannah Arendt, Harry Zohn, Leon Wieseltier
My Review:
I'd lie if I said that I understood more than - charitably - fifty percent of these essays. Besides for the mountains of literary references and the oblique angles from which Benjamin approaches his subjects, his languid, flâneur-like writing makes it difficult to follow his train of thought. Still, the beauty of such writing, and the tendency toward hyperbole so characteristic of the Frankfurt School, have no doubt played a great role in Benjamin's reputation as a critic.

These essays, selected by Hannah Arendt, focus on a number of Modernist writers (Proust, Kafka, Baudelaire, Leskov [whom I hadn't heard of], Brecht) and their approach to society. As a Marxist, Benjamin saw the cultural as tightly embedded in the political - as he concludes the most best-known essay in the book, The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction, Fascism seeks to make the aesthetic political (glorifying war and destruction), and Communism must respond by politicising the aesthetic. Thus he sees the decline of the culture of storytelling as symptomatic of the increasing demands on our time placed by industrialisation and urbanisation. Boredom, the prime condition for storytelling, no longer exists ("Reflections on the Work of Nikolai Leskov"). In another essay, he recalls Poe's and Baudelaire's respective takes on an imagined crowd scene, both regarding with growing horror the single-minded intensity of the crowd, and their utter alienation (in the Marxist sense) from each other and themselves ("On Some Motifs in Baudelaire").

Benjamin is fascinated by Proust, focusing on the Bergsonian metaphysics underpinning In Search of Lost Time. From what I understand of Bergson's philosophy, he claims that only by ignoring our subjective experience of time and connecting to the atemporal durée can we transcend causality and experience true freedom. Thus Proust searches for his childhood memories, attempting to restore his unadulterated youthful happiness through mental effort. Perhaps it is not a stretch to see Benjamin politicising this thought, seeing society as undergoing a similar transformation through the overthrow of the bourgeois societal status quo and the return to the more authentic state of nature.

The other essays focus on some literary trends with remarkable prescience. One is a deep reading of Kafka's absurdism, and its relation to Jewish culture (in 1940, the year of Benjamin's death, Kafka was still a little-known figure, at least in the English-speaking world). A shorter essay describing Brecht's idea of the Epic Theatre (stripped of the attempt at realism, and full of meta-theatrical devices to confuse and startle the audience) presages Tom Stoppard, Samuel Beckett, and countless art films. The final essay consists of some rather Gnomic statements on Hegel's Philosophy of History.

Contrary to its subtitle, this book is rather more one of "Reflections", and less one of "Essays", in the Montaignian sense. Benjamin swirls his brush into society, politics, and art, and teases out the gossamer threads connecting artistic creation and social change. In the finest spirit of Modernism, he delves into the unconscious, seeking to understand the changes we have wrought, the ills in our society, and the ephemeral presence of beauty amongst cruelty and dehumanisation. Sadly, he could not escape the march of that inhumanity, which was close on his heels at the time that he took his own life.

Title: The Girl in the Flammable Skirt
Author: Aimee Bender
My Review:
I'll start with the positive: people always seem to notice when an author writes about sex badly, so it's only fair that credit be given to Aimee Bender for writing sex really, really, well. This collection of quirky short stories positively sweats, pants and drips with cumulated sexual activity, and it never becomes dull or clichéd. There is a rhythm in the writing that lends itself well to powerful emotions, and the desire to use sex against them as a palliative or antidepressant. Thus when it comes, it feels natural, unfeigned, human and yes, kind of sexy (James Salter, take note). And like a good lover, Bender knows to end her stories with a little bit of mystery, always leaving us wanting more.

Strong emotions are very much the motif of this thin book, whose other narrative device is the ubiquitously supernatural. Allowing magic to signify roiling inner tension allows the young heroines to affect hip dispositions of apathy reminiscent of (recently shamed) Tao Lin - but make no mistake, here lies none of the aforementioned's dour neurasthenia. These characters - with dying fathers, wounded veteran husbands, noncommital boyfriends - feel deeply. And it is their very sensitivity which makes it difficult for me to take these stories seriously as capital-F-fiction.

Literary snobbery has been on the radar lately, via an insipid Vanity Fair piece about [b:The Goldfinch|17333223|The Goldfinch|Donna Tartt|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1378710146s/17333223.jpg|24065147], and some Salon clickbait about (ugh) [b:The Fault in Our Stars|11870085|The Fault in Our Stars|John Green|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1360206420s/11870085.jpg|16827462]. I don't intend to rant about this here, because my opinion on it hasn't yet percolated into something halfway articulate. But my gut feeling is that there's a relationship between the complexity of a work of fiction, and the extent to which its characters can control their passions. Just like in real life, the difficulty and the pleasure of interaction with high-level fiction is in confronting the personae of real people, and growing to understand the artifice they have built around their infant selves. And the fascination, as well as the weakness, in YA fiction, is in how it deals with people on the cusp of adulthood, expected to function as grownups, yet constantly struggling to control raging hormones, which bubble up and explode, in an out of control shouting fit - or a fiery hand, or a set of premonitions, or a flammable skirt.

Title: Being and Nothingness
Author: Jean-Paul Sartre
Additional Authors: Hazel E. Barnes, Mary Warnock, Richard Eyre
My Review: Heidegger's difficult too - but he actually has brilliant content behind all the jargon.

Title: Nights in the Gardens of Brooklyn
Author: Harvey Swados

Title: Partial List of People to Bleach
Author: Gary Lutz

Title: The Posthumous Memoirs of Brás Cubas
Author: Machado de Assis

Title: The Castle
Author: Franz Kafka
My Review:
1)Kafka's really about mood, isn't he? The most "kafkaesque" feelings can be created even by his short stories (some only a few paragraphs long). Reading a whole novel full of such feelings - dread, frustration, alienation - can be wearysome, especially as many of the characters have a yen for logorrheic soliloquies (and I get that this is parody, but still, it's tough).
2)He's also about bureaucracy. Ever since reading about Max Weber's "iron cage", I've been thinking about this quintessentially modern device, at once efficient and stifling, reducing humanity to a bare numeric identity. No-one else reflects this with such perfect accuracy.
3)Here, David Foster Wallace wrote about the humor in Kafka, which is harder to see.
4)Winter is really the best time to read this book. You feel isolated and hopeless. Everybody you love will slowly realise that you are actually hopelessly unlikable and doomed, and will slowly drift away from you, abandoning you to your ineluctable fate.
5)This would incomplete without mention of the loaded gender politics in the novel, e.g. Frieda's manipulation of K. to get back into Klamm's good graces, and the disastrous result of Amalia's refusal of Sordini. Women, perhaps - objectified, servile, never feeling sufficiently loved - are the most identifiable characters in Kafka's universe. (Needless to say, his own tortured relationship with women and sex is well-documented.)
6)Another novel without an ending (and it always seems so weird when novelists end books mid-sentence. Did he just keel over, unable to finish the line? Or is it part of the intentional lack of resolution?) There seems no conceivable way a Kafka novel could end. Maybe his deathbed instructions to Max Brod are in a way an acknowledgment of this problem. The books will always be imperfect, because they present the world as a series of blind alleys, in which the only whole truth is the final one, long-awaited death which sweeps away all of the panic and anxiety which have come before it.

Title: The Beautiful: An Introduction to Psychological Aesthetics
Author: Vernon Lee
My Review:
Three men stop on a hike to look at the mountain behind them.

The engineer says, we could bring so much efficiency here with a highway and a cable-car.

The scientist says, the way this mountain must have been formed is fascinating.

The aesthete just gazes, annoyed at how the others are ruining his view with their talk.

Vernon Lee (nom de plume of Violet Paget, 1856-1935) uses this parable to open this book of aesthetical musings. My summary of it follows.

•Aesthetic appreciation is neither practical nor scientific.

•Beauty refers to an aspect of a thing, rather than the thing itself. (There are certain obvious metaphysical commitments here - in particular, Kant's Critique of Judgement casts a shadow over many of these ideas. Paget studied under Walter Pater, and was a product of the then-dominant British Idealism which Russell and Moore were about to smash. Russell's own semantic descriptivism inhabits a totally different universe from this.)

•Taking in colour is passive, but seeing shapes is active - it's how we order the colour.



•An 'aspect' is: sensations grouped into relations.

•Perceiving beauty takes memory, to hold together the various parts (i.e. the Kantian manifold of intuition). This accounts for things like symmetry and rhythm.

•Einfühlung (empathy) is the psychological effect whereby the lines of a drawing are invested with an ongoing, non-innate sort of character, which "irradiates even the most practical, the apparently least contemplative, moments and occupations of our existence".

•This empathy has a reiterative character, which gives ongoing attraction to beautiful aspects, and in its abstract nature accounts for its existing sub specie aeternitatis ("fond lover, never. never canst thou kiss" - Keats).



It is no poetic metaphor or metaphysical figment, but mere psychological fact, to say that if the interlacing circles and pentacles of a Byzantine floor-pattern absorb us in satisfied contemplation, this is because the modes of being with which we are obliged to invest them are such as we vainly seek, or experience only to lose, in our scattered or hustled existence.


•Though we don't yet know for sure, it's reasonable to assume that historically, creating shapes preceded representations of things.



•Representing things includes cubic shape and locomotion.

•The point of art is to make you look back to it, it serves not to convey information or utility (though it may do both) and be disposed of, but to be cherished and returned to.

•These rules are for art, but they can be applied to music and literature as well (harmony is three-dimensionality in music, plot is the same in literature).

•Often the hassle of having to respond to things as things, or the natural fluctuation of aesthetic interest,
detract from one's readiness for aesthetic contemplation.

A reader will...report days when his aesthetic appreciation has begun with the instant of entering a collection of pictures or statues, indeed sometimes pre-existed as he went through the streets noticing the unwonted charm of familiar objects, other days when enjoyment has come only after an effort of attention; others when, to paraphrase Coleridge, he saw, not felt, how beautiful things are; and finally...days upon which only shortcoming and absurdities have laid hold of his attention.


•For this reason, aesthetic appreciation can come much easier to one who deals with art daily, even for profit; yet often eludes and frustrates gallery-goers...



•...were it not for the transferability of aesthetic experience. Emotion can be attached to one art form, and transferred to another. It also explains why a critic's dismissal of an artwork can take away from one's own emotional perception of it.



I thought I'd add in a graph I drew which incorporates some of these ideas into a broader definition of art and the place of non-beautiful art.



PS I'm the first person to review this on here! Hopefully this will help to increase interest in Romantic Idealism, in a time in which Scientific Positivism chases down humanist ideals like a little boy with a butterfly net.

Title: Kafka Was the Rage: A Greenwich Village Memoir
Author: Anatole Broyard
My Review:
Greenwich Village in the 1940s, the East Village in the 1960s, Bed-Stuy today: the scene may have drifted, but the mannerisms of artsy, precocious (and pretentious) lit-bros and -chicks have changed but little. Gaddis skewered them perfectly in [b:The Recognitions|395058|The Recognitions|William Gaddis|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1309209622s/395058.jpg|1299804]; Broyard has no intention of that. Everything he says is autobiographical, including meetings with Anaïs Nin, Maya Deren, Dylan Thomas, Delmore Schwartz, and many other avant-garde superstars. But more importantly, it's completely sincere. Broyard has a wonderful nature, kind and free of pretensions. He plays down his own gifts as a jazz critic to praise the artists and writers around him, seeing past their vanity and personal problems and underlining instead their creative brilliance.

He wrote this unfinished memoir on his deathbed in the 1980s with undisguised nostalgia, and he casts its warm glow over everything that happened back then. And so you get a picture of a well-spent youth in an age just recovering from two wars, daring to think the unthinkable and tear down the old taboos. People live in small, run-down apartments, drink imprudently, read obsessively and fill the streets with talk of ideas. I couldn't stop underlining.

Title: The Moviegoer
Author: Walker Percy
My Review:
I want to say, Camus meets...Wallace Stegner, maybe? The existentialist flux of affable (and only mildly racist) Southern gent Binx Bolling is so much warmer and more likable than that of his Francophone counterpart. Bolling is the bearer of a certain tradition of, as his fiery aunt puts it,
a certain quality of spirit, a gaiety, a sense of duty, a nobility worn lightly, a sweetness, a gentleness with women - the only good things the South ever had and the only things that really matter in life

While not lionising this tradition, Percy doesn't exactly attempt to skewer it. Instead, his protagonist seems entirely value-neutral, and his goals in life amount to no more than making money, romancing his pretty young secretaries, and enjoying the movies.

Behind this façade, though, there is no nihilism. Bolling is transfixed: "solitary and in wonder, wondering day and night, never a moment without wonder". Having been through the Korean War (the traumatic experiences therein are hinted at but not explicit), he becomes transfixed by the idea of discovering meaning - whether in religion (something he distances, though a religious motif with shades of Kierkegaard runs through the novel), some kind of Spinozan naturalism (more on that later), or in the ephemera of pop culture (specifically film), his loving consumption of which forms a makeshift onotology of urban living.

What makes reading this novel so special is the richness and complexity of its language. Percy evokes a sun-drenched Gulf coast lined with verdant suburbs, teeming bayous and secluded beaches. His hero seeks enlightenment and meaning, a goal in which he is ultimately unsuccessful (no journey down the path of nihilism ever leads to higher ground). But his happy-go-lucky nature, and his pleasure taken from life, allows him to still experience meaning and escape the everpresent "malaise" cast by modern life. Asea among hysterical, avaricious and flaky family members (whose various exigencies add little to the novel, and do not enter this review), Bolling manages to wrest Homeric glory out of the jaws of uniquely modern ennui.
