Title: A Meaningful Life
Author: L.J. Davis
My Review:
This book's reviews don't do it justice: it is a taut, brilliant, hands-down modern classic. It plays out against a background of gentrification in Brooklyn in the early 1970s, but more importantly, it's an existential yell, a pitch-perfect rendition of a young married professional for whom everything has come easily, whose life feels eerily empty.

Lowell Lake comes up from a small town in Idaho to study at Stanford, marry his college sweetheart and, reluctantly, move to New York and take a job at a plumbers' weekly. The stultifying nature of his job and marriage, coupled with his retiring personality, lead him to the brink of madness. Lacking any challenge or interest, he decides to buy an apartment in Brooklyn, the sleaziest, most terrifying area he has ever been to. In the process of buying and attempting to refurbish an old mansion, he undergoes something like a process of renewal - though L.J. Davis is in no mood to teach lessons, and lets his protagonist's growth take second billing beneath the comic moments.

Davis's dry prose is laugh-out-loud funny and his plotting is terrific. This book was pure pleasure to read. It is something like a comic adaptation of Crime and Punishment made by the Coen brothers, set in winter in 1970s New York. Recommended to people who like film noir (or Todd Solondz movies) for the jokes.

Title: Jakob von Gunten
Author: Robert Walser
My Review:
A joy from start to finish. In one sense, Walser is a gentler, (reasonably) well-adjusted version of Kafka, full of self-deprecating wit and benign hopelessness. But beneath his protagonist Jakob's diffidence lies a warmth and perspicacity, executed sublimely, so that we barely notice. Observations of the busy to and fro of a city street - many degrees removed from the Benjamenta's anti-ambitious drudgery - gradually, drolly, melt into excitement: I wanted to hug everybody. And as the book reveals the truth behind the Institute, we understand how "the smaller von Gunten" is vindicated, and how only he, with his Walter Mitty-ish persona, truly grasps what his instructors are desperately trying to convey.

Imaginative, whimsical, and poignant, this book encapsulates strangely familiar dualities: alienation together with love of humanity, lack of ambition and hopefulness, inner peace and the urgent desire to explore. Intrinsically and without elaboration or pretense, JvG personifies the power of art, and curiosity, and freedom: and all that is exciting about reading.

Title: A Month in the Country
Author: J.L. Carr
My Review:
European secularism, with its roots going back to the Enlightenment, shares many roots with its American counterpart; and yet it seems clear that the deep skepticism and apathy held toward religion on the Continent is qualitatively and quantitatively stronger. Some part of the explanation for this must go back to the brutality of the 20th Century's two great wars, which left American soil unscathed.

J.L. Carr, in an astonishingly subtle and moving way, tells a story of a traumatised veteran sublimating the horrors of Ypres into his temporary assignment as an art restorer in a small northern village. Suffocated at first by the unfriendly church and minister he gradually comes out of his shell and makes connections with various figures, leading him to experience a sun-filled and life-affirming summer. Rather than contrasting this with his bitterness and spiritual loneliness, he instead isolates it into a pocket of stand-alone good cheer, reflecting that life is made up of small moments of joy, as we look forward to the next one while realising that their supply is gradually dwindling to nothing.

There is a poetic sensitivity and intelligence in this book, which gives it space to reflect on religion, memory, Modernism, and aesthetics within a short novella and grasp toward something concrete without offering answers, or even articulating the questions. Instead, the implications of protagonist Tom Birkin's summer slowly wash over the reader, an incoming tide of catharsis and Stendhalian aesthetic awareness. There are shadows of [b:Brideshead Revisited|30933|Brideshead Revisited|Evelyn Waugh|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1402582670s/30933.jpg|2952196]'s resigned sadness and religious overtones (but without Evelyn Waugh's conviction), and of Gaddis's exploration of religion's role in art in a post-religious world. But this book's feeling of lost opportunity, - through mostly wordless scenes of artistic contemplation - is completely its own.

Title: Stoner
Author: John  Williams
My Review:
A five-star novel simply because it does everything well, swiftly paced, replete with tangibly human characters, insightful prosody and passages of wonderful, almost lyrical beauty, though toned down to fit the novel's austere Midwestern tone; and trimmed free of any bloat or self-indulgence, so that its pages fly by. A lot of writers could learn from John Williams a directness and simplicity that makes his philosophical asides that much more powerful.

This writing style suits the protagonist, a silent and passive farmer's son whose intelligence persuades his parents to send him to university, where an English lecturer inspires him with the power of English lit, leading him on a path to tenure and modest success. From this quiet, unexceptional life - circumscribed in the opening pages - Williams derives a sort of reverse coming-of-age tale (a coming-of-old-age tale, maybe).

Because as Stoner's experiences broaden, his character takes on more and more depth and liveliness, even as his body prepares for the final struggle against death. In the shadows of his failed marriage, stymied career, and hopeless relationship with his daughter, he comes into himself, realising his ancestral heritage of toil and silent acceptance, making peace with his mortality, quietly proclaiming some sort of existential victory over the hypocrisy and frustrated hope which make up most of our lives.

Title: The Pilgrim Hawk
Author: Glenway Wescott
My Review: Ugh, white people. TW animal cruelty.

Title: Outline
Author: Rachel Cusk
My Review: I can't discern a single merit in this dreary, inane book, which strings together eye-roll inducing bromides with such frequency I decided it had be self-parody. The Paris Review has undertaken to print this novel in full. They must be joking.

Title: A Sport and a Pastime
Author: James Salter
My Review:
What did I just read? A sleepy, luscious novella about a winter in France and a doomed relationship, or some lazy erotica with ten-dollar words (like the cover implies)?

There is a contradiction in this book. Slater proudly parades the clichés of French travel novels: the expensive, beautiful meals, the witty banter, the nihilism, the outrageous sex. And yet, by positioning the first-person narrator on the outside, as a swotty never-was hopelessly in love with a local girl (and unable to prevent himself checking out every girl that steps onto the train), he "queers" the dynamic, turning the omniscient protagonist into a sort of cuckolded figure, frustrated by his loss in love, possibly harboring or repressing homosexual desires.

There are some beautiful, evocative passages in this book, as the narrator imagines the love affair on highways and in restaurants, in hotel rooms and in the rain. There are detailed sex scenes that seem slightly risqué even today. There is a portrayal of a quieter, modest French countryside, far from the tourist traps of Paris.

I don't consider this a great novel, but Slater's mastery of his craft makes it a very worthwhile one for aspiring writers.

Title: Enormous Changes at the Last Minute
Author: Grace Paley

Title: My Traitor's Heart: A South African Exile Returns to Face His Country, His Tribe, and His Conscience
Author: Rian Malan
My Review:
Growing up as a white South African, my upbringing was quite similar to Rian Malan's. There was one crucial distinction: I lived in the "free", post-apartheid South Africa, where the miracle of democracy had given everyone the right to vote, live where they pleased, and earn a living wage. Everyone was relieved that we had gotten rid of our great moral burden, and we could finally just be a remote, peaceful nation, welcoming tourists to our wine routes and game reserves.

Except that things still weren't quite right. Segregation still existed, in a more informal sense - the wealthy Johannesburg suburbs in which I lived were almost all white, sprinkled with a few black families who'd been blessed with the right connections for government jobs or lucrative contracts. Almost all of the black people I interacted with were menial workers. And there were other sides to this country with which I was completely unacquainted. Poor white farmers, blighted housing projects, all-black "squatter camps" (or informal settlements). Having left South Africa more than six years ago, I'm only now realising how little I ever knew it.

That's why reading this book felt so important. Rian Malan was a classic liberal, who flirted with Communism in his teens and fled to the US to avoid conscription. He intended to write a boilerplate book about the evils of apartheid, but in doing so he encountered the multivalent nature of Africa which has perplexed outsiders for centuries.

He begins with the arrival of his ancestor Dawie Malan (a chain of Malans runs through the key moments of South African history) and his flight across the Great Fish River. Throughout the book he wonders, how did we come to a situation of such hatred and fear? When the first humans left Africa and wandered off to Nordic climes, what changed in them? And when they finally returned, what caused their meeting with their long-lost brethren to be one of fear and violence? Malan repeatedly interrogates the concepts of race, peoplehood and tolerance. Africa scrambles the preconceptions of justice and fairness he imbibed with his Eurocentric education. At one point he declares "the Enlightenment cannot penetrate here, in darkest Africa".

Malan describes all manners of violence: white on black, black on white, black on black. He is driven to despair by the insensate nature of the conflict he witnesses. One section of the book describes a series of grisly murders, followed by a description of the trial and final statement of the murderer, which indicts white South Africa for the cruelty and humiliation it heaped upon the man, driving him to become a murderer. And then it goes back to the man's community and calls his account into question, portraying him as the child of an incestuous relationship, spurned by his tribe, with possible mental health issues.

South Africa resists easy explanations, or any explanations at all. That explains the circuitous nature of this book (and perhaps this review). Malan is unable to put a handle on everything he has seen. The violence, the sickness of his society draws him back from exile, but appears insoluble (this book was published in 1990, four years before the first democratic elections). Even now, though things are exponentially better, there are overwhelming problems of integration and protection of minorities. This is a country that will never stop breaking your heart.

The final chapter of this book encapsulates perfectly its overall theme. It tells of Neil Alcock, a white farmer who dedicated his life to living in a drought-stricken Zulu reservation, helping develop sustainable farming systems and mediating with heartless white authorities. He spoke Zulu like a native and lived in a white hut with his wife, two biological sons, and several adopted black children. Malan chronicles, sometimes dispassionately but more often with great sorrow, Alcock's attempt to intervene in one of the constant internecine conflicts, and his resulting death. His widow is eventually robbed, beaten and threatened with death by a man she raised as her son. Droughts are followed by floods, goats trespass on the farm and destroy it, and finally even eat the flower garden she has planted on her husband's grave.

Yet from this heart-wrenching, infuriating story, Malan wrenches (maybe a little too easily, maybe to placate a nervous editor, who needed a strong ending - but still with great skill) a tiny piece of redemption. In an early morning ceremony, two men return to gather Neil Alcock's soul, and return it to his home. The villagers create a joyous ceremony out of this return, feasting and dancing, until even the widow joins in. And finally, something real and unprecedented has happened - documented in a paragraph of tremendous, shocking power.

In the end, the sun went down and the celebrants went home, leaving the horns of the sacrificial cattle nailed to the room of the home. The horns were a reminder of the ceremony performed that day, a sign that the household within had honored its shades. In a continent where people worship their ancestors, Neil Alcock had become a god - the first white god in Africa, as far as anybody knows. Aeons after our ancestors walked away, the first white man had come home to Africa to stay.

Title: Whites
Author: Norman Rush
My Review:
I started subscribing to the Paris Review this year. I know, kind of silly, since almost all of their stuff is online. But I like the short stories, often, and I like feeling the thickness of the pages when I read it outside. One thing I've picked up from the issues I've read is that there seem to be a lot of writers who are seen as touchstones in American fiction, most of whom are completely unfamiliar to me - what I have begun to call the MFA canon. It includes names like James Salter, Marilynne Robinson, John Williams, Lydia Davis, Grace Paley, Joy Williams, Lorrie Moore, Evan S. Connell, and at the top of the chain, the Tolstoy and Flaubert of the canon, John Cheever and Raymond Carver. The defining quality of this fiction is a very minimalist, introverted, calmness. It concerns itself with the domestic lives of mild-mannered people, who observe the world with a wry wit and defeated mien. Overly complex plots are rare. I get the sense that MFA students, focused on recreating this lapidary, elegant prose, aren't going anywhere near the experimental pyrotechnics of John Barth or Thomas Pynchon or D Foster Wallace (perhaps the latter, only through his short stories).

Which isn't meant as a criticism at all. The stories that the Review prints - some indie writers, some stuff from the slush pile, whatever Zadie Smith is working on - are superb. Having never been in an MFA program, I'm more at the stage of learning and processing than critiquing. But there seems to be a cluster of influence here that I've only just begun discovering. (Can someone let me know if this is what that whole [b:MFA vs NYC|18248379|MFA vs. NYC The Two Cultures of American Fiction|Chad Harbach|https://d.gr-assets.com/books/1386380672s/18248379.jpg|25701143] thing was about?

Anyway, this collection of short stories is another book by a "writer's writer" that I'd place firmly in the canon. The first four stories are five-star brilliance. They, like the rest, concern American expats living in Botswana, mostly as aid workers or government contractors. Norman Rush lightly describes the lives of well-off, educated Westerners living in a society filled with danger and poverty and great kindness. Africa is filled with contradictions and causes people's values to veer wildly and their identities to change, like a psychic Bermuda Triangle.

While most of the characters are the eponymous Whites, one story is narrated by a native BaTswana in broken English, and, amazingly, comes off as wonderfully sympathetic and real, without an ounce of condescension. Rush finds his characters frustrated and tired, overshadowed by an ever-present drought (mentioned roughly once every ten pages). But like the physical one, their spiritual drought refuses to break. Africa still eludes them, as it has eluded every writer seeking to get to the bottom of it. Rush wisely doesn't try that. His style is naturalist and authentic, and perfectly suited to his subject.

Title: The People of Forever Are Not Afraid
Author: Shani Boianjiu
My Review: I found much to relate to, but this book was a little disappointing. Boianjiu is fond of hyperbole and as the book progresses allows this to interfere more and more with the strict realism which is so compelling. The fantasies of the characters, and the violence that they witness, become an increasingly large part of the book, until the levels of violence (sexual and otherwise) become implausible and just feel like showboating. Five stars for the first chapter; one star for the last third, which reads like an undergrad creative writing assignment badly in need of an editor. Still, it's exciting to read fresh, original Israeli fiction, from a promising author barely out of college.

Title: John the Posthumous
Author: Jason Schwartz
Publisher: OR Books, New York and London
My Review: Short, puzzling, totally plotless, collection of laconic etymologies and historical facts. Full of eerie atmosphere: reading meaning into it, however, was beyond me. Maybe reading it in one sitting was a mistake.

Title: The Mill On The Floss
Author: George Eliot
My Review: Slow in parts (Eliot purposely set it back a few decades, in the quiet rural areas she favoured) but full of magic. In describing mental states of people torn between faith and happiness, love and loyalty, she is a master of realism and "close writing".

Title: The Mill On The Floss
Author: George Eliot
My Review: Slow in parts (Eliot purposely set it back a few decades, in the quiet rural areas she favoured) but full of magic. In describing mental states of people torn between faith and happiness, love and loyalty, she is a master of realism and "close writing".

Title: Middlemarch
Author: George Eliot
My Review: A poignant, beautiful, masterful depiction of a rural English community involving themes also pertinent to today's youth - career worries, lack of direction, pressure from parents. The characters are flawed but human, as recognisable as any we see outside of fiction. Elliot's psychological brilliance reveals both her male and female characters as well-intentioned but flawed human beings. Penetrating insights abound, such as the following: "what we call our despair is often only the painful eagerness of unfed hope".

Title: Middlemarch
Author: George Eliot
My Review: A poignant, beautiful, masterful depiction of a rural English community involving themes also pertinent to today's youth - career worries, lack of direction, pressure from parents. Title: The Hall of Uselessness: Collected Essays
Author: Simon Leys
My Review:
RIP Simon Leys 1935-2014

An erudite, spirited collection of essays on Western literature (with an emphasis on Belgian writers such as Simenon and Henri Michaux), China and the value of universities and the humanities. Leys is unabashedly conservative, standing against new academic trends (Edward Said and Roland Barthes come in for particularly harsh treatment) and the dominance of pluralism over elitism, as well as standing up for his somewhat old-fashioned religious principles (an exchange of letters criticising Christopher Hitchens for his words against Mother Theresa hasn't aged well). Leys (a pen-name for Pierre Ryckmans) examines Chinese poetics and aesthetics in what was for me the book's most interesting part. He examines a connection perceived by the Chinese between the moral value of an artist to the quality of his art, and strongly endorses it. I skimmed some of the essays, but there are enough "a-ha" moments to make this worthwhile.

Title: Terra Nostra
Author: Carlos Fuentes
Additional Authors: Margaret Sayers Peden, Milan Kundera, Jorge Volpi

Title: Language as Symbolic Action: Essays on Life, Literature, and Method
Author: Kenneth Burke

Title: The Age of Innocence
Author: Edith Wharton
My Review: According to the New Yorker, we're not allowed to say that something isn't relatable anymore, so I'll just say that this is a little slow and mannered. A tale of opportunity lost amongst New York's upper classes.

Title: Jimmy Corrigan: The Smartest Kid on Earth
Author: Chris Ware

Title: The Easter Parade
Author: Richard Yates
My Review:
Emily Grimes c'est moi*.




*Apologies to Flaubert

Title: The Stories of Breece D'J Pancake
Author: Breece D'J Pancake
Additional Authors: James Alan McPherson, Andre Dubus III, John Casey
My Review: Comparisons to Hemingway are by no means overwrought - this kid can write, bringing to life the worn-out rural back-country with stunning precision. There's an atmosphere of melancholy present in each one of these stories that makes it hard to get through more than one per sitting. But they are short, crafted masterpieces of laconic realism, eschewing sentimentality, and instead describing the coal dust-covered, hilly landscape which slowly stifles any hope of redemption. Seeing that process unfold is something unique.

Title: The Melancholy of Resistance
Author: László Krasznahorkai
My Review:
Punishing but at times totally gripping - a few lyrical passages, plus glowing blurbs from Susan Sontag and W.G. Sebald, got me to the finish. I saw the film first, Béla Tarr's slow-paced portrayal of innocence vs mob rage. That's broadly the theme here, but the book is more than a little resistant to thematic analysis. For one, János (called Valuska in the novel) is far less prominent as the central character. His mother, the bitter and conservative Mrs Plauf, frames the beginning and end-pieces. Decomposition is a major theme, still; there's a connection to musical theory via the anxious musicologist Eszter, whose efforts are ultimately thwarted by his wife's plans of domination. The theme of death and destruction is reinforced by a bleak ending piece titled 'Sermon on the Grave'. The film made me think of the violent history that Hungary has seen in the last century, but the book feels atemporal and certainly much less political.

Everything in this book is vague, including the words themselves. Krasznahorkai never inserts paragraph breaks (I finished this the same weekend as Thomas Bernhard's Concrete, another example of this practice) and constantly interjecting characters' thoughts in quotes in the middle of their own monologues. I think there's a kind of irony in this - the cliches people think in, but are embarrassed to vocalise. Being aware that something is a cliche but using it anyway with knowing distance makes this Hungarian hermit a level-A hipster, or millenial, or whatever. A passage later in the book might be explaining it

Enough of this...claptrap! Ever since dawn I have had to listen to nothing but retarded babble...you don't talk, you "whisper" or "expostulate", you don't walk down the street but "proceed feverishly", you don't enter a place but "cross its threshold", you don't feel cold or hot, but "find yourself shivering" or "feeling the sweat pouring down you"! I haven't heard a straight word for hours. (pg 278; New Directions 1989)


The implication is almost that the destruction perceived by the characters is exaggerated, or at least misinterpreted. But the book doesn't really offer any other clues, nor does it give us an explanation about the Prince or his powers.

The 'pomo' tag is for that, and this epic closing line

It ground the [body] into carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen and sulphur, took their delicate fibres and unstitched them till they were dispersed and had ceased to exist, because they had been consumed by the force of some incomprehensibly distant edict, which must also consume this book, here, now, at the full stop, after the last word.

Title: Concrete
Author: Thomas Bernhard
My Review: Thomas Bernhard: perfect for those Sunday afternoons when you feel your most antipathy towards humanity.

Title: Moby-Dick, or, the Whale
Author: Herman Melville
My Review: Kind of a weird experience. The beginning and end - the story - move really quickly, a fair amount of the middle felt like a slog to me. But there are a lot of different things going on there: some Gonzo journalism (the book was based on Melville's experiences on a whaler, although he also put in a lot of research); philosophising about man's place in the world, the colour white, and good and evil; really rich, difficult, Shakespearean soliloquies (occasional chapters are written as theatrical scenes); attempts to place cetology and whale-hunting at the forefront of Western culture. Definitely felt lost by a fair amount of it, but I have an obsessive drive to get through the damn book, in general (overall, probably a bad thing, only encouraged by the quantifying mechanics of a site like Goodreads). It's definitely got canon written all over it: each character is replete with symbolic elements. Ishmael seems to come out of a vacuum in the book's first line to become an almost omniscient narrator, Ahab exists only as his obsessive hubris, Starbuck as the voice of common sense, etc. So it's a book that's meant to be chewed over and mapped, and quoted. College English departments have pretty much got that covered.

Title: Lukacs: History and Class Consciousness (Studies in Marxist Dialectics)
Author: György Lukács

Title: A Guide for the Perplexed
Author: Ernst F. Schumacher
My Review: Along with a healthy dose of crazy (pseudoscience, Evolution denial and bad philosophy) this proto-environmentalist tome delivers some prescient advice on our relationship with technology, and how scientific development needs to be yoked with ecological and humanist concerns.

Title: U.S.A.: The 42nd Parallel / 1919 / The Big Money
Author: John Dos Passos

Title: Dress Your Family in Corduroy and Denim
Author: David Sedaris

Title: Meditations
Author: Marcus Aurelius
Additional Authors: Martin Hammond, Albert Wittstock, Diskin Clay

Title: The People Look Like Flowers at Last
Author: Charles Bukowski

Title: Regarding the Pain of Others
Author: Susan Sontag
My Review: A thought-provoking meditation on war photography and, by extension, our ambiguous relationship with the sight of other people's suffering.

Title: Principia Ethica (Philosophical Classics)
Author: G.E. Moore
My Review:
The continental/analytical divide, which has split philosophy for around the past hundred years, is less a debate than a division of labour. Continental philosophers, liberated by Kant from the need to ground their intuitions empirically, have taken on the grand mantle of philosophy of old: metaphysics, aesthetics, history. Analyticals, mostly concentrated in the Anglophone world, have preferred to focus on more modest fields, mostly of modern provenance: philosophy of language, mathematics and science; and formal logic. (The one exception might be Analytical philosophy of mind, which goes back to Descartes and Leibniz, and has antecedents in Classical Philosophy.)

G.E. Moore sits firmly in the second camp, but ambitiously attempts to reclaim the field of ethics to the analytical fold. To do so, he begins by clearing up a lot of the incorrect notions which had accumulated in the field, including hedonism, utilitarianism, and Kantian ethics. Pretty much every serious study of ethics has at some point fallen back on an appeal to nature or the like. Moore calls this the "naturalistic fallacy". Having dismissed all of the rest, he attempts a positive construction of what might be defined as good, and thus as desirable.

And here is where he stumbles. Freely admitting that much work remains, Moore (himself known for his high ethical character, incidentally) struggles to define exactly what we might consider good, and on what basis. Especially in the field of aesthetics, his own judgments seem to veer dangerously close to the naturalistic fallacy. The assumption that some virtues are inherently good, while tempting, does seem to need more formal grounding.

The strength of this book is in its thorough and clear examination - and repudiation - of most of the previous ethical theories to gain currency in the Western world. But the spectre of Postmodernism haunts this book: as logical positivism crumbled to dust by mid-century, Continentals would turn to moral relativism, while Analyticals would withdraw from the field altogether. Neutral moral judgments, seen as intuitive to most of us as children, aren't nearly as simple as they appear.

Title: Molloy
Author: Samuel Beckett
My Review:
Stream-of-images, beautifully rendered, more than suffices for the lack of narrative cohesion. Beckett's sense of absurdity/futility, coupled with a zesty disgust for his own physicality, makes for brutally funny reading.

Bakhtin's idea of the Grotesque Body found in Rabelais seems a good touchpoint.

Title: Inferno
Author: Dante Alighieri
My Review: I picked this up trying to follow the Paris Review's Fall Challenge, but I think I'd have done better joining a class or book club - it was hard to appreciate its fabled greatness, especially when reading the poem in translation. (Even TPR's recaps ended up as jokey satire.) The notes helped understand the basics, but I didn't come away totally enraptured, as I'd secretly been hoping.

Title: Summer in Baden-Baden
Author: Leonid Tsypkin
Additional Authors: Roger Keys, Angela Keys, Susan Sontag
My Review: This book is full of thick, run-on, endless prose - sentences tend to just keep going, as the author switches focus without wanting to interrupt his train of thought - using dashes in place of full stops - creating a feeling of motion, of absorption in his full sense of being in his imagined world. OK, I'll stop recreating the style, but it really is something, challenging and absorbing. Tsypkin fetishises Dostoevsky, in all his greatness and smallness - his gambling, his jealousy, petty feuds with literary scenesters (particularly memorable is the portrayal of lofty, leonine, Turgenev; a lit celeb surrounded by admirers and aristocrats, dropping witty bon mots in French; exactly as Tolstoy - like Dostoevsky, a passionate Slavophile - portrays the decadent bourgeoisie in W&P). Following in the master's footsteps, all the way to the Dostoevsky museum in St Petersburg, Tsypkin immerses himself in the parallel world he has created and attempts to grasp the measure of the man. FD's antisemitism is prominent (references to "nastly little Jews" abound) and toward the end Tsypkin zeroes in on it, grappling with it without giving concrete answers. But the ending, with the author sitting in the house of an elderly, religious Jew, still beleagueredly keeping up her faith despite decades of Soviet persecution gives something of an answer. In raw, passionate paragraphs, this slim novel gives over a lasting image of a life. And by its existence, as a lost work of a frustrated Soviet Jew, who died without ever being published, repeatedly denied an exit visa, it testifies just as eloquently to another forgotten life.

Title: The Golden Notebook
Author: Doris Lessing
My Review:
By the end of this book I'd decided to go back and and reread my own notebooks. Seeing a life through notebooks is one of the most honest ways it can be presented. But how much of someone's unexpurgated life do we really want to read? The last ~150 pages of this felt like retreading the same territory, with little added value.

Some of the issues are specifically 'women's issues', or '50s women's issues', like how men blame women for their own hangups, and the difficulty of being a mother vs maintaining independence. as a guy you can sympathise but not totally relate.

One thing which struck me as annoying about Lessing's writing style is these ironic tensions nestled in every conversation, in which no-one is really saying what they mean, just playing these oracular cards and then laughing at how they sound, or how that's exactly what they're supposed to say, or at how bourgeois or provincial they sound. I realise that this is because they're all wise and overeducated and world-weary, but at some point it becomes self-parody.

'Richard, your problem is you're too sensitive' Anna said, knowing she didn't mean it, but just saying it because she felt she must'. 'But Anna, you know what it's like', said Richard, and Anna burst into peals of laughter because this is what Richard always said.

Maybe it's not immediately apparent what's annoying about this tone, but after 600 pages of dialogue like this, you start wishing someone would just say things straight.

Title: Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance: An Inquiry Into Values (Phaedrus, #1)
Author: Robert M. Pirsig
My Review:
Fun and conversational, but Pirsig posesses the philosophical chops to make this novel more than just a collection of platitudes (comparisons to Alan Watts here would be merely unkind). At its heart is a critique of no less than Western rationalism - and, since Hume, the lackings in that system have been all too painfully aware to us.

Pirsig sees the idea of 'quality' as parallel to the pre-Socratic concept of the good, which was usurped by Platonic epistemology, effectively placing 'the truth' above the good, with the ensuing subject-object dichotomy. Our fragmented world view is in effect, a lack of awareness of our place in the greater scheme of things, from which we derive satisfaction/meaning in life, or what Pirsig terms 'gumption'.The philosophy is solid, but the conclusions, a radical rejection of Western philosophy, warrant more depth than they are given in between the narrative. Still, an important and enjoyable read.

Title: The Drowned World
Author: J.G. Ballard
My Review:
Better.

At some point I'm going to have to give up my completely unjustifiable prejudice against genre fiction. here's a great example of warped, really psychological fiction, which uses an exterior world as an extrapolation of the interior - just like The Metamorphosis, except with more rationalisation (a sort of global-warming-on-crack scenario). Like Tarkovsky with Solaris, Ballard seeks to create artistic sci-fi. But there's no doubt as to which of the two is Il miglior fabbro.

Title: Cocaine Nights
Author: J.G. Ballard
My Review:
Definitely feel the need to justify this rating, and my disappointment with Ballard (who feels like a "writers' writer") in general. Got pretty far into a review using John Updike's nexus of critique, but then the internet happened, and GR decided to erase it all. I'll try and replace the loss soonish.

Update:

Firstly, I'm planning to read The Drowned World, and I listened to My Dream of Flying to Wake Island on The Guardian's fiction podcast, but beyond that this novel is my first foray into Ballardian territory. Wouldn't have been my optimal choice, but it's available for free on the avant-garde storehouse UbuWeb, adapted from cassette(!)

The book starts out as a pretty generic crime thriller, involving a murder of in tropic island paradise Estrella del Mar. The narrator, a travel journalist whose brother has inexplicably copped to the crime, investigates what turns out to be a far deeper conspiracy than he'd suspected.

...
...

It stretches out for a long time, and it doesn't really feel like there's much of a payoff. I understand some of what Ballard might be going for here: a world devoid of morality, anodyne, soulless automatons going through anhedonous lives as metaphor for the modern condition.


But this book is neither fun nor meaningful: it's too long, flat, bland and pleasureless, which makes me think that it might just work as performance art: the struggle of getting through such half-assed hackery as metaphor for a very bleak existence.

Anyway, I found it kind of distressing to be so underwhelmed by a book I'd been so looking forward to, so I availed myself of John Updike's criticism rules to see if I'd been fair, or at least to make my opinion completely clear in my own mind.

1. Try to understand what the author wished to do, and do not blame him for not achieving what he did not attempt.

As an airport paperback, it's OK - though not enough to keep me from compulsively checking how much was left.

2. Give enough direct quotation—at least one extended passage—of the book's prose so the review's reader can form his own impression, can get his own taste.

"Crossing frontiers is my profession. Those strips of no-man's land between the checkpoints always seem such zones of promise, rich with the possibility of new lives, new scents and affections. At the same time they set off a reflex of unease that I have never been able to repress."

That style is pretty much two thirds the book.

3. Confirm your description of the book with quotation from the book, if only phrase-long, rather than proceeding by fuzzy précis.

Can't do this one as I don't have a physical copy. (Maybe that was the problem?)

4. Go easy on plot summary, and do not give away the ending.

☑

5. If the book is judged deficient, cite a successful example along the same lines, from the author's œuvre or elsewhere. Try to understand the failure. Sure it's his and not yours?

Well, it's hard to find a comparable author. Maybe a crime writer like Raymond Chandler? Maybe after The Drowned World, I'll have a better grasp of what I'm dealing with.

I think the failure is in subject matter, making a creepy, alienated feeling into a book length murder mystery. I could have done without a lot of the exposition. I just want to read enjoyable prose, or find some kind of recognition in what I'm reading - even a Kafkaesque sort of recognised alienation.

And the final rule:

6.Do not accept for review a book you are predisposed to dislike...never try to put the author "in his place,"...Review the book, not the reputation. Submit to whatever spell, weak or strong, is being cast. Better to praise and share than blame and ban.

The communion between reviewer and his public is based upon the presumption of certain possible joys of reading, and all our discriminations should curve toward that end.

I spend a lot of time these days thinking about what it is that makes fiction enjoyable, and why we pursue it so avidly. Whatever that mysterious factor is, here it is absent. Reading this book was a pleasure I'd gladly have yielded.

Title: The Street of Crocodiles
Author: Bruno Schulz
Additional Authors: Celina Wieniewska, Mikolaj Dutsch, Hana Jechova, A. Vivanti Salmon, Jerzy Ficowski, Jonathan Safran Foer
My Review:
A prescient classic of magical realism, richly and vitally written, though Schultz's obsession with describing his elusive, diaphanous feelings inevitably comes at the expense of intelligibility, to a degree. The erudite intro to my edition (not written by Jonathan Saf-Fo, though his weird concept-art reëdit of this did lead me to discovering it, so thanks are due) discusses how Schultz basically felt that certain momentary childhood feelings mark all of us at some point, and our artistic, spiritual and literary efforts are all an attempt to regain or at least delineate that simple joy.

Thus this novel: descriptive words abound (the rococo prose, full of botanical/zoological/architectural arcana, had me repeatedly mashing the dictionary feature on my e-reader), magical things happen, simple elements of small-town family life are elevated to Biblical or mythical dimensions. There's a self-proclaimed rewriting of the book of Genesis on more humanist terms, involving the character's father's creation of a homunculus and a comet (he must have read War and Peace, right?) and the titular stories (in the Polish original and the translation, respectively) "Cinnamon Stores" and "The Street of Crocodiles". Those in love with 100 Years of Solitude will probably go for this too - I didn't love the former, but I did appreciate the relative brevity of the latter, plus everyone not being called Arcadia or Buendía.

Schultz was sadly cut down in his prime, a shy and sweet writer who had a Kafkaesque way of seeing absurdity in the world, but an infinitely brighter disposition. His childlike intensity and erudition are matched with an artist's eye. With these tools he created surreally beautiful and unique literary structures which, even when not totally cohering, stand far apart from any of his contemporaries. We can only wonder what he would have made of the disillusionment of the post-holocaust world, that inspired such wholly different artistic endeavours.

Title: Righteous Victims: A History of the Zionist-Arab Conflict, 1881-1998
Author: Benny Morris

Title: My Promised Land: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel
Author: Ari Shavit
My Review:
An excellent, unputdownable personal and ethnic history that never feels dreary or apologetic. Shavit distills the focal points of Zionist history into thematic chains, interrogating the traditionally accepted Zionist narratives of "Shoah to uprising" and "making the desert bloom", while acknowledging and celebrating the accomplishments of the early state in so many fields (unlike more curmudgeonly leftists of the ilk of, say, Uri Avnery). Going through his family's past in the country, beginning with his English great-grandfather, Shavit weighs up the great successes of Israel along with its dark secrets, and ponders its future in its current state.

With impeccable professionalism, the author gives a sympathetic journalistic ear to people from all over the political spectrum, ranging from messianic right-wing Jews to business oligarchs to Arab activists. In between, though, he doesn't hold back on his own views. His peace credentials are solid, having spent many years working at peace organisations and as a columnist at left-leaning Ha'aretz, but Shavit is wary of Israeli leftists who blame all of the country's ills on the Occupation, ignoring the broader regional context of hostility in which Israel has always existed.

Weak points: like his New Yorker colleague Malcolm Gladwell, Shavit has an annoying tendency to "storify" his chapters - after announcing a chapter's theme he will sum it up in a few trenchant questions (what was the defining aspect of the pioneers? can Israel survive in the twenty-first century?) and then immediately follow it up with a couple of personal biographies and interviews with the characters he has chosen to give the definitive answers. His writing is also a bit overwrought (looking over the GR reviews, it seems I'm not the first to pick up on this). Everything is defining and heart-breaking and pivotal, all of the people are beautiful and brilliant and talented.

Still, there are few books on either the history or contemporary state of Israel containing as much in-depth knowledge and consummate skill as this one. Whether talking about Jewish-Arab co-existence in Mandate Palestine, expulsions of Arab villagers, or nightclubs and social protests in 2013, Shavit brings an unmatched scope and clarity to his subject. In a conflict in which every detail is disputed and the future is shrouded in doubt, this is probably the closest you can get to a reliable survey.

Title: The Man Who Loved Children
Author: Christina Stead
My Review:
The one prominent critical Goodreads review of this book is by someone who gave up on it around page 130, which makes sense, because at that point I was sorely tempted to give it up myself. Sheer bloody-mindedness compelled me to continue. I'm so glad that I did. This book grows on you slowly, and, in adjusting you to the sharply realised Pollit crew, demands your complete emotional investment.

The titular character is the immensely annoying patriarch, Sam, the prime factor in one's desire to put down the book - that is, until you realise what a monster he is; that his childish speech, sexism and huge egotism make living with him impossible. His wife Henny - plagued with plenty of her own issues, as becomes clear later on in the book - gave up on her marriage from the outset, spending most of her free time engaged in playing solitaire (the focus of one of the phenomenal set pieces towards the end). There are some powerful scenes where the two parents have it out, reminiscent of the Sopranos episode "Whitecaps" in their emotional intensity, crackling with the repressed frustration of wasted decades. There is a black thrill in seeing the toxicity of the Pollit family dynamic seep outward, starting from Sam, the oblivious source of all the trouble.

Sam is self-pitying and self-centred. He takes for granted that his opinions are supremely important to the world, that he is a martyr held back by his loved ones. Anyone familiar with such a character in real life will recognise the tendency to hold forth at length about issues instead of discussing them, to flinch from criticism or see it as a personal attack, and to alternating spite and wounded humility.

By contrast, the children adjust to their circumstances fairly well, as children tend to do. Ernie is calm and prudent, carefully planning out the savings in his money box and accounting for the expenses of birthday presents. Saul and the younger ones are generally cheerful, relating perfectly to their father. In this sense he does love children: young, malleable minds, eager to learn, interested in nature, accepting authority without question. But in the oldest daughter Louise he finds a resistance that curdles into hatred: his dismissal of her complexity, and insistence that she fall into his entourage of admirers, drives her into open, not quite futile, revolt.

This is a challenging but beautifully written book. It requires the reader to learn about a family mostly by observing their speech patterns and chaotic daily life. Like reality TV, but less polished, it places before us regular people in whom we will see myriad things wrong, but nothing that we would know how to improve, because we know how our own relationships tend to tangle into Gordian knots of denial and dissatisfaction. Like real life, the family in the book is irreducible to simple dichotomies or pop-psychology cliches. (It was apparently based mostly on Stead's own upbringing in Australia.) At first it resists you, but eventually you begin to love its sad, well-intentioned characters, and by the time the closing sequence of events commences, bringing wave after wave of heartbreak, you are too firmly in its grip to let go. This is a big-hearted novel, which paints growing up and family life in spectacular dimensions.

Title: Gargantua and Pantagruel
Author: François Rabelais
My Review:
Going through this back-to-back with the Canterbury Tales (and not far removed from Don Quixote) afforded me ample opportunity to reflect on the development of the modern novel, and the modern sensibility. Something subversive lies in these two books - which are so ripe with scatological humour and hanky-panky - and one wonders how much this contributed to their enduring popularity. Both, too, along with Don Quixote, contain metafictional elements (Chaucer's cameo narration, G&P's endless made up books), symptom of a certain experimental zest that elevated them above the primordial ooze that was lay literature from the Middle Ages to the Renaissance.

I was exposed to Bakhtin's famous reading long before I read this, but I wasn't quite aware what sensational fun the degradation of the human anatomy could be. Rabelais isn't just ripping into the Church of his time (like Chaucer does, a little more sanctimoniously), and pompous middle-class notions of dignity. He's having a blast. Whole cities drowning in urine, mustard poop, giant babies with yard-long erections. It's so surreal, so over the top, that it begins to feel realistic again.

What is life, if not a giant codpiece? How does anything make sense? It certainly doesn't when you accept the conventions of polite society, today or five hundred years ago. Asking these kinds of questions is how the seeds of the Enlightenement were sown, and it's behind every really great novel.

Title: In the Light of What We Know
Author: Zia Haider Rahman

Title: Nightwood
Author: Djuna Barnes
My Review: Basically a novel-length prose poem. So many jewel-like, delicately crafted sentences that snake upwards like giant glass skyscrapers. Brilliant writing, and so full of sadness.

Title: Discourse on the Origin of Inequality
Author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
My Review: Civilization is, like, way overrated, maaan.

Title: Sex, Drugs, and Cocoa Puffs: A Low Culture Manifesto
Author: Chuck Klosterman
My Review:
I'm fascinated by the formation and circulation of cultural capital, and I have a nagging suspicion that monetarian economic models could have something to say in this field. Yesterday I was browsing GR for some good books on the commodification of culture, kind of hoping to find someone who could summarise Adorno and Horkheimer without being too dense and jargon-loaded. On a whim I picked up this book instead. It's a light read which you can fly through in one determined sitting. Basically, it goes to the opposite extreme: it's the little guy, giving the sceptical winking brosplanation to what all those mixed-up eggheads are talking about.

Klosterman, in his congenial tone, likes to expand his pop culture observations into Universal Rules, neatly resolving everything he surveys into simple, distinct binaries. Soccer, unlike real American sports, "represents outcast culture". Pamela Anderson, in contrast to Marilyn Monroe, represents sex in the 90s vs the 60s. Everything makes perfect sense!

I'm baffled as to how people seem to hate on this book because it's for and about pretentious hipsters. I love pretentious hipsters! I wish Klosterman had been a pretentious fuck, instead of unambitiously middlebrow, in the worst sense of the word. Instead of geeking out on musical arcana like the people he pokes fun at, Chuck spent his college years doing ordinary things: beer pong, watching sports, getting wasted. Which is fine - and explains the everyman disdain he holds for the pointy-headed music critics who convene in the final essay to discuss academic perspectives on hip-hop and cock rock. Klosterman takes on the mantle of middleman, interpreting the gist of what they have to say: mostly disdaining how out of touch and ridiculous they are, and idly throwing in his own half-assed ideas with a "postmodern" and "ironic" thrown in here and there in non-threatening ways. This is the dumbed-down version of academic culture studies.

Most of this book has aged pretty well, besides for the essay on print media, and a curiously prudish chapter on porn. Those looking for a superficial, easily quotable read will enjoy it, but if you want an analysis with some level of depth, you might want to consider someone who actually internalised some of the show-offy parts of his college experience. Y'know, like an actual hipster.

Title: An Episode in the Life of a Landscape Painter
Author: César Aira
My Review:
I have no idea how much of this is surreal, metaphysically inflected short novel is true, but it's gripping and superbly composed throughout. The tale of an artist's compulsive search for beautiful scenery, under, ahem, less than favourable conditions, it works around themes of artistic sincerity and the nature of reality.

Much more than anything I've read in a long time, Aira's writing gave me a sense of location: the locust-devoured pampas, steaming jungle, violet mountains populated with a huge variety of life. The author's love of biology is evident, both in his descriptions and in his meticulous, lapidary taxonomy - along aesthetic, rather than strictly scientific, lines. An enchanting combination of the wordly and the otherworldly.

Title: The Living Thoughts of Kierkegaard
Author: Søren Kierkegaard
My Review:
Kierkegaard's terse, opaque style requires extremely close reading, even to get a cursory understanding. Turns out I'm not better equipped to do this than I was when I read Fear and Trembling and The Sickness Unto Death a few years back - though Auden's concise intro is very helpful. Whether SK's anguished existentialism is relevant to today's phenomenologists and postmodernists, or if they're just meandering apologia, is a call I'm not yet ready to make.

[Addendum: In my mind I couldn't help connecting the Platonic pursuit of Logos - Kierkegaard's Ethical Religion - with modern scientific positivism. But the ways in which SK critiques it are primarily archaic, mystical abstractions. Ontologically, it might matter if I'm compelled to pursue the Ideals once I understand them, and if the either/or dichotomy of knowledge/ignorance truly encompasses all of human behaviour. But as a system of practical ethics, a scaled-down version of this works for most people. SK's goal is to discover an existentially authentic metaphysics, grounded in Greek philosophy but realisable only in Revealed Faith. That hasn't been supplanted by anything (not to discount efforts by the likes of Heidegger and Foucault). But I still have doubts as to the coherence and workability of SK's weltaunschaung. Ultimately, I suspect that he remains what he was in his own time: ignored by the masses; a philosopher who was, and wrote only for, lonely, thoughtful individuals.]

Title: The Sickness Unto Death: A Christian Psychological Exposition for Upbuilding and Awakening
Author: Søren Kierkegaard
Additional Authors: Edna Hatlestad Hong, Howard Vincent Hong
My Review: Sort of annoying how Kierkegaard kept stating things as being "dialectically true" instead of proving them, but then again, I guess that's his thing - you've got to just get it, man! We all should. I just felt guilty that I didn't.

Title: The Sickness Unto Death: A Christian Psychological Exposition for Upbuilding and Awakening
Author: Søren Kierkegaard
Additional Authors: Edna Hatlestad Hong, Howard Vincent Hong
My Review: Sort of annoying how Kierkegaard kept stating things as being "dialectically true" instead of proving them, but then again, I guess that's his thing - you've got to just get it, man! We all should. I just felt guilty that I didn't.

Title: The Sickness Unto Death: A Christian Psychological Exposition for Upbuilding and Awakening
Author: Søren Kierkegaard
Additional Authors: Edna Hatlestad Hong, Howard Vincent Hong

Title: Audio Culture: Readings in Modern Music
Author: Christoph Cox

Title: The Geography of the Imagination: Forty Essays
Author: Guy Davenport

Title: Beautiful Losers
Author: Leonard Cohen
My Review:
This book would probably be a lot more accessible, or at least more organised, if Leonard Cohen had been doing less drugs while writing it, but it probably wouldn't have had the same heart.

A post-colonial-psychedelic-pansexual-ahistorical-Buddhist-Christian-subaltern story about ecstasy, loss and loneliness.

Title: The Sound and the Fury
Author: William Faulkner
My Review:
Before I read this novel, I didn't have much interest in a)books about the South, or b)"Gothic"-style novels (or Gothic-style anything). Is this book Gothic? Not in the emo Wuthering Heights sense, but it reaches extreme notes of pathos as it relates the disintegration of the Compton family. The story wasn't always easy to follow, but it was always compelling, believable and sympathetic.

It feels superfluous to expand on Faulkner's mastery as a prose stylist, so I won't; but it might be this formal innovation that made his (flawed, bungling, often wilfully cruel) characters seem so memorable.

Title: Axel's Castle: A Study of the Imaginative Literature of 1870-1930
Author: Edmund Wilson

Title: The Flowers of Tarbes: or, Terror in Literature
Author: Jean Paulhan

Title: The Unbearable Lightness of Being
Author: Milan Kundera
My Review:
Surprised me by being a lot more sexy, and a lot more philosophical, than I'd expected. Kind of like Aristotelian erotica, or 50 Shades of Being. The title refers to one of the philosophish digressions, a rejection of Nietzsche's "eternal recur", meaning we live life again and again. Which is bleak, hence the alternative "lightness" - doing things only once (einmal ist keinmal). Thus for me the theme of the book, is more a shaking off of the traditional politically charged Soviet mantel, in favour of just loving your dog, living on a farm, making love - ordinary people things.

Often gets referred to as postmodernist, which I think is funny, because I thought when reading it that it was stylistically nothing like that - closer to those talky, thoughtful, 19th century novels. But its true postmodernism is in its nihilism. In the absence of religious values, God, communism, political activism - the section lampooning pretentious leftists on a mercy tour of Southeast Asia is a classic, and its discussion of kitschy sentiment absolutely spot on - one instead takes comfort in just being, life, unadorned, meaningless, but still beautiful.

Oh, and TW for a really sad animal death towards the end. Sensitive readers beware.

Title: Hunger
Author: Knut Hamsun
My Review: Back in the day, writers were tough.

Title: Dead Souls
Author: Nikolai Gogol
My Review:
Some unedited thoughts on Dead Souls by Nikolai Gogol

Firstly, the unspoken implication in writing a review is that you're telling the reader whether s/he should buy the book. Which, in the case of the (mostly) universally acclaimed classics that I've been reading lately, seems a tad redundant. So that's not why I'm writing these things. Why is it?

Well, one easy way to keep my writing muscles in shape is to put down my immediate impressions, try to sort through them, understand some of the formal elements involved, put the book in its historical and authorial context - in short, to attempt to read thoroughly. I often end up glomming together some idea of the book's themes and the standard interpretations from some random idiot. And if I'm being honest here, my goal is also to show off some urbane literary sensitivity and not look naïve.

Here are some observations: I was expecting something a lot more psychological and angsty, judging not least from that ominous title but also from having read the almost Kafkaesque The Overcoat. Instead, I get what on the surface seems like your standard Dickensian social satire, specifically launching in at Capitalism 25 years before the spectre of Marx's Capital. I'm immediately reminded here of Our Mutual Friend - the dust heap as pointed metaphor for fleeting lucre (q.v. also JR's penny stocks, further down the line). Chichikov (the name itself is worth a laugh) is some kind of Tzarist 419 scammer, trying to buy up dead serfs, playing a long con which I'll omit so as not to spoil too much. It's surprisingly funny, though - particularly in the second part - the characters start to repeat themselves some.

It feels as if there's a lot more that I've failed to really grasp - comparisons to the Odyssey, modernist rereadings of the book as surrealist prosody, an inclination to read the powerful psychological novelist of the Overcoat into this work. Reading, and reading about a book at the same time, is a difficult and unique pleasure. I'll gladly give an ear to scholarly critiques, but attempting to read alternative theories into a book deprives the reader of the joy of discovery and imagination. The New Critics thought there was one true way to read a text. I'd rather perceive it in as natural a way as possible, and enjoy the plurality of possible readings in its due course.

Title: The Polish Boxer
Author: Eduardo Halfon
Additional Authors: Thomas Bunstead, Lisa Dillman, Daniel Hahn, Anne McLean

Title: Doctor Zhivago
Author: Boris Pasternak
Additional Authors: Max Hayward, Hülya Arslan, Manya Harari, John Bayley
My Review: Yak yak yak...some perspective on how sucky large parts of Russian history have been...Zhivago as a tragic figure who writes poetry and falls in love but ultimately gets screwed by the cogs of life...it isn't very good, overall.

Title: The Master and Margarita
Author: Mikhail Bulgakov
Additional Authors: Katherine Tiernan O'Connor, Ellendea Proffer, Diana Lewis Burgin
My Review:
1)The overweening mode is surrealist, and the titular characters are just a small part of what is going on in this ambitious/confusing book. There are echoes of Faust and the Bible, and clearly at some level it's a satire of paranoid and fanatical 1930s Moscow. But mostly it's just chaos, talking cats, ancient pseudohistory, naked dancers, fake money. There's a lot to figure out here.

2)Falls under 'Menippean satire', apparently, the meaning of which is opaque, but that's better than understanding it as specific satire, because then, of what?

3)Well, here are some things it might be about: the redemption of Pontius Pilate, an intertextual exploration of the connection between writers and their work, a surrealist satire of bureaucracy (q.v. Jacques Tati's Playtime (1967)).

4)Filed under 'worth further examination' and 'too long to reread', but I'm keeping an open mind.

Title: A Hero of Our Time
Author: Mikhail Lermontov
My Review: "Superfluous men", whether of the Byronic, libertine, or beatnik type, full of Weltschmerz, cynicism and ennui, commitment-phobic, aimless, and tragically underutilised, have existed for centuries, from the wild forests of the Caucasus to contemporary Bed-Stuy. Beautifully and thoughtfully realised, this still feels like a Seinfeldian "novel about nothing", a rehashing of Eugene Onegin with a deapan, affectless demeanour. Beneath its icy exterior lies complete emptiness.

Title: Don Quixote
Author: Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra
My Review:
1)It's not cool nowadays to talk about medieval times as being "that boring time before the Renaissance when everyone was repressed and punitive" (cf. the snafu over The Swerve), presumably because our history from that time is poor, many rich oral traditions didn't reach the historical record, and, people generally being people, it's safe to assume that things pretty much stay the same under the solar penumbra.
2)But to when can we date the origin of the novel? Of modern quote-unquote literary fiction? Of the caustic, wholly/partially secular sensitivity that looks back on society and tries to understand it, and give us some knowledge of our own failings? Not Homer or Euripides, nor Chaucer, who all set out within predefined frameworks of social convention, to tell the heroic journey, or the cozy monastic parable. Nor, in some ways to Don Quixote.
3)Much of this book, especially in Part I, is taken up with the type of tales which were popular in Cervantes' time, which cleave to an annoyingly basic template. No matter how much the author is playing with, or subtly skewering, these tropes - these are still ballast, to the modern reader, giving the book a lot of extra pages which can be a slog to get through. But the characters of Quixote, Sancho Panza, Rocinante, etc are affable and occasionally insightful enough to make the journey passable, especially on a soothing audiobook, after a long work day; in some sense, the way all stories are meant to be told.
4)It is perhaps owing to the metafictional weirdness bits of Part II for which the plaudits come in. The intertextuality is unexpected, out of place. Quixote's relationship to the author, and the people around him being aware of him qua literary character, adds a completely new dimension to the story.
5)The ending is also surprisingly sentimental. It seems to confirm that this book is in fact a satire, though at so many times thorughout the novel we, like Sancho, are questioning our understanding of reality. Don Quixote can be tragic, comic or inspiring. In his questioning of the value of (then-)conventional literature, and his spirit of adventure in the face of reality, common sense and repeated adversity, he is an agent of change, triumphantly heralding a new literature, adhering more closely to mimesis of a multivalent and confusing world.

Title: The Sense of an Ending: Studies in the Theory of Fiction
Author: Frank Kermode

Title: Darkness Moves: An Henri Michaux Anthology, 1927-1984
Author: Henri Michaux

Title: Sons and Lovers
Author: D.H. Lawrence
My Review:
In the time-honoured neurotic tradition of writers peeling back the layers of their damaged psyches to find inspiration, D.H. Lawrence presents his relationship with his mother, and the other women in his life, in all its glory. Beginning with the marriage of his parents - ill-advised and irreconcilable almost from the start - he develops the increasing reliance of his mother (here dubbed Mrs Morel) on him (Paul) and his brother William. It's hard not to read the title as a reference to the weirdly Oedipal bond between mother and son, and not to the protagonist's barely consummated relationships.

It's a shame that, narratively speaking, things are so chaotic, perhaps as an outgrowth of the autobiographical nature of the story. Characters like Arthur are half-formed, much of the action seems unrelated to the core of the story, and - most critically - it's difficult to relate to the decisions taken by the main character. Lawrence never clearly states/analyses his emotional struggle. Instead, he relates isolated incidents, chronicling his slow abandonment of would-be lovers and frustrated relationship with his mother - leaving the reader, like himself, estranged, bitter, confused.

Title: The Complete Persepolis (Persepolis, #1-4)
Author: Marjane Satrapi
Additional Authors: Mattias Ripa, Blake Ferris, Anjali Singh
My Review: As compelling a coming of age tale as any, even were it not under the background of the Iranian Revolution and war with Iraq. The naarator's maturity, and struggle with the great ideas of the twentieth century, are perfectly formed.

Title: The Odyssey
Author: Homer
My Review: Best-in-class in bloody, exhausting, ancient epics. Excuse me now while I get my Gilgamesh and Veda on.

Title: Undoing Depression:  What Therapy Doesn't Teach You and Medication Can't Give You
Author: Richard O'Connor

Title: A Passage to India
Author: E.M. Forster
My Review: Not just a colonial parable or a story of misplaced love, Forster wields rich, ornate prose and his depth of education to lay into eternal problems of faith versus rationalism, humanity versus sectarianism, and finding meaning in life's tear-strewn, seemingly arbitrary journey. A gripping and enriching story worthy of its reputation.

Title: Reality Sandwiches
Author: Allen Ginsberg
My Review: Always exciting, always experimental, endlessly captivating, this h(e/i)p cat knew where it was at.

Title: The Anathemata: Fragments of an Attempted Writing
Author: David Jones

Title: Gödel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid
Author: Douglas R. Hofstadter
My Review:
This book intrigued me primarily because of how amorphous and undefinable everyone thinks it is. Well, on that count, I'll take away the mystique: this is basically a cog-sci book, explaining how human intelligence works based on an idea from a famous mathematical theorem. The music and art references implied in the title are not nearly as involved in as I'd hoped. Bottom line: don't read this book if you don't like math.

If, like me, you wouldn't choose to read a book on math, but are amenable to one presented in a non-technical and fun way, then go ahead. I enjoyed it; it makes for fascinating (albeit demanding!) reading. (I can't say that I never felt a little lost, especially in the sections heaviest on Propositional Calculus.)

Title: The Problems of Philosophy
Author: Bertrand Russell
My Review: Written in a crisply understandable tone - and spanning a mere 91 pages - this philosophical primer will guide the newbie through the basic questions of Western epistemology, giving some quick overviews of Descartes, Kant and Hegel along the way. Metaphysics gets short shrift, but a note in the bibliography encourages the reader to bone up some Plato, where such goodies abound. Russell segues each chapter into the next, and stops before the end to give a helpful summary, before going into the limits of philosophy, and the reasons for which one should pursue it. A superb work of pop philosophy from one of the discipline's greatest luminaries.

Title: Philosophy of Mind (Foundations of Philosophy)
Author: Jerome A. Shaffer
My Review: A clear, engaging discussion of the basic issues dealt with by philosophers of mind.

Title: On Bullshit
Author: Harry G. Frankfurt
My Review: Better than you'd expect.

Title: Tao Te Ching
Author: Lao Tzu
Additional Authors: Gia-Fu Feng, Jane English, Chungliang Al Huang, Rowena Pattee Kryder, Toinette Lippe

Title: Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair
Author: Pablo Neruda
My Review: I know everybody's supposed to be 'over' Neruda or whatever, but wow. Even in translation the language sends shivers down your spine.

Title: Wittgenstein on Rules and Private Language: An Elementary Exposition
Author: Saul A. Kripke
My Review:
A great book on philosophy. Put very baldly, it posits that no word in our language can ever have a consistent meaning which can predict future use, and thus the only way we can define language is as something accepted by a group; basically (although Kripke doesn't use the phrase) a social construct, a "language-game" without any meaning outside of the group dynamic. This, a major reversal of the Tractatus, is from the the pragmatist late-Wittgenstein work Philosophical Investigations - although it is more accurately the basis of the independent beast known as 'Kripkenstein'.

I do not handle philosophical jargon well. This book, happily, is clear, lively and enjoyable (the footnotes can occasionally get a bit gnarly, though).

Title: Tender Buttons
Author: Gertrude Stein
My Review:
Sometimes writers like to recreate mimetically the rhythm of life, carefully recording speech and emotion as it is. Sometimes they prefer to engage in surrealism or stream-of-consciousness, opening up wider avenues of language. And sometimes they are Gertrude Stein.

This perplexing yet weirdly beautiful book of words contains a multitude of short bursts, sometimes circling around a particular object or feeling, and sometimes wheeling off on crazy tangents. Like Jackson Pollock's dazzling nothings, Stein takes words and twists them into bizarre forms of perception. Before Borges, the internet and @Horse_ebooks, this was happening - a mind-blowing concatenation of word-forms, affecting us in ways impossible to explain.

Title: SKETCHES FOR A LIFE OF WASSILY
Author: Lydia Davis
My Review: With haunting economy, Lydia Davis paints a portrait of a man mired in his own neuroses whose life is slowly wasting away.

Title: The Book of Evidence (The Freddie Montgomery Trilogy #1)
Author: John Banville
My Review: Is John Banville the best prose stylist of our generation?

Title: Fathers and Sons
Author: Ivan Turgenev
My Review: The sons return from university with modern, nihilistic ideas, but it is the sentimentality of the fathers - via failed love affairs and entangled jealousy - that wins out, reaffirming the centrality of humanism in understanding the mystery of being. A well-crafted and warm novel.

Title: Money
Author: Martin Amis
My Review: Pure '80s, in every way possible: the obsession with money; the glitzy, overdone hedonism; the condescending attitude towards women, gays and non-white people. It is also very funny in parts. Oh, and you probably won't guess the twist at the end.

Title: Irritant
Author: Darby Larson
Publisher: Blue Square Press, an imprint of Mud Luscious Press

Title: What We Talk About When We Talk About Anne Frank
Author: Nathan Englander

Title: Days of War Nights of Love: Crimethink for Beginners
Author: CrimethInc.

Title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
Author: Gabriel García Márquez
My Review:
What you think of this book very much depends on your opinion on magical realism as a whole. For some, it is uplifting and enchanting, while for others its sweetness sticks in the throat. This book follows several generations of the Buendia family of the village of Macondo, Colombia. They fall in love, have children (who they name after themselves, making it hard at times to keep track of things) and die.

There are moments that are likely to make you smile, and a very satisfying ending that nearly moved me to give it another star, but ultimately finishing this book was something of a chore. The characters are motivated by lust and superstition, usually to their own disadvantage. We stumble from one catastrophe to another. One interesting part of the book looks at the massacre of thousands of banana plantation workers by the company's ruthless overseas owners.

There are presumably points being made here about Colombia's history, the nature of human sexuality, and other universal topics. Perhaps I was inured to them by my Western sensibilities, unable to parse literary prose based on mythology and not salon discussions. Either way, I was vanquished by this book. It has a large and loyal fanbase, but if I am to join it, I will need to reread the book with a fresh mind - and I promise, that will not happen soon.

Title: Catch-22 (Catch-22, #1)
Author: Joseph Heller
My Review:
"The Texan turned out to be good-natured, generous and likable. In three days no one could stand him." All very well, but the (ab)use of paraprosdokian will only take one so far. That this book works at all owes less to the titular Catch and its concomitant ironies - which quickly become irritating - than to its surprisingly poignant descriptions of the boredom, humiliation and occasional abject terror of army life.
It is densely plotted, with an exploded chronology that can be hard to follow. But there is a clear divide between the exaggerated slapstick of the first two thirds, and the somber ending. The graft feels a little unnatural. Toward the end the generals abruptly metamorphose from bumbling idiots to menacing, Stalinist-style inquisitors. But behind all of these missteps, Heller is a strikingly accomplished prose stylist, and he evokes the horrors of war with great power.

Title: Georges Perec: A Life in Words
Author: David Bellos

Title: An Introduction to the History and Sources of Jewish Law
Author: Neil S. Hecht

Title: Great House
Author: Nicole Krauss
My Review:
Sharks in a tank, connected to people's brains, absorbing their nightmares. Because sharks are tough and can deal with trauma, or something like that.

Meh.

Title: Madame Bovary
Author: Gustave Flaubert
Additional Authors: Mark Overstall, Malcolm Bowie, Margaret Mauldon, Victor Villarraza, Tomás de C.  Duran
My Review: In a book with an almost painfully simple plot reside a multitude of touching moments. The dull moments in a marriage. Professional humiliation, shattered hopes. The struggle between naïve romanticism and society's dictates. At some points the plot seems to wander, but throughout this novel - ever somehow removed, yet never reproachful - we glimpse what seems ineluctably to be real life.

Title: The Scarlet Letter
Author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
My Review: While perhaps not attuned to this book's overall decidedly Romantic conceit, I enjoyed its trenchant, thoughtful and occasionally playful look at Puritanical New England.

Title: A Distant Episode: The Selected Stories
Author: Paul Bowles

Title: Under the Volcano
Author: Malcolm Lowry
My Review: Rich, dazzling, and packed to the gills with inter- and extratextual references, Under the Volcano is a modernist classic. The plot, tightly structured through twelve dense chapters, describes the death of an alcoholic British ex-consul stationed in a remote Mexican village, accompanied at times by his estranged wife Yvonne, childhood friend Monsieur Larouelle, and a brilliant, politically active stepbrother named Hugh. Multiple perspectives relate the story over time as the protagonist staggers through the day, suffering from DTs and bizarre hallucinations. At times I was overwhelmed by the ubiquitous symbolism and the daunting amount of callbacks to the literary canon. Surely this is a book that will reward multiple readings...can I put it back on my to-read list?

Title: The Prophet
Author: Kahlil Gibran
My Review: Moving, thought-provoking and inspirational. The biblical-style prose won't be everyone's cup of tea.

Title: Darkness at Noon
Author: Arthur Koestler
My Review:
"I knew I could end all of this by confessing" says Rubashov, the main character in 'Darkness at Noon'. "But I did not want to." At times, you may find yourself wishing he did, as his farcical show trial (which largely inspired George Orwell's '1984') drags out, step by incriminating step.

But it is the lengthy dialogues in which this book really shines, and where I began to understand the critical regard in which it is held. Rubashov is an old, loyal Party man who has finally diverged from his former comrades, including the sinister, Stalin-esque 'Number One', with whom he has always had an uneasy relationship. His arrest and interrogation come as little surprise to him - even, perhaps, a relief, during a time of constant purges - and he faces his fate with a stoic calm. His interlocutors are his old friend Ivanov and a humourless younger officer named Gletkin.

The characters debate the Machiavellian ethics of Stalinism. Ivanov claims that "the ends justify the means; that was and remains the only rule of political ethics". He sees the attainment of the socialist utopia as justifying any evils perpetrated by Party members. But both Ivanov and Rubashov feel moments of regret and cynicism, as they can see that the situation is not progressing as they had imagined.

Rubashov is a sensitive intellectual, in stark contrast with a lecherous neighbour in prison and with Gletkin, whom he sees as a "Neanderthal". He struggles to find meaning and reason in what is happening around him. The state has not achieved its goals, and has instead become an instrument of immense evil.

The questions raised by this book concern not only Marxists and members of the Left, but all human beings. In a society without God, how do we create meaning? Can groups of people ever be trusted not to abuse their power? If we labour to better ourselves, but are only left with heartbreak, should we then not have tried?

In the midst of his discussion with Ivanov, Rubashov brings up Raskolnikov from Dostoevsky's 'Crime and Punishment'. Ivanov scoffs. "Raskolnikov acted only for himself," he asserts. "Had he been acting for the party, his actions would have been fully justified." In this world of steely ideological certainty, there are no doubts. All morality is defined by the needs of the people. Bitter, facing down a world of darkness, Rubashov emphatically disagrees.

Title: The Tell-Tale Heart and Other Writings
Author: Edgar Allan Poe

Title: When the Women Come Out to Dance: Stories
Author: Elmore Leonard

Title: When the Women Come Out to Dance: Stories
Author: Elmore Leonard

Title: When the Women Come Out to Dance: Stories
Author: Elmore Leonard

Title: Maus I: A Survivor's Tale: My Father Bleeds History (Maus, #1)
Author: Art Spiegelman

Title: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time
Author: Mark Haddon

Title: To Kill a Mockingbird (To Kill a Mockingbird, #1)
Author: Harper Lee

Title: Friday the Rabbi Slept Late (The Rabbi Small Mysteries #1)
Author: Harry Kemelman

Title: The No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency (No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency #1)
Author: Alexander McCall Smith
